Prerequisite: 

  • CMPEN 270 or CMPEN 271
  • CMPSC 121 or CMPSC 201

 

TEXTBOOKS:

REQUIRED: 

 

  • Patterson, David A. and Hennessy, John L. Computer Organization and Design. 5th edition. (Do not buy the normal hard copy)

 

To subscribe for Computer Organization and Design textbook, it costs $72

 

1- Sign in or create an account at learn.zybooks.com

2- Enter zyBook code "PSUCMPEN331AlmekkawySpring2025"

 

 

The first chapter of any zyBook is open to students without payment so everyone in the class can get started right away! If any student needs an extension in complimentary access beyond the first chapter, please follow these instructions to request longer access.

Zybook help center for students can be found here and is also linked via the help/FAQ button in the top right-hand corner of the zyBooks platform. 

 

REFERENCES:

  1. Andrew Tanenbaum and Todd Austin. Structured Computer Organization, 6th edition, Pearson
  2. Linda Null and Julia Lobur. The Essentials of Computer Organization and Architecture, 4th edition, Jones & Bartlett Learning.
  3. William Stallings, Computer Organization and Architecture, 10th edition, Pearson
  4. Carl Hamacher, Zvonko Vranesic, Safwat Zaky, Naraig Manjikian. Computer Organization and Embedded Systems, 6th edition, Mc Graw Hill
  5. Kip Irvine, Assembly Language for Intel-Based Computers, Prentice Hall. 

 

SOFTWARE TOOLS:

  • MARS, Xilinx Vivado.
  • For the assembly language, you will need an environment in which you can edit, assemble, link and run assembly-language programs. We will use a Freeware simulator called MARS to support the required assembly language programming. This software is available for download from the following link MARS "https://dpetersanderson.github.io", MARS itself has a nice Help feature. “http://courses.missouristate.edu/KenVollmar/MARS/”.
  • For the Verilog language, you will need to use Xilinx Vivado/ModelSim. This is available in w136 Westgate building. You can also download Vivado (It is available for windows machine and it is not available for Mac). Instructions for downloading the Vivado WebPack version can be found here: “ https://www.xilinx.com/support/download.html”. Xilinx has a strict internal export control policy which blocks users from E or D category countries. Check this file for more details: https://www.bis.doc.gov/index.php/documents/regulation-docs/2255-supplement-no-1-to-part-740-country-groups-1/file.
  • Students are facing different issues while installing Vivado. So, I request everyone to complete the installation as soon as possible.
  • It is very recommended to install Vivado as all the labs hints are using this software. However, students facing the Vivado license issue should install an alternative software called "Intel Quartus".
  • This is very uncommon but just to let you know that students who are outside the United States may face difficulties with respect to Vivado webpack installation due to license issues. They can install the Intel Quartus software instead. This problem occurred due to obligations of export controls and related license agreement restrictions for Vivado. In this case, students are not allowed to use any such controlled software even remotely if they are in a location forbidden by said agreements. Accordingly, you are not permitted to use Vivado even if you have the access to log in remotely to w135 in Westgate building or any other lab that you have access to here in the United States.
  • Follow the following steps to install Quartus software:
  • Go to this website: https://fpgasoftware.intel.com/?edition=lite.
  • Select Edition: Lite Select Release: 19.1
  • Go to combined files tab => Download .tar file
  • Extract the downloaded .tar file
  • Then, run "QuartusLiteSetup" file which should automatically install all other files.
  • If it asks for user sign in, then just create an account using college mail id and use it to sign in.

INSTRUCTIONS FOR THE REMOTE LOGIN TO W135 WESTGATE BUILDING:

 

The hostnames are e5-cse-135-01.cse.psu.edu through e5-cse-135-38.cse.psu.edu and can be accessed remotely once connected to the PSU Globalprotect vpn.  The Windows machines are not accessible remotely but are available at w136 Westgate.

Students need to connect to GlobalProtect vpn and then ssh to one of the w135 Linux machines.

 

COURSE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES:

 

Critical thinking, problem solving and information literacy: Students will use critical thinking and problem solving skills in analyzing information gathered through different media and from a variety of sources.

 By the end of the semester, successful student will be expected to Identify/Recognize:

  • Digital Logic Circuits and how data is represented
  • Computer organization
  • Assembler directives and the Instruction set
  • How to write small programs in assembly language and translate them to machine code
  • Combine basic digital circuitry components to process subsets of machine code
  • MIPS and data path with pipeline implementation
  • Verilog test bench and familiarity with Zynq 7000 Development Board
  • Memory Hierarchy
  • Storage and I/O devices

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

REQUIRED WORK

 

Homework

Problems will be assigned weekly or biweekly. Late homework will not receive any credit. However, you have the permission to miss one of the homework without penalty. You have to solve the online problems in the zyBooks website (https://www.zybooks.com). Some of the problems will be assigned in advance of covering their corresponding materials in class.

 

Exams

There will be three midterm exams. Each student is entitled to skip one exam due to official reasons without incurring any penalties. Consequently, no makeup exam will be granted for the first missed exam. You will only be eligible for a particular makeup exam if you have missed two or more exams due to official excuses. Please be aware that if you choose to miss one exam for personal reasons, it will count towards your official number of allowable excuses mentioned earlier. It is strongly recommended not to miss any exams unless you have an official excuse. Official excuses need to be approved by the instructor in advance. Please refer to the 'Guidelines for Makeup Examinations' for further information. I will not respond to any email that requesting a makeup exam unless it satisfies the aforementioned policy.

 

Quizzes

6 – 9 pre-announced quizzes will be given during the semester, (no makeups, unless you have more than a defined number of official excuses), I will not respond to any email that requesting a makeup quiz unless it satisfies the aforementioned policy.  Every student will have a defined number, in advance, of excuses to use them for skipping any defined number of quizzes if needed (these can be personal or official excuses). Meaning that, I will drop the lowest defined number of scores. This defined number is currently equal to two and it could increase in the future. You must take a permission in advance from the instructor if you would like to take your quiz with another section. Cheating on any QUIZ will result in 0 grade on that QUIZ.

 

Labs

Lab assignments will be assigned on canvas. Late submissions will incur a penalty of 2% per day, up to a maximum of 5 days (with one minute being equivalent to one day). It is advisable to adhere to timely submission and refrain from relying on the available late submission days. Your proactive approach to meeting deadlines is highly encouraged. No submission will be accepted after the 5th day of the due date. TAs or LAs (if any) will grade the submitted zipped file to canvas. Please expect that we might pick randomly some students to grade their submitted labs through one to one meeting with the grader. In this case, your answers have to match your submission and you need to show your understanding of your solution. Your GRADE will depend solely on your answers to the grader(s) questions in that particular lab. The same apply for the project stated in the next item.

 

Project

There will be one project. This project due date will be posted online, late submission will not be accepted.

 

Guidelines for Makeup Examinations or Delayed Assignment Submission:

- A self-report or standard doctor's appointment is not considered an acceptable reason or suffice as an excuse.

 

- Evidence from an in-person visit with a healthcare practitioner, explicitly demonstrating the inability to partake in the exam/quiz as originally scheduled, is necessary.

 

- It must be emphasized that under these circumstances too, notifications regarding excuses have to be delivered at least 24 hours before the designated assignment due date. This is crucial as late submission requests beyond the assignment deadline or approved grace period will not be accommodated.

 

-An email petition sent by a student on the day of or one day prior to the exam requesting a makeup examination does not ensure automatic acceptance by the instructor.

 

-Unexcused absence from an examination without prior consent of the instructor will disqualify students from being allowed a makeup opportunity regardless of their situation.

 

GRADING:

Homework: 5%

Labs: 20%

Quizzes: 25%

Exam 1: 15% (Tentative: Week of February 24th in class)

Exam 2: 15% (Tentative: Week of March 31st in class)

Exam 3: 15% (Tentative: Week of April 21st in class)

Project: 5 %

 

GRADING DISTRIBUTION:

A  100-94                    B+  < 90 - 86               C+  < 77 - 73               D  < 68 - 61

A-  <94- 90                  B    < 86 - 81               C     < 73 - 68              F   < 61 - 0

                                    B-    < 81-77                                       

 

COURSE POLICIES

 

Engaging in academic dishonesty during any examination will result in a grade of 0 for that specific examination. Violations will be subject to academic integrity consequences, which may include failure of the course in certain instances. This applies also to quizzes, problem sets, labs or project. 

 

While we will make every effort to communicate both in person and online, students are responsible for being aware of any in-person announcements that may not have been posted online

 

Cell phones: All cell phones should either be turned off or set to a silent mode all the time. No phone calls or text messages may be sent within the classroom – if it is important to take a call or text, please leave the classroom to do so, and be prepared to make up the missed material outside of the class.

 

Laptops /Tablets: Please limit your activities on such devices to those which aid in your studies. It is your responsibility to maintain proper focus on the material being presented, as not all course material will be in electronic form.

 

Other devices: Unless otherwise permitted by the instructor, please keep other devices turned off during classroom activities.

 

Attendance Policy: Class attendance is one of the most important ways students learn and understand course materials. It is a critical element of student success. Class attendance recognizes on exceptional occasions.

 

Changes in syllabus and assignment sheets may be modified. All changes will be announced in class or/and online. 

EECS ACADEMIC INTEGRITY MODULE

The information is available on Canvas and includes additional details regarding the use of Generative AI tools. Please ensure that you complete all listed items, including the EECS Academic Integrity Quiz

 

ACCOMMODATIONS FOR STUDENTS WITH DISABILITIES     

Penn State welcomes students with disabilities into the University’s educational programs. Every Penn State campus has an office for students with disabilities. Student Disability Resources (SDR) website provides contact information for every Penn State campus. For further information, please visit Student Disability Resources website.

In order to receive consideration for reasonable accommodations, you must contact the appropriate disability services office at the campus where you are officially enrolled, participate in an intake interview, and provide documentation: See documentation guidelines. If the documentation supports your request for reasonable accommodations, your campus disability services office will provide you with an accommodation letter. Please share this letter with your instructors and discuss the accommodations with them as early as possible. You must follow this process for every semester that you request accommodations.

 

COUNSELING AND PSYCHOLOGICAL SERVICES

Many students at Penn State face personal challenges or have psychological needs that may interfere with their academic progress, social development, or emotional wellbeing. The university offers a variety of confidential services to help you through difficult times, including individual and group counseling, crisis intervention, consultations, online chats, and mental health screenings. These services are provided by staff who welcome all students and embrace a philosophy respectful of clients’ cultural and religious backgrounds, and sensitive to differences in race, ability, gender identity and sexual orientation.

Counseling and Psychological Services at University Park  (CAPS)  
(http://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/): 814-863-0395  

  

Counseling and Psychological Services at Commonwealth Campuses  
(https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/caps-campuses)  

Penn State Crisis Line (24 hours/7 days/week): 877-229-6400
Crisis Text Line (24 hours/7 days/week): Text LIONS to 741741

 

EDUCATIONAL EQUITY/REPORT BIAS STATEMENTS

Penn State University has adopted a “Protocol for Responding to Bias Motivated Incidents” that is grounded in the policy that the “University is committed to creating an educational environment which is free from intolerance directed toward individuals or groups and strives to create and maintain an environment that fosters respect for others.” That policy is embedded within an institution traditionally committed to
academic freedom Bias motivated incidents include conduct that is defined in University
Policy AD 91: Discrimination and Harassment, and Related Inappropriate Conduct. Students, faculty, or staff who experience or witness a possible bias motivated incident are urged to report the incident immediately by doing one of the following:

* Submit a report via the Report Bias webpage
* Contact one of the following offices:

University Police Services, University Park: 814-863-1111
Multicultural Resource Center, Diversity Advocate for Students: 814-865-1773
Office of the Vice Provost for Educational Equity: 814-865-5906
Office of the Vice President for Student Affairs: 814-865-0909
Affirmative Action Office: 814-863-0471

* Dialing 911 in cases where physical injury has occurred or is imminent

 

ACADEMIC INTEGRITY STATEMENT

Academic integrity is the pursuit of scholarly activity in an open, honest, and responsible manner. Academic integrity is a basic guiding principle for all academic activity at The Pennsylvania State University, and all members of the University community are expected to act in accordance with this principle.

 

According to Penn State policy G-9: Academic Integrity, an academic integrity violation is “an intentional, unintentional, or attempted violation of course or assessment policies to gain an academic advantage or to advantage or disadvantage another student academically.” Unless your instructor tells you otherwise, you must complete all course work entirely on your own, using only sources that have been permitted by your instructor, and you may not assist other students with papers, quizzes, exams, or other assessments. If your instructor allows you to use ideas, images, or word phrases created by another person (e.g., from Course Hero or Chegg) or by generative technology, such as ChatGPT, you must identify their source. You may not submit false or fabricated information, use the same academic work for credit in multiple courses, or share instructional content. Students with questions about academic integrity should ask their instructor before submitting work.

Students facing allegations of academic misconduct may not drop/withdraw from the affected course unless they are cleared of wrongdoing (see G-9: Academic Integrity). Attempted drops will be prevented or reversed, and students will be expected to complete course work and meet course deadlines. Students who are found responsible for academic integrity violations face academic outcomes, which can be severe, and put themselves at jeopardy for other outcomes which may include ineligibility for Dean’s List, pass/fail elections, and grade forgiveness. Students may also face consequences from their home/major program and/or The Schreyer Honors College.

 

Appropriate behavior expectations

Sexual misconduct is never tolerated at Penn State. Prohibited conduct includes sexual and gender-based harassment, stalking, sexual assault, and dating violence. These behaviors are not allowed in the classroom, the campus community, labs, or anywhere students, staff, and faculty are located. Prohibited behaviors can include degrading comments such as belittling female-identified students, LGBTQ+ individuals, and gender-diverse students. It can also include harassment, touching someone without their consent, following someone without consent, repeated calls or messaging, physical acts of violence, and more. In other words, professional and appropriate behavior is always expected, and inappropriate or unprofessional behavior is never tolerated. For more information, please refer to the Student Code of Conduct and Penn State Policies AD85 and AD91. (Title IX Sexual Harassment | Penn State Policies (psu.edu) and Discrimination and Harassment and Related Inappropriate Conduct | Penn State Policies (psu.edu)) 

 

If you or anyone you know has experienced or is concerned about inappropriate or unprofessional behavior, you can talk with College, or School leadership, your instructor, academic advisor, or another trusted faculty/staff member, report to police or the Office of Sexual Misconduct Reporting & Response (titleix.psu.edu), or you can seek confidential support and assistance from the Gender Equity Center. The Gender Equity Center supports any student who has had negative relationship experiences including those impacted by sexual violence, relationship violence, stalking, harassment, and other campus climate issues. Services include one on one crisis intervention/support, advocacy, exploring options, accommodations, safety planning, and referrals. They also promote awareness, build support for survivors, and conduct educational programs and events. All services are free and confidential. Gender Equity Center | Penn State Student Affairs (psu.edu) 

 

 

* Source: http://keepteaching.psu.edu/ and https://senate.psu.edu/ as of 12/5/22  

* Last updated February 2, 2024 

 

 

Whom should I contact if I need additional assistance?

I encourage you to contact your academic adviser for specific needs you might have outside this course.  Academic adviser information and scheduling can be found at starfish.psu.edu.

 

How will I get updated information from PSU?

As the instructor for this course, I strongly encourage you to abide by the requirements Penn State has communicated regarding testing and returning to campus. This information is evolving, but you can find the latest here. Check your PSU email and the Penn State Go app daily for updates from the University, your college, department, and instructors. We use your PSU email address to make sure you have the most up-to-date information. It will be very important for you to check Penn State’s keeplearning.psu.edu page for helpful information about the Spring semester.

documents.title: Lab Assignment 0.5
documents.content:
Due Jan. 31, 2025, by 11:59 pm, Points 100 (2% weight towards the final grade), Submitting a text entry box

Instructions

  • Log in to your virtual machine.
  • Click on this invitational link, and a private repository will be created for you after accepting the assignment. 
  • Follow the instructions from this document to set up your git environment.
  • To clone (i.e., download) the starter artifacts from a terminal in your virtual machine :
    • % mkdir cmpsc311
    • % cd cmpsc311
    • % git clone git@github.com:PSU-CMPSC311-SAHA/sp25-labhalf-<your_github_username>.git
    • % cd sp25-labhalf-<your_github_username>
    • [ START EDITING ]

 

   Once cloned, you will have the starter files in the sp25-labhalf-<your_github_username>.

  • To complete this assignment, you are to:
    1. Create a file named IDs
    2. Edit the IDs file and put your 9 digits PSU ID in the first line, and your PSU username in the second line. No other text or comment should be added to the file (A sample file with  fake PSU ID and username is provided).
  • To submit your changes via git (following the git instructions):
    1. Prepare your changes using the git add command
    2. Commit your changes with an appropriate message using git commit command
    3. Push your changes using the git push command
       
  • It is good practice to commit and push your code regularly if you run into issues with your machine (Note: you must commit all files marked as changed when running 'git status').

To turn in:

After completing the assignment, submit on Canvas the commit ID that should be graded without additional text/words/comments around it.

Note: To get the commit ID (7 digits) that you want to be graded (usually the latest one), go to your repository page on GitHub.com, click on the last column named "<#> commits" in the top right, and then copy the commit ID from the Commits History page.

Note: To get the commit ID that you want to be graded (usually the latest one), go to your repository page on GitHub.com, click on the last column named "<#> commits" in the top right, and copy the commit ID (7 characters long ).

 

Grading Rubrics:  

  • Working code/Passing test cases: 95%
  • Descriptive/relevant comments: 5%

 Note:

  • If "make" generates errors or warnings or if your code enters an infinite loop, you will receive a 0 for this lab.
  • Failure to submit your commit ID on Canvas by the due date will result in a 0.
  • Penalties: 10% per day for late submission (up to 3 days)
  • The lab assignment will not be graded if it is more than 3 days late

 

Edit1: We have updated the ReadMe to correct the Armstrong example. 2 is an Armstrong number, so it should be cubed.

documents.title: Lab Assignment 2
documents.content:
Due Feb. 28, 2025, by 11:59 pm, Points 100 (9.6% weight towards the final grade), Submitting a text entry box

Available Feb. 14, 2025 - Mar. 3, 2025 at 11:59 pm 
Note: This lab has a checkpoint, whose deadline is Feb 23. There will be a 50% penalty for missing the checkpoint submission. You do not need to submit anything in Canvas for the checkpoint because we will download the last version in GitHub as your checkpoint version.  

Lab 2 is a critical part of this course, serving as the foundation for all future labs. Unlike Lab 1, which was a warm-up to C, Lab 2 is the main building block for Labs 3, 4, and 5. You will not be able to complete the later labs if you do not finish Lab 2.

It is very important that you read the instructions provided in the ReadMe_LAB2.pd carefully before starting this assignment.  Do not delay starting the assignment—plan your time wisely!
To help you better understand this lab we have created  a helper video which we hope you find useful: https://psu.mediaspace.kaltura.com/media/CMPSC311%3A+Lab+2+Helper+Video/1_8xdlsxij 
Please do not use the video as a substitute for ReadMe.  

 

Instructions

  • Log in to your virtual machine.
  • Click on this invitational link, and a private repository will be created for you after accepting the assignment. 
  • Clone the repository by running git clone git@github.com:PSU-CMPSC311-SAHA/sp2-lab2-<your_github_username>.git
  • Read ReadMe_LAB2.pdf and start your implementation
  • Check the checkpoint requirement 

Remember to push your code to your repository before the deadline(s). 

To turn in:

Commit and push your latest code to Github. Then, submit on Canvas the commit ID that should be graded with no additional text/word/comment around it.

Note: To get the commit ID that you want to be graded (usually the latest one), go to your repository page on GitHub.com, click on the last column named "<#> commits" in the top right, and copy the commit ID (7 characters long ).

 

Grading Rubrics:  

  • Passing test cases: 95%
  • Adding meaningful descriptive comments: 5%
  • If you have any make errors or warnings or if the program is stuck in a loop, then you will receive a straight 0. Make sure your code does not have any make errors before submitting
  • If you do not submit your commit ID on Canvas, you will receive a straight 0
  • We will use the timestamp on Canvas when you submit your commit ID to assess any late penalty. If you push your work on time on github.com but submit the commit ID late on Canvas, your work will be considered late and will incur a late penalty.

documents.title: Week #1
documents.content:
Weekly Quiz and Extra Credit Opportunity

This quiz consists of 10 questions based on the topics covered so far in the class in the week, with a 10-minute time limit for completion. Participation in this quiz offers you the chance to earn extra credit. For detailed information about the weekly extra credit opportunities, please refer to the syllabus on Canvas (Syllabus for CMPSC 311: Intro Sys Prog - SP25).

Each week, you will have one quiz like this, focusing on the material covered during that week. As a reminder, this quiz is purely for extra credit and does not affect the general grading scheme.

To help you prepare, we are providing additional study materials each week. You can find these resources in the "Files" section of the Canvas course under the "Microlearning" folder. (Files (instructure.com))

documents.title: Lab 2 checkpoint help with additional office hour
documents.content:
As you are aware, the Checkpoint deadline is Sunday, February 23.

Struggling with Finishing the Checkpoint:

If you are facing difficulties, here are some immediate steps you can take:

  • Visit Office Hours Today – Get direct help from TAs and LAs. (We have them till 7 pm)
  • Watch the Helper Video – It covers key concepts for Lab 2.
  • Check Campuswire Discussions – Your question may have already been answered.
  • Read the Entire PDF Carefully – Many issues arise from missing details in the instructions.

 Need Additional Help?

If you are still stuck, you can use any of the following to get additional help:

  • Use Office Hours – Ask TAs and LAs for guidance.
  • Post Questions on Campuswire – Get help from peers and staff. This is one of the fastest ways to get help.
  • Email TAs/LAs –if your Campuswire question remains unanswered.

Special Office Hours on Sunday: If you have tried all of the above and still need help, I will hold special office hours on Sunday from 12:00 PM – 1:00 PM (via my regular OH Zoom link).

 What You Need to Understand for Lab 2:

To successfully implement Lab 2, make sure you understand the following:

  1. Difference between the 16 individual disks vs. the abstraction of a linear disk.
  2. How jbod_operation() controls the 16 disks.
  3. How to use the op parameter in jbod_operation().
  4. How to construct an op for specific operations (e.g., how to read a block from disk 2, block 1).
    •  Refer to Slide 10 of the Helper Video 
  5. How to translate the linear address to disk id, block id, and potential offset (not required for the checkpoint)

 Example: Constructing an op for Reading a Block

If you want to read from disk 2, block 1, here’s how you construct the 32-bit op value:

Step 1: Identify Components

  • Command: JBOD_READ_BLOCK (value = 4 in jbod.h, which is 100 in binary).
  • Disk ID: 2 (binary = 10).
  • Block ID: 1 (binary = 00000001).

Step 2: Format According to the Lab 2 ReadMe (Table 1)

The 32-bit op is structured as:
<8 bits for block ID> <4 bits for disk ID> <14 bits reserved> <6 bits for command>

Using our values op would be:
00000001 0010 00000000000000 000100 = 00000001001000000000000000000100= 18874372

Step 3: Pass to jbod_operation()

The above op integer value is what you must pass as the first parameter to jbod_operation().

Incorrect Usage Examples:
I have seen a lot of students using the following format for op in jbod_operation

jbod_operation(JBOD_READ_BLOCK, buff); jbod_operation(JBOD_MOUNT, NULL);

These do not follow the correct op format!




To construct an op, you can:

  • Create a helper function to properly format the op.
  • Use bitwise and shift operators to place each field (disk ID, block ID, command) in the correct position.

Let us know if you have any questions! 
We are here to help!

-
Neeraj

documents.title: Midterm-1: Important Information
documents.content:
Dear All,

Your Midterm-1 will be held on 17th February at 8:10 - 10:00 pm. 

Duration of the exam: 1 hour 50 minutes

Location
Forum 108: Students whose last names begin with 'A' to 'M' (A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M)
Keller 104: Students whose last names begin with 'N' to 'Z' (N, O, P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, W, X, Y, Z)


Logistics

  • Arrive on time (ideally 10-15 minutes early) at the beginning of the exam.
  • Have a pen/pencil and your student ID card ready.
  • Shut down your smartphone and all other electronic devices (smartwatch, laptop, tablet, etc.) and leave them in your backpack. No calculator is allowed for this exam.
  • Anyone caught with a smartphone or other electronic device, cheat sheet material, etc., during the exam will be asked to leave the room immediately, get a 0, and receive an academic integrity violation.
  • If you finish the exam before the end, stand up, hand out your exam to a TA, and leave the room quietly.
  • CMPSC 311 course does not have any online version of any exam.


Exam Policy for Make-Up and Conflict Exam

Please note the following policy regarding exams for this course:

Conflict/Make-Up Exam:

There will be only one conflict/Makeup exam.
A conflict/Make-up exam will be offered only to students with a verified scheduling conflict and health issue.
To be eligible, students must provide appropriate documentation as proof of the conflict and other reasons.

Penalties for Missing the Conflict/Make-Up Exam:

If you cannot attend the conflict/Make-Up exam and request another conflict/Make-Up exam,  you will get a 25% penalty on points. This is a department-wise policy.

Unless you have a genuine scheduling conflict or health issue, we strongly encourage all students to attend the main exam. Once again. We ask for your cooperation in adhering to this policy to ensure fairness for everyone. If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to contact us.


Syllabus

1. VM
2. System Programming
3. Unix OS
4. Unix Essentials
5. Git & Shell
6. Intro to C
7. Arrays and Pointers
8. Types, Structs, and Union
9. Bits/Bytes Operation


Bonus Points in the Exam

This exam includes bonus questions worth 10 points, bringing the total possible
points to 110 (100 points + 10 bonus points).

How bonus question works: The maximum score for this exam is 100 points. If you
answer all questions correctly, you will earn 100 points (100%). If the total of your
attempt in the whole exam is less than 100 points, for example: say 60 pts out of
110 pts, your final score is 60 out of 100 (60%).

 

I wish you good luck on your exam!

 


Regards

Teaching Team

documents.title: Fifth Week of CMPSC 311
documents.content:
Dear Students,

Welcome to the fifth week of CMPSC 311! This week, we will types in C programming and bit/byte arrangement in system.
 

Assignment#1

You need to submit your Assignment#1 by this week, which is due on 14th February.


We published Lab Assignment #1 on 31st January, which involves writing small C programs to solve various problems. This assignment is designed to help you understand how to use basic programming components in C, such as arrays, loops, and more. documents.title: Academic Integrity in EECS
documents.content: Module: Academic Integrity in EECS

documents.title: What is Academic Integrity (AI)?
documents.content:
NOTE: It is a bit confusing that the abbreviation AI is used for both "Academic Integrity" and "Artificial Intelligence", especially since the improper use of Artificial Intelligence tools is a common way to commit an Academic Integrity violation. In this module, the term AI always refers to Academic Integrity.

Message from the Director of the School of EECS

Academic Integrity is the pursuit of scholarly activity in an open, honest and responsible manner (University Faculty Senate Policy 49-20). Falsifying any aspect of your academic work jeopardizes the entire education process.

In this module, we will discuss:

  • Why academic integrity is important​
  • Types of academic integrity violations​
  • Consequences of academic integrity violations​
  • Academic integrity violation process

What is Academic Integrity?

Why is AI Important?

Types of AI Violations

Consequences of AI Violations

AI Violation Process

Take the Quiz

documents.title: Why is Academic Integrity Important?
documents.content:
Practice Makes Perfect

Engineering is an ethical profession, and unethical practices in the workplace can have dire consequences. Just like you learn and practice other tools that you’ll use in the real world (programming languages, test equipment, simulation software, etc.), practicing integrity in an academic setting will help you make ethical decisions once you’re in the workforce. Practice makes perfect!

All engineers and scientists need to follow codes of ethics. Here are a few examples of professional codes of ethics in related fields:

  • IEEE Code of Ethics
  • ACM Code of Ethics
  • NSPE Code of Ethics

While the consequences of violating academic integrity standards can be steep, the consequences of ethics violations in the workplace can be even more detrimental, including:

  • being terminated from a job
  • fines being levied onto individuals and/or companies
  • legal action
  • injury/death to users of products that were jeopardized by unethical practices

There are many examples of lapses in ethical judgment in industry that led to lawsuits, injuries, or even death. Here are some high-profile cases:

Connection Between Academic Integrity & Professional Ethics

In the real world, it is generally acceptable to look up existing resources/code, and sometimes even directly utilize existing libraries in one's project, granted that while doing so you are giving trust to the resource(s) you are using. However, if one does not have a thorough understanding of the code/library they use, this could pose security problems. The code may contain errors or even intentional malicious backdoor traps. For example, here are five common accidental sources of data leaks. You must be able to properly scrutinize, vet, or modify the code you find through other resources. If you haven't properly learned the material, you could be opening yourself, and others, to harm.

In an academic setting, the goal of projects/assessments is to learn. Looking up answers, or even submitting modified code/work from others after understanding what it does is not a good way to learn or a sustainable practice. Instructors may utilize existing resources as good, or bad, examples to help you learn, but you must develop a strong foundation to build on, so you are able to be competitive and innovative once you enter the workforce.

What is Academic Integrity?

Why is AI Important?

Types of AI Violations

Consequences of AI Violations

AI Violation Process

Take the Quiz

documents.title: Types of AI Violations
documents.content:
Below are some types of violations typically seen in EECS courses. This is not necessarily a complete list of types of AI violations, because what is considered to be an AI violation can vary from course to course, or even from assignment to assignment. You should always consult your course syllabus for details about the Academic Integrity policy and expectations for that particular course. If you're unsure whether something is ethical, consult your instructor.

AI Violations in the Lab

Examples of academic integrity violations in the lab include things like:

  • Falsifying data
    • Making up data if you don't finish an experiment
    • Changing data to make it closer to what you expect
    • Copying data from other students or lab groups
  • Using circuits designed by other students or lab groups
  • Using Artificial Intelligence tools to complete any part of the assignment unless explicitly permitted by the instructor
  • Copying answers to lab questions from other students
  • Sharing any data, circuit designs, or answers with other students
  • Posting any of your lab results on any internet website or message forum, even after the lab is over

Key Points

  • What is considered to be an AI violation can vary from course to course, or even from assignment to assignment.
  • Always check with your course instructor to determine the AI rules for that course.
  • Read the course syllabus for details on Academic Integrity.
  • The use of Artificial Intelligence tools (e.g., ChatGPT) to complete any part of an assignment is considered an AI violation, unless explicitly permitted by the instructor.
  • Sharing answers, code, or specific details about assignments or exams with others that would offer an unfair advantage is always considered an AI violation, even after the assessment is over.
  • In the case of AI, it is NOT easier to ask for forgiveness than for permission! When in doubt, ask for clarification.

AI Violations in Programming Courses

Examples of academic integrity violations in programming courses include things like:

  • Submitting code that is not your original work as your own work, such as:
    • Submitting code (partially or fully) copied from other people except course staff
    • Submitting code (partially or fully) copied from any external sources (public forums, group messages, public GitHub repositories, etc.)
    • Using Artificial Intelligence tools to complete any part of the assignment unless explicitly permitted by the instructor
    • Looking up code anywhere and then making changes to copied code. This does not make the code your own. Your submitted code must be your original work.
    • Failure to clearly identify code from an external source and/or collaboration and to properly credit the source even when it is explicitly allowed by the course
  • Not securing your own code and intentionally or unintentionally facilitating others to violate academic integrity.
    • Posting your code online that is visible by other people, such as:
      • Posting to public GitHub repositories
      • Posting to online forums and/or group messages
    • Providing any part of your code to another student
    • Leaving your code unattended in public locations (i.e., on an unlocked machine in a public space)
    • Sharing any part of your code with another student or posting any part of your code on any internet website or message forum, even after the assignment is over.

There is no fixed percentage threshold of similarities for code to be considered an academic integrity violation. We rely on the expertise of the instructors to determine whether similarities rise above what a reasonable person could expect two students working independently to construct.

AI Violations When Taking Exams

Examples of academic integrity violations with exams include things like:

  • Using unauthorized resources
    • Calculator, if not permitted
    • Notes or formula sheets, if not permitted
    • Books, if not permitted
    • Communication devices of any kind
  • Obtaining (or attempting to obtain) answers from or discussing exam content with others

For take-home or online exams:

  • Using unauthorized internet resources (including Artificial Intelligence tools such as ChatGPT)
  • Seeking assistance from or providing assistance to others (either in-person or online)
  • Posting any take-home or online exam on an internet website or message forum, even after the exam is over

AI Violations in Completing Homework

Examples of academic integrity violations in homework include:

  • Using unauthorized solution manuals
  • Using Chegg or other online "tutoring" resources
  • Using Artificial Intelligence tools to complete any part of the assignment unless explicitly permitted by the instructor
  • Copying other students' homework
  • Sharing your work with others

Other Types of AI Violations

Some other examples of AI violations include:

  • Plagiarism
  • Improper citation of materials used
  • Falsifying attendance record
  • Falsifying assignment submission record
  • Misrepresenting absences (e.g. feigning illness)

For more details, visit University Policy G-9: Academic Integrity.

What is Academic Integrity?

Why is AI Important?

Types of AI Violations

Consequences of AI Violations

AI Violation Process

Take the Quiz

documents.title: Consequences of an AI Violation
documents.content:
AI Violation Sanctions

If you are found responsible for an AI violation in a course, the sanction (punishment) may be academic and/or administrative, and may consist of one or more of the following, depending on the nature of the violation:

Academic Sanctions

  • Having to redo the assignment
  • Grade penalty on the assignment
  • Grade of zero (0) on the assignment
  • Lowering of a course grade by one (or more) letter grade(s)
  • F in the course
  • Having to participate in ethics/integrity workshops
  • XF (F for the course with a transcript notation)
  • Removal from your degree program

Administrative Sanctions

Note: The faculty member and the College of Engineering Academic Integrity Committee can recommend disciplinary sanctions, but they can be imposed only by the Penn State Office of Student Accountability and Conflict Response.

  • Formal warning
  • Conduct probation
  • Suspension from the University
  • Permanent expulsion from the University

Other Automatic Consequences of AI Violations

If you are found responsible of an AI violation in a course, the following restrictions will be automatically imposed, in addition to any academic/administrative sanctions above.

  • You are not permitted to drop the course
  • You are not permitted to use alternate grading for that course (if alternate grading is in place that semester)
  • You are not permitted to use grade forgiveness for that course
  • You are not eligible for Dean’s List that semester
  • Possible removal from the Schreyer’s Honors College
  • Possible removal from ROTC

What is Academic Integrity?

Why is AI Important?

Types of AI Violations

Consequences of AI Violations

AI Violation Process

Take the Quiz

documents.title: Academic Integrity Violation Process
documents.content:
If a student is suspected of committing an AI violation in a course, the following steps are taken:

  • The instructor speaks to the student regarding their concerns and completes the AI violation form.
    • Description of suspected violation
    • Proposed sanction
  • The student has five (5) business days to respond to the accusation.
    • The student can accept both the violation accusation and sanction.
    • The student can contest (challenge) either the violation itself, the sanction, or both.
    • If the student does not respond within 5 business days, the case proceeds as if the student accepted the accusation and sanction.
  • If the student accepts both the accusation and sanction, the sanction is imposed (see note below about previous confirmed violations).
  • If you contest either the sanction or the accusation itself, the College of Engineering will conduct a hearing with a panel of faculty members and students. The panel will decide one of the following:
    • You are not responsible for the violation.
    • You are held responsible, but with reduced sanctions.
    • You are held responsible, and the proposed sanctions are imposed.
    • You are held responsible, and additional sanctions are imposed (see note below about previous confirmed violations).

Once an academic integrity case is resolved, and sanctions are imposed, the results of the violation are filed with the Penn State Office of Student Accountability and Conflict Response and basic information is shared with Schreyer Honors College (when applicable), but are not shared with others, except in cases of some administrative sanctions or when the student has a future academic integrity violation, in accordance with FERPA rules.

Note: If a student with a current confirmed violation has any prior violation(s) of academic integrity at Penn State, the current case and the academic integrity history is reviewed, likely with additional sanctions imposed. This review and addition of sanctions happens whether or not the student contests the current violation, even if the prior violation was in a different course. Augmented sanctions are typically only imposed for students who have confirmed past AI violations (either accepted or contested and upheld). For first violations, the Committee typically defers to the instructor's judgment regarding academic sanctions if the instructor's proposed academic sanctions are reasonable under the circumstances and fall within Penn State's Sanctioning Guidelines for Violations of Academic Integrity. The Committee, however, retains the discretion to increase sanctions if the details and circumstances of the violation indicate the action to be a major or egregious violation.

For more details, visit AAPPM: G-9 Academic Integrity.

What is Academic Integrity?

Why is AI Important?

Types of AI Violations

Consequences of AI Violations

AI Violation Process

Take the Quiz

documents.title: Week 1
documents.content: Module: Week 1

documents.title: Notes: Virtual Machine
documents.content:
Operating System

An operating system is a software that acts as an interface and abstraction between the computer user and computer hardware and controls the execution of programs.

The operating system (OS) manages all of the computer's software and hardware. It performs basic tasks such as file, memory, and process management, handling input and output, and controlling peripheral devices such as disk drives and printers.

Most of the time, several different computer programs run simultaneously, and they all need to access your computer's central processing unit (CPU), memory, and storage. The operating system coordinates all of this to ensure each program gets its needs.

 

The user interfaces with the System & Application software in the image above. The System & Application software interfaces with the Operating System. The Operating system interfaces with the Hardware. Each interface is a two-way transaction, with each sending and receiving data.

 

Types of Computer

We can categorize computer systems based on their internal structure, features, applicability, and capability.

  • A Mainframe computer is a high-capacity computer. Most organizations where many people use the computer simultaneously use this type of computer.
  • A Supercomputer is the fastest computer performing trillions of computations per second.
  • A Workstation computer is also a high-end computer designed for complex computations.
  • A Personal computer is a low-capacity computer designed for single users.
  • A Laptop (Notebook) is also a low-capacity computer for single users, but unlike a personal computer, we can carry it easily anywhere.
  • A Tablet and Smartphone is an example of how we can keep a computer in our pocket.  

 

Popular Operating Systems

There are many operating systems, but the followings are the most popular.

  • Microsoft Windows is one of the popular operating system types and is preloaded on most new PC hardware.
  • Apple macOS is used to run Apple and Macintosh computers. 
  • Google’s Android OS, which companies including Google use to run its Android mobile smartphones and tablets, is based on Linux distribution and other open-source software. 
  • Apple iOS is another mobile operating system used exclusively for iPhones.
  • Linux Operating System is a family of open-source systems.

 

OS dominance by sector

  • Desktop/laptops: Windows > macOS > Linux
  • Server: no reliable source, probably Linux
  • Mobile: Android > iOS

 

Why do we learn system programming on Linux?

Most big companies use Linux, including Amazon, Dell, Facebook, Google, IBM, Microsoft, NASA, Oracle, and Samsung. There are plenty of reasons the companies use Linux. Here are some of them.

  • Many IT infrastructures, including routers and servers, are Linux-based, which powers the internet.
  • Linux is open-source software that helps you to learn how the operating system works and gives you a way to customize the operating system.
  • Linux is a great operating system for learning and managing networking and security.
  • Linux provides many open-source tools, such as editors, compilers, debuggers, IDEs, and interpreters; you need these tools to build a program.

 

Hypervisor

You might need to run multiple operating systems on a single machine. A hypervisor is a small software layer that enables multiple instances of operating systems to run alongside each other, sharing the same physical computing resources. This process is called virtualization, and the operating system instances are called virtual machines (VMs)—software emulations of physical computers.

The hypervisor, also known as a virtual machine monitor (VMM), such as VirtualBox manages these VMs as they run alongside each other. It separates VMs from each other logically, assigning each slice of the underlying computing power, memory, and storage. This prevents the VMs from interfering with each other; so if, for example, one OS suffers a crash or a security compromise, the others survive.

 

                                                                                                                                   

 

There are two broad categories of hypervisors: Type 1 and Type 2.

 

Type 1 hypervisor

A Type 1 hypervisor runs directly on the underlying computer’s physical hardware, interacting directly with its CPU, memory, and physical storage. A Type 1 hypervisor takes the place of the host operating system. Type 1 hypervisors are highly efficient because they directly access physical hardware. This direct access also increases their security because there is nothing between them and the CPU that an attacker could compromise. 

Examples of type 1 hypervisors 

  • VMware ESXi 
  • Xen

Type 2 hypervisor

A Type 2 hypervisor doesn’t run directly on the underlying hardware. Instead, it runs as an application in an OS. Type 2 hypervisors rarely show up in server-based environments. Instead, they’re suitable for individual PC users needing to run multiple operating systems. Examples include engineers, security professionals analyzing malware, and business users that need access to applications only available on other software platforms.

Examples of type 2 hypervisors 

  • VMware Workstation (Fusion)
  • QEMU
  • VirtualBox
  • Parallels Desktop for Mac
  • UTM

 

Benefits of Virtualization

  • Reduced expenses: A single physical server transforms into many virtual machines. These virtual machines can have different operating systems and run different applications while still all being hosted on a single physical server.
  • Resiliency: A virtualized server environment is not bound to hardware like a traditional environment. You can easily back up, copy, and clone VMs to different physical hardware.
  • High availability: Virtualization provides a highly reliable system with no single point of failure in hardware or software.
  • Increase efficiency: With less physical hardware, the IT department spends less time maintaining physical machines.
  • Environmentally friendly IT: Reducing hardware requirements also reduces power consumption, ultimately minimizing our carbon footprint.

 

References

  • https://www.uow.edu.au/student/learning-co-op/technology-and-software/operating-systems/
  • https://www.tutorialspoint.com/basics_of_computer_science/basics_of_computer_science_types.htm
  • https://www.makeuseof.com/practical-reasons-learn-linux/
  • https://www.ibm.com/topics/hypervisors

documents.title: Lab Setup (VM and Ubuntu)
documents.content:
Lab Setup: VM/Ubuntu

What You Will Need:

  1. VMware (For the free version, you will have to register with Broadcom) 

    • For Windows: Download VMware Workstation

    • For macOS: Download VMware Fusion Player 

    • Reference Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kTO810vbF_E

  2. Ubuntu

    • For Windows or x86-based machines: Download Ubuntu 22.04.3

    • For newer MacBooks (M1/M2/M3): Use the pre-made VMware image:Download VMware Image

 

Read FAQs on VM and Ubuntu

Steps for Windows/x86-Based Machines:

  1. Install and run VMware Workstation Player.

  2. Click on Create a New Virtual Machine.

  3. In the installer disk image, select the downloaded Ubuntu 22.04 ISO file.

  4. Create a username and password during setup. Do not forget this password.

  5. Select the virtual disk size and type. Customize as preferred but keep the size at least 35 GB.

  6. Customize hardware settings:

    • Set memory (RAM) to at least 4 GB.

  7. Finish the setup and start your virtual machine.

  8. Follow the instructions to install Ubuntu and adjust settings as preferred.

  9. After installation, the system will reboot.

    • If the screen shows "Try or Install Ubuntu" again, remove the Ubuntu ISO file from the virtual machine settings and reboot.

  10. Log in and run the following commands to install required packages:

    sudo apt-get install build-essential
sudo apt-get install libssl-dev

  11. Recommendation: Create SSH keys for your GitHub account for use in the labs.

 

Reference Video:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NhlhJFKmzpk

 

Steps for ARM64-Based Machines (Apple's M1/M2/M3):

  1. Install and run VMware Fusion.

  2. Unzip the provided VMware image.

  3. Double-click the image file to open it in VMware Fusion.

  4. Select "I Copied It" when prompted. The virtual machine should start.

  5. Use the following credentials to log in:

    • Username: cmpsc311

    • Password: cmpsc311

  6. Recommendation: Create SSH keys for your GitHub account for use in the labs.

Your setup is now complete. If you have any questions or encounter issues, please start by searching for similar issues on Campuswire. If no relevant posts exist, feel free to create a new post on Campuswire. If the issue persists, please contact a TA via email or visit their office hours for additional support.

documents.title: Notes: Unix OS
documents.content:
History of Unix

(Source: Wikipedia)

In the late 1960s, Bell Labs was involved in a project with MIT and General Electric to develop a time-sharing system, called Multiplexed Information and Computing Service (Multics), allowing multiple users to access a mainframe simultaneously. Dissatisfied with the project's progress, Bell Labs management ultimately withdrew.

Ken Thompson, a programmer in the Labs' computing research department, had worked on Multics. He decided to write his own operating system. While he still had access to the Multics environment, he wrote simulations for the new file and paging system on it. He also programmed a game called Space Travel, but it needed a more efficient and less expensive machine to run on, and eventually, he found a little-used Digital Equipment Corporation PDP-7 at Bell Labs. On the PDP-7, in 1969, a team of Bell Labs researchers led by Thompson and Ritchie, including Rudd Canaday, implemented a hierarchical file system, the concepts of computer processes and device files, a command-line interpreter, and some small utility programs, modeled on the corresponding features in Multics, but simplified. The resulting system, much smaller and simpler than Multics, was to become Unix. In about a month, in August 1969, Thompson had implemented a self-hosting operating system with an assembler, editor, and shell, using a GECOS machine for bootstrapping.

Douglas McIlroy then ported TMG compiler-compiler to PDP-7 assembly, creating the first high-level language running on Unix. Thompson used this tool to develop the first version of his B programming language.

 

Main Attributes of Unix

Multi-user: UNIX is a multi-user operating system: a program suite that runs a computer and allows an interface to the hardware and software. It allows many users to share a powerful machine and all the available resources, each user running their own processes simultaneously.

Multi-tasking: This proper multi-tasking aspect of UNIX allows far greater flexibility than is possible with other operating systems; even more, recent multi-tasking versions of popular PC operating systems.  The advantages of a truly flexible multi-tasking operating system has been demonstrated with the popularity of UNIX in the scientific, engineering and financial communities, along with the rise of Linux and OS-X.

Portability: It is the ability of a piece of software to move easily from one hardware platform to another. Unix was the first portable operating system, reimplemented in C to enable it to move from early Digital Equipment Corp. minicomputers to later, more advanced products. 

 

Unix Variants

(Source: Wikipedia)

 

 

 

Linux Origin

A Finnish software engineer Linus Torvalds created the computer operating system called Linux in the early 1990s. While a student at the University of Helsinki, Torvalds started developing Linux to create a system similar to MINIX, a UNIX operating system. In 1991 he released version 0.02; Version 1.0 of the Linux kernel, the operating system's core, was released in 1994. At about the same time, American software developer Richard Stallman and the FSF (Free Software Foundation) tried creating an open-source UNIX-like operating system called GNU. In contrast to Torvalds, Stallman, and the FSF, they started by creating utilities such as gcc, gdb, bash, and emacs for the operating system first. These utilities were then added to the Linux kernel to create a complete system called GNU/Linux, or, less precisely, just Linux.

 

Linux, an Operating System, or a Kernel

Linux, in its nature, is not an operating system; it’s a Kernel. The Kernel is part of the operating system – And the most crucial. For it to be an OS, it is supplied with GNU software and other additions giving us GNU/Linux.

The latter is then installed on a computer as a distribution such as Ubuntu, elementary OS, Fedora, OpenSUSE, etc. However, because there are Linux distributions paired with more software other than GNU, some people feel we cannot generalize all ‘Linux-Kerneled‘ operating systems as GNU/Linux.

 

Linux can be viewed as software layers

OS Kernel is the central component of an operating system that manages the operations of a computer and hardware. It handles operations of memory and CPU time. It is a core component of an operating system. Kernel acts as a bridge between applications and data processing performed at the hardware level using inter-process communication and system calls. 

A system Call is a mechanism that provides the interface between a process and the operating system. It is a programmatic method in which a computer program requests a service from the kernel of the OS. System call offers the operating system's services to the user programs via API (Application Programming Interface). System calls are the only entry points for the kernel system.

 

 

System libraries are special functions or programs using which application programs or system utilities access Kernel's features. These libraries implement most of the operating system's functionalities and do not require the kernel module's code access rights.

Programming Language Libraries extend system libraries. The Linux kernel is written mainly in C, with the rest in assembly language. The standard system libraries for input/output, networking, string processing, mathematics, security, data encoding, and so on are likewise written mainly in C. Writing a library in C is, therefore, writing in Linux's native language. 

System Utilities application-independent tools. They are only a well-defined set of commands usable by portable shell scripts and specified by POSIX.

Command interpreter, Command shell are user interface (in terminal program)

Application libraries are application-specific tools.

Applications are complete programs for ordinary users. Some applications have their own command shells and programming-language facilities (e.g., Perl, Python, …)

 

Linux Distribution

To learn about the popular Linux distributions, please check the link DistroWatch.com: Put the fun back into computing. Use Linux, BSD.

 

Open-Source Software

Open-source software is software with source code that anyone can inspect, modify, and enhance.

"Source code" is the part of software that most computer users don't ever see; it's the code computer programmers can manipulate to change how a piece of software—a "program" or "application"—works. Programmers who have access to a computer program's source code can improve that program by adding features to it or fixing parts that don't always work correctly.

 

As the English adjective free does not distinguish between "for free" and "liberty", the phrases "free as in freedom of speech" (libre, free software) and "free as in free beer" (gratis, freeware) were adopted. Many in the free software movement feel strongly about the freedom to use the software, make modifications, etc., whether or not this freely usable software is to be exchanged for money. Therefore, this distinction became important.

"Free software" means software that respects users' freedom and community. Roughly, it means that the users have the freedom to run, copy, distribute, study, change and improve the software. Thus, "free software" is a matter of liberty, not price. To understand the concept, you should think of "free" as in "free speech," not as in "free beer". We sometimes call it "libre software," borrowing the French or Spanish word for "free" as in freedom, to show we do not mean the software is gratis"

-- The Free Software Foundation

 

Operating System

An operating system is the most critical software that runs on a computer. It manages the computer's memory, processes, and all of its software and hardware. It also allows you to communicate with the computer without knowing how to speak the computer's language. Without an operating system, a computer is useless.

 

Operating System is a trusted system.

Software is trusted software if we know that the code has been rigorously developed and analyzed, giving us reason to trust that the code does what it is expected to do and nothing more.

An operating system that manages data to make sure that it cannot be altered, moved, or viewed except by entities having appropriate and authorized access rights.

An operating system in which there exists a level of confidence (based on rigorous analysis and testing) that the security principals and mechanisms (e.g., separation, isolation, least privilege, discretionary and non-discretionary access control, trusted path, authentication, and security policy enforcement) are correctly implemented and operate as intended even in the presence of malicious activity.

 

What is Abstraction in Operating Systems?

Abstraction means hiding the operational complexity or technical details of the system. The operating system provides a level of abstraction or a layer of abstraction with the help of OSAL. OSAL stands for Operating System Abstraction Layer, a set of application programming interfaces (APIs) that a developer can use to quickly develop an application without considering the type of operating system, hardware, and background complexity of the operating system.

 

Unix is an Abstraction Provider

Unix has several modules those your program can call using system calls. Unix provides a powerful POSIX API.

POSIX (Portable Operating System Interface) is a set of standard operating system interfaces based on the Unix operating system.It defines a standard interface and environment that can be used by an operating system (OS) to provide access to POSIX-compliant applications.

 

 

A few system calls:

file system: open( ), read( ), write( ), close( )
network stack: connect( ), listen( ), read( ), write ( )
virtual memory: brk( ), shm_open( )
process management: fork( ), wait( ), nice( )

You can find the common and well-known system calls from UNIX System Calls (miami.edu)

documents.title: Sample Unix Commands
documents.content:
You should know the following shell concepts·     

 

Hierarchical file system

Directory tree

    • Root directory
    • Home directory   
    • Standard directory
      • /etc: configuration files
      • /dev: device files
      • /home: user home directories
      • /lib: shared library files used by core systems programs
      • /sbin: system binaries for vital system tasks
      • /usr: programs and support files for users
      • /var: system log files

 

Absolute path:

Starts with the root directory, that is "/", and specifies a complete path for a file or a directory, e.g. /usr/bin/firefox

Relative path:

Specifies the path for a file relative to the current directory; e.g., if the current directory is /usr, then ./bin/firefox is a relative path for the firefox binary

 

Types of shell commands

    • binary files: separate programs executed by the shell
    • shell builtins: commands interpreted by the shell; the functionality for these commands is implemented in the shell program itself
    • aliases: shortcuts defined by users to avoid typing long commands or command sequences     

 

Shell Variables

Variables that a user can set to control the shell's behavior

    • PATH: when a user types a command, the shell looks for the binary in the list of directories present in the PATH variable.    

 

Input/Output redirection   

Every program executed in the shell has three streams associated with it.

    • standard input: where the program reads the input from; attached to the keyboard by default
    • standard output: where the program writes its output, attached to the screen by default
    • standard error: where the program writes its errors; attached to screen by default     

 

shell allows us to redirect these streams from their defaults   

    • use > to redirect standard output to a file:  

            Example: ls -l /usr/bin >ls-output.txt

    • use >> to append standard output to a file; using >> will append to a file, whereas using > will wipe the output of the file first before writing to it; thus, after the following commands, the file ls-output.txt will have twice the contents of the /usr/bin directory:
      • ls -l /usr/bin >ls-output.txt
      • ls -l /usr/bin >>ls-output.txt-  
    • use 2> to redirect standard error to a file:

            Example: ls -l /nonexistentfile 2>ls-error.txt-  

    • use < to read input from a file instead of keyboard:

            Example: cat < /etc/passwd·    

 

shell allows us to send the output of one program to the input of another program using pipe (|). The following command sequence sends the output of ls -l /usr/bin" command to the input of "less" command for easier viewing:

             Example: ls -l /usr/bin | less     

 

shell allows us to form powerful pipelines to perform arbitrarily complex tasks. See the lecture for an example.

 

Other Commands


You should know the following shell commands; use tldr command to find out the most frequently used forms of these commands:

  • man <command> : Provides details of the command 
  • pwd : Print the pathname of the current directory 
  • ls : List the files and subdirectories in a directory
  • cd  <directory> : Change directories
  • cp <file> <file2> : Copy the contents of file into file2
  • history : List history of all commands issued at system prompt
  • mv <file> <file2> : Copy file to file2
  • rm <file> : Remove or delete files
  • mkdir <dir> : Make a directory
  • rmdir <dir> : Remove a directory
  • type :  Display information about command type.
  • alias : Create an alias, aliases allow a string to be substituted for a word when it is used as the first word of a simple command.
  • echo : display a line of text
  • cat <files> : Print contents of file in the command window
  • ls -a : List all the files in a directory including dot files

 

An example demo of running several commands: Try to run these commands on your terminal and observe the changes

neo@ubuntu:~$ pwd
  /home/neo
  neo@ubuntu:~$ ls
  demo     Documents  Music   Templates   Videos
  Desktop  Downloads  Public  typescript
  neo@ubuntu:~$ cd /
  neo@ubuntu:/$ ls
  bin    dev   lib    libx32      mnt   root  snap      sys  var
  boot   etc   lib32  lost+found  opt   run   srv       tmp
  cdrom  home  lib64  media       proc  sbin  swapfile  usr
  neo@ubuntu:/$ cd
  neo@ubuntu:~$ ls -a
  .              .config    .gitconfig  Public                     typescript
  ..             demo       .gnupg      .ssh                       Videos
  .bash_history  Desktop    .local      .sudo_as_admin_successful
  .bash_logout   Documents  .mozilla    Templates
  .bashrc        Downloads  Music       .thunderbird
  .cache         .emacs.d   .profile    .tldr
  neo@ubuntu:~$ cd .
  neo@ubuntu:~$ pwd
  /home/neo
  neo@ubuntu:~$ cd ..
  neo@ubuntu:/home$ pwd
  /home
  neo@ubuntu:/home$ cd ..
  neo@ubuntu:/$ pwd
  /
  neo@ubuntu:/$ cd
  neo@ubuntu:~$ ls
  demo     Documents  Music   Templates   Videos
  Desktop  Downloads  Public  typescript
  neo@ubuntu:~$ file demo
  demo: directory
  neo@ubuntu:~$ cd demo
  neo@ubuntu:~/demo$ ls
  demo.c
  neo@ubuntu:~/demo$ file demo.c
  demo.c: C source, ASCII text
  neo@ubuntu:~/demo$ cat demo.c
  #include <stdio.h>

  int main() {
    printf("welcome to git demo!\n");
    printf("Nice to meet you!");
  }
  neo@ubuntu:~/demo$ cd
  neo@ubuntu:~$ alias
  alias alert='notify-send --urgency=low -i "$([ $? = 0 ] && echo terminal || echo error)" "$(history|tail -n1|sed -e '\''s/^\s*[0-9]\+\s*//;s/[;&|]\s*alert$//'\'')"'
  alias egrep='egrep --color=auto'
  alias fgrep='fgrep --color=auto'
  alias grep='grep --color=auto'
  alias l='ls -CF'
  alias la='ls -A'
  alias ll='ls -alF'
  alias ls='ls --color=auto'
  neo@ubuntu:~$ alias deepdir='mkdir a; cd a; mkdir b; cd b; mkdir c; cd c'
  neo@ubuntu:~$ alias
  alias alert='notify-send --urgency=low -i "$([ $? = 0 ] && echo terminal || echo error)" "$(history|tail -n1|sed -e '\''s/^\s*[0-9]\+\s*//;s/[;&|]\s*alert$//'\'')"'
  alias deepdir='mkdir a; cd a; mkdir b; cd b; mkdir c; cd c'
  alias egrep='egrep --color=auto'
  alias fgrep='fgrep --color=auto'
  alias grep='grep --color=auto'
  alias l='ls -CF'
  alias la='ls -A'
  alias ll='ls -alF'
  alias ls='ls --color=auto'
  neo@ubuntu:~$ deepdir
  neo@ubuntu:~/a/b/c$ cd
  neo@ubuntu:~$ deepdir
  mkdir: cannot create directory ‘a’: File exists
  mkdir: cannot create directory ‘b’: File exists
  mkdir: cannot create directory ‘c’: File exists
  neo@ubuntu:~/a/b/c$ cd
  neo@ubuntu:~$ rmdir a
  rmdir: failed to remove 'a': Directory not empty
  neo@ubuntu:~$ rm -rf a
  neo@ubuntu:~$ type deepdir
  deepdir is aliased to `mkdir a; cd a; mkdir b; cd b; mkdir c; cd c'
  neo@ubuntu:~$ unalias deepdir
  neo@ubuntu:~$ type deepdir
  bash: type: deepdir: not found
  neo@ubuntu:~$ ls
  demo     Documents  Music   Templates   Videos
  Desktop  Downloads  Public  typescript
  neo@ubuntu:~$ rmdir Videos
  neo@ubuntu:~$ mkdir Videos
  neo@ubuntu:~$ ls
  demo     Documents  Music   Templates   Videos
  Desktop  Downloads  Public  typescript
  neo@ubuntu:~$ cp /etc/passwd x
  neo@ubuntu:~$ file x
  x: ASCII text
  neo@ubuntu:~$ cp /etc/passwd Documents/
  neo@ubuntu:~$ ls Documents/
  passwd
  neo@ubuntu:~$ cp /etc/passwd Documents/mypasswd
  neo@ubuntu:~$ ls -l Documents/
  total 8
  -rw-r--r-- 1 neo neo 2744 Feb  2 07:50 mypasswd
  -rw-r--r-- 1 neo neo 2744 Feb  2 07:49 passwd
  neo@ubuntu:~$ mv Documents Templates/
  neo@ubuntu:~$ ls
  demo  Desktop  Downloads  Music  Public  Templates  typescript  Videos  x
  neo@ubuntu:~$ ls Templates/
  Documents
  neo@ubuntu:~$ ls Templates/Documents/
  mypasswd  passwd
  neo@ubuntu:~$ exit
