documents.title: Getting started with your GitHub account
documents.content:
Git

Git is a version control system for tracking changes in computer files and coordinating work on these files among multiple users. It is primarily used for source code management in software development, but it can be used to keep track of changes in any set of files. As a distributed revision control system, it is aimed at speed, data integrity, and support for distributed, non-linear work-flows

 

Signing Up

To use GitHub, you first need to create an account. To do that, go to https://github.com, click on the Sign-Up button, and proceed to the registration form. Choose a proper username and remember your login credentials.

 

NOTE: If you already have a Github account, you can use that. However, you cannot change your Github username throughout the semester.

 

Installing git on Computer

If you don't have git on your local machine, it will show an error message "unknown command" when you try the git command on your terminal. To install git on your local machine, follow the command:

$ sudo apt install git

 

Configuring the git

To configure your git client in the terminal (either your VM or your Linux/WSL machine), set your name and email using the following commands:

$ git config --global user.name “Your Name”

$ git config --global user.email  ”Your Email”

 

Adding SSH key

To authenticate your Git client while working with your repository, add your public SSH key to your GitHub account. To do so, follow the below steps:

i. Create an SSH key by running this command on your terminal:

$ ssh−keygen −t rsa −b 4096 −C ”your@email.com”

ii. Press Enter on any question to select the default answer.

iii. Your public SSH key will be created in $ ∼/.ssh/id rsa.pub. Copy its content. To copy, you can run the $cat ∼/.ssh/id rsa.pub command and copy from terminal

iv. Go to your GitHub account, click on your profile in the top right, and click on settings.

v. In the left-side menu, select SSH and GPG keys.

vi. Click on New SSH Key, set a proper name for the key (e.g., 311VMKey), paste your public Key, and click on Add SSH Key.

 

Accepting the assignment

Once the assignment is released, you will receive an invitation link to join a corresponding private repository. By accepting the invitation,  you will have access to your private repository containing the starter files we provide. Your private repository is accessible at https://github.com/PSU-CMPSC311-SAHA/<assignmentName>-<YourGithubUsername>

 

Initialize a local directory as a Git repository.

You want to clone the assignment from the GitHub repository to your local machine. Thus, you can update them on the local machine and then push them to the GitHub account. Therefore, create a local directory and initialize the directory as a git repository using the following command:

$ mkdir assignments

$ cd assignments

$ git init

 

Cloning The Assignment Repository

To clone your assignment repository to your local machine, run the following command on your terminal:

$ git clone https://github.com/PSU-CMPSC311-SAHA/<assignmentName>-<githubUserName>.git

This command will download the repository to your current working directory.

 

Pushing Changes

Whenever you change an existing file or add a new file to your local repository, you must commit the changes and then push them to the remote repository on gitHub.com.

 

Add files that have been created or have been changed:

$   git   add  <list of filenames separated by space>

 

Commit the changes with a message about that change:

$   git commit -m ” your   proper  commit   message ”

 

Finally, push the changes to the remote repository:

$  git push origin main

 

Other Commands

  • git init: initialize an existing directory as a Git repository
  • git clone [url]: retrieve an entire repository from a hosted location via URL
  • git status: show modified files in the working directory, stage for your next commit
  • git add [file]: add a file as it looks now to your next commit (stage)
  • git reset [file]: unstage a file while retaining the changes in the working directory
  • git diff: diff of what is changed but not staged
  • git diff –staged: diff of what is staged but not yet committed
  • git commit -m “[descriptive message]”: commit your staged content as a new commit snapshot
  • git branch: list your branches. a * will appear next to the currently active branch
  • git branch [branch-name]: create a new branch at the current commit
  • git checkout: switch to another branch and check it out in your working directory
  • git merge [branch]: merge the specified branch’s history into the current one
  • git log: show all commits in the current branch’s history
  • git log branchB..branchA : show the commits on branchA that are not on branchB
  • git log --follow [file]: show the commits that changed file, even across renames
  • git diff branchB...branchA : show the diff of what is in branchA that is not in branchB
  • git show [SHA]: show any object in Git in human-readable format
  • git rm [file]: delete the file from the project and stage the removal for commit
  • git mv [existing-path] [new-path]: change an existing file path and stage the move
  • git log --stat -M: show all commit logs with an indication of any paths that moved
  • git remote add [alias] [url]: add a git URL as an alias
  • git fetch [alias]: fetch down all the branches from that Git remote
  • git merge [alias]/[branch]: merge a remote branch into your current branch to bring it up to date
  • git push [alias] [branch]: Transmit local branch commits to the remote repository branch
  • git pull: fetch and merge any commits from the tracking remote branch
  • git rebase [branch]: apply any commits of the current branch ahead of the specified one
  • git reset --hard [commit]: clear staging area, rewrite working tree from the specified commit
  • git stash: Save modified and staged changes
  • git stash list: list stack-order of stashed file changes
  • git stash pop: write working from the top of the stash stack
  • git stash drop: discard the changes from the top of the stash stack

 

Important Note

Do not push your assignment in one shot! You must commit and push any changes you make to files to the git repository with a proper message.

documents.title: Exercises: Introduction to C Programming
documents.content:
As part of this exercise we are providing few sample c programs.

1. Write a program to calculate the sum of two numbers entered by the user.

#include <stdio.h>

int main() {
    int num1, num2, sum;
  
    printf("Enter the first number: ");
    scanf("%d", &num1);
    
    printf("Enter the second number: ");
    scanf("%d", &num2);
    
    sum = num1 + num2;
    
    printf("The sum is: %d", sum);
    
    return 0;
}

2. Write a program to check if a number entered by the user is positive, negative, or zero.

#include <stdio.h>

int main() {
    int num;
    
    printf("Enter a number: ");
    scanf("%d", &num);
    
    if (num > 0) {
        printf("Positive");
    } else if (num < 0) {
        printf("Negative");
    } else {
        printf("Zero");
    }
    
    return 0;
}

3. Write a program to find the largest among three numbers entered by the user.

#include <stdio.h>

int main() {
    int num1, num2, num3, largest;
    
    printf("Enter the first number: ");
    scanf("%d", &num1);
    
    printf("Enter the second number: ");
    scanf("%d", &num2);
    
    printf("Enter the third number: ");
    scanf("%d", &num3);
    
    largest = num1;
    
    if (num2 > largest) {
        largest = num2;
    }
    
    if (num3 > largest) {
        largest = num3;
    }
    
    printf("The largest number is: %d", largest);
    
    return 0;
}

4. Write a program to print the Fibonacci series up to a given number n.

#include <stdio.h>

int main() {
    int n, first = 0, second = 1, next;
    
    printf("Enter the value of n: ");
    scanf("%d", &n);
    
    printf("Fibonacci series up to %d: ", n);
    
    for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        printf("%d ", first);
        next = first + second;
        first = second;
        second = next;
    }
    
    return 0;
}

5. Write a program to check if a number entered by the user is a prime number.

#include <stdio.h>

int main() {
    int num, isPrime = 1;
    
    printf("Enter a number: ");
    scanf("%d", &num);
    
    for (int i = 2; i <= num / 2; i++) {
        if (num % i == 0) {
            isPrime = 0;
            break;
        }
    }
    
    if (isPrime == 1) {
        printf("Prime");
    } else {
        printf("Not Prime");
    }
    
    return 0;
}

6. Write a program to calculate the factorial of a given number n.

#include <stdio.h>

int main() {
    int n, factorial = 1;
    
    printf("Enter a number: ");
    scanf("%d", &n);
    
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        factorial *= i;
    }
    
    printf("Factorial of %d is %d", n, factorial);
    
    return 0:
}

7. Write a program to check if a given number num is a palindrome or not.

#include <stdio.h>

int main() {
    int num, reversedNum = 0, originalNum, remainder;
    
    printf("Enter a number: ");
    scanf("%d", &num);
    
    originalNum = num;
    
    while (num != 0) {
        remainder = num % 10;
        reversedNum = reversedNum * 10 + remainder;
        num /= 10;
    }
    
    if (originalNum == reversedNum) {
        printf("Palindrome");
    } else {
        printf("Not Palindrome");
    }
    
    return 0;
}

8. Write a program to calculate the sum of natural numbers up to a given number n.

#include <stdio.h>

int main() {
    int n, sum = 0;
    
    printf("Enter a number: ");
    scanf("%d", &n);
    
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        sum += i;
    }
    
    printf("The sum of natural numbers up to %d is %d", n, sum);
    
    return 0;
}

9. Write a program to find the factorial of a number using recursion.

#include <stdio.h>

int factorial(int n) {
    if (n == 0) {
        return 1;
    } else {
        return n * factorial(n - 1);
    }
}

int main() {
    int num;
    
    printf("Enter a number: ");
    scanf("%d", &num);
    
    printf("Factorial of %d is %d", num, factorial(num));
    
    return 0;
}

10. Write a program to check if a string entered by the user is a palindrome.

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

int main() {
    char str[100];
    int i, j, isPalindrome = 1;
    
    printf("Enter a string: ");
    gets(str);
    
    j = strlen(str) - 1;
    
    for (i = 0; i < j; i++, j--) {
        if (str[i] != str[j]) {
            isPalindrome = 0;
            break;
        }
    }
    
    if (isPalindrome == 1) {
        printf("Palindrome");
    } else {
        printf("Not Palindrome");
    }
    
    return 0;
}

documents.title: Emacs Cheatsheet
documents.content:
- C-x C-f open or create a file
- C-x C-c exit emacs
- C-x C-s save current file
- C-f move forward one character
- C-b move backward back character
- C-n move to the next line
- C-p move to the previous line
- M-f move forward one word
- M-b move backward one word
- C-e move to the end of the line
- C-a move to the beginning of the line
- M-< move to the beginning of the file
- M-> move to the end of the file
- Backspace - delete character before the cursor
- C-d delete character after the cursor
- M-Backspace - deletes word before the cursor
- M-d - deletes word after the cursor
- C-k - deletes until the end of line
- C-y - paste the deleted text
- C-SPC - place a mark
- C-w - delete text between mark and cursor
- C-y - paste killed text
- M-y - scroll through the kill ring
- C-/ - undo
- C-v - scroll a page forward
- M-v - scroll a page backward
- C-x 3 - divide screen into two windows vertically
- C-x 2 - divide screen into two windows horizontally
- C-x 1 - kill all windows other than the current one
- C-x 0 - kill current window
- C-x o - jump between windows
- C-g quit current command that asks for input in the minibuffer

documents.title: Exercises: Arrays and Pointers
documents.content:
1. Write a program to find the largest and smallest elements in an array. Constraints: The array must contain at least one element. 
    #include <stdio.h>

    void findMinMax(int arr[], int size) {
        int i;
        int min = arr[0];
        int max = arr[0];
        
        for (i = 1; i < size; i++) {
            if (arr[i] < min) {
                min = arr[i];
            }
            if (arr[i] > max) {
                max = arr[i];
            }
        }
        
        printf("Minimum element: %d\n", min);
        printf("Maximum element: %d\n", max);
    }

    int main() {
        int arr[] = {10, 5, 8, 2, 7};
        int size = sizeof(arr) / sizeof(arr[0]);
        
        findMinMax(arr, size);
        
        return 0;
    }
  1. Write a program to find the second largest element in an array. Constraints: The array must contain at least two unique elements. 
    #include <stdio.h>

    int findSecondLargest(int arr[], int size) {
        int i;
        int largest = arr[0];
        int secondLargest = arr[0];
        
        for (i = 1; i < size; i++) {
            if (arr[i] > largest) {
                secondLargest = largest;
                largest = arr[i];
            } else if (arr[i] > secondLargest && arr[i] < largest) {
                secondLargest = arr[i];
            }
        }
        
        return secondLargest;
    }

    int main() {
        int arr[] = {10, 5, 8, 2, 7};
        int size = sizeof(arr) / sizeof(arr[0]);
        
        int secondLargest = findSecondLargest(arr, size);
        
        printf("Second largest element: %d\n", secondLargest);
        
        return 0;
    }
  1. Write a program to rotate an array to the right by a given number of steps. Constraints: The array size should be greater than the number of steps. 
    #include <stdio.h>

    void rotateArray(int arr[], int size, int steps) {
        int i, j;
        int temp;
        
        for (i = 0; i < steps; i++) {
            temp = arr[size - 1];
            
            for (j = size - 1; j > 0; j--) {
                arr[j] = arr[j - 1];
            }
            
            arr[0] = temp;
        }
    }

    int main() {
        int arr[] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
        int size = sizeof(arr) / sizeof(arr[0]);
        int steps = 2;
        
        rotateArray(arr, size, steps);
        
        printf("Rotated array: ");
        for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {
            printf("%d ", arr[i]);
        }
        printf("\n");
        
        return 0;
    }
  1. Write a program to find the median of an array of integers. Constraints: The array size will always be odd. 
    #include <stdio.h>

    int findMedian(int arr[], int size) {
        int i, j;
        int temp;
        
        for (i = 0; i < size - 1; i++) {
            for (j = 0; j < size - i - 1; j++) {
                if (arr[j] > arr[j + 1]) {
                    temp = arr[j];
                    arr[j] = arr[j + 1];
                    arr[j + 1] = temp;
                }
            }
        }
        
        return arr[size / 2];
    }

    int main() {
        int arr[] = {3, 1, 5, 2, 4};
        int size = sizeof(arr) / sizeof(arr[0]);
        
        int median = findMedian(arr, size);
        
        printf("Median: %d\n", median);
        
        return 0;
    }

5. Write a program to merge two sorted arrays into a single sorted array. Constraints: The merged array should not contain any duplicates.

#include <stdio.h>

void mergeArrays(int arr1[], int size1, int arr2[], int size2, int merged[]) {
    int i = 0, j = 0, k = 0;
    
    while (i < size1 && j < size2) {
        if (arr1[i] < arr2[j]) {
            merged[k++] = arr1[i++];
        } else if (arr2[j] < arr1[i]) {
            merged[k++] = arr2[j++];
        } else {
            merged[k++] = arr1[i++];
            j++;
        }
    }
    
    while (i < size1) {
        merged[k++] = arr1[i++];
    }
    
    while (j < size2) {
        merged[k++] = arr2[j++];
    }
}

int main() {
    int arr1[] = {1, 3, 5, 7};
    int size1 = sizeof(arr1) / sizeof(arr1[0]);
    
    int arr2[] = {2, 4, 6};
    int size2 = sizeof(arr2) / sizeof(arr2[0]);
    
    int merged[size1 + size2];
    
    mergeArrays(arr1, size1, arr2, size2, merged);
    
    printf("Merged array: ");
    for (int i = 0; i < size1 + size2; i++) {
        printf("%d ", merged[i]);
    }
    printf("\n");
    
    return 0;
}

6. Write a program to swap the values of two variables using pointers.

#include <stdio.h>

void swap(int* a, int* b) {
    int temp = *a;
    *a = *b;
    *b = temp;
}

int main() {
    int x = 5, y = 10;
    printf("Before swap: x = %d, y = %d\n", x, y);
    
    swap(&x, &y);
    
    printf("After swap: x = %d, y = %d\n", x, y);
    
    return 0;
}

7. Write a program to reverse a string using pointers.

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

void reverseString(char* str) {
    int length = strlen(str);
    char* start = str;
    char* end = str + length - 1;
    
    while (start < end) {
        char temp = *start;
        *start = *end;
        *end = temp;
        
        start++;
        end--;
    }
}

int main() {
    char str[] = "Hello, World!";
    printf("Before reverse: %s\n", str);
    
    reverseString(str);
    
    printf("After reverse: %s\n", str);
    
    return 0;
}

8. Write a program to find the largest element in an array using pointers.

#include <stdio.h>

int findLargest(int* arr, int size) {
    int largest = *arr;
    
    for (int i = 1; i < size; i++) {
        if (*(arr + i) > largest) {
            largest = *(arr + i);
        }
    }
    
    return largest;
}

int main() {
    int arr[] = {10, 5, 8, 2, 7};
    int size = sizeof(arr) / sizeof(arr[0]);
    
    int largest = findLargest(arr, size);
    
    printf("Largest element: %d\n", largest);
    
    return 0;
}

9. Write a program to concatenate two strings using pointers.

#include <stdio.h>

void concatenateStrings(char* str1, char* str2) {
    while (*str1) {
        str1++;
    }
    
    while (*str2) {
        *str1 = *str2;
        str1++;
        str2++;
    }
    
    *str1 = '\0';
}

int main() {
    char str1[100] = "Hello";
    char str2[] = ", World!";
    printf("Before concatenation: %s\n", str1);
    
    concatenateStrings(str1, str2);
    
    printf("After concatenation: %s\n", str1);
    
    return 0;
}

10. Write a program to reverse an array using pointers.

#include <stdio.h>

void reverseArray(int* arr, int size) {
    int* start = arr;
    int* end = arr + size - 1;
    
    while (start < end) {
        int temp = *start;
        *start = *end;
        *end = temp;
        
        start++;
        end--;
    }
}

int main() {
    int arr[] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
    int size = sizeof(arr) / sizeof(arr[0]);
    
    printf("Before reverse: ");

documents.title: Exercises: Types, Struct and Union
documents.content:
1. Write a program to reverse the digits of an integer number.

#include <stdio.h>

int reverseNumber(int num) {
    int reversedNum = 0;
    
    while (num != 0) {
        reversedNum = reversedNum * 10 + num % 10;
        num /= 10;
    }
    
    return reversedNum;
}

int main() {
    int num;
    printf("Enter an integer number: ");
    scanf("%d", &num);
    
    int reversed = reverseNumber(num);
    printf("Reversed number: %d
", reversed);
    
    return 0;
}

2. Write a program to count the number of vowels and consonants in a given string.

#include <stdio.h>
#include <ctype.h>

void countVowelsAndConsonants(const char* str, int* vowels, int* consonants) {
    *vowels = 0;
    *consonants = 0;
    
    while (*str) {
        char ch = tolower(*str);
        
        if (ch >= 'a' && ch <= 'z') {
            if (ch == 'a' || ch == 'e' || ch == 'i' || ch == 'o' || ch == 'u')
                (*vowels)++;
            else
                (*consonants)++;
        }
        
        str++;
    }
}

int main() {
    char str[100];
    int vowels, consonants;
    
    printf("Enter a string: ");
    fgets(str, sizeof(str), stdin);
    
    countVowelsAndConsonants(str, &vowels, &consonants);
    
    printf("Number of vowels: %d
", vowels);
    printf("Number of consonants: %d
", consonants);
    
    return 0;
}

3. Write a program to convert a decimal number to binary.

#include <stdio.h>

void decimalToBinary(int num) {
    int binary[32];
    int index = 0;
    
    while (num > 0) {
        binary[index++] = num % 2;
        num /= 2;
    }
    
    printf("Binary representation: ");
    
    if (index == 0)
        printf("0");
    
    for (int i = index - 1; i >= 0; i--)
        printf("%d", binary[i]);
    
    printf("
");
}

int main() {
    int num;
    
    printf("Enter a decimal number: ");
    scanf("%d", &num);
    
    decimalToBinary(num);
    
    return 0;
}

4. Write a program that defines a struct called Rectangle with members length and width. The program should prompt the user to enter the length and width of a rectangle, calculate its area, and display the result.

#include <stdio.h>

struct Rectangle {
    float length;
    float width;
};

int main() {
    struct Rectangle rect;

    printf("Enter the length of the rectangle: ");
    scanf("%f", &rect.length);

    printf("Enter the width of the rectangle: ");
    scanf("%f", &rect.width);

    float area = rect.length * rect.width;
    printf("The area of the rectangle is: %.2f
", area);

    return 0;
}

5. Write a program that defines a struct called Employee with members name, age, and salary. The program should create an array of Employee objects and prompt the user to enter the details of each employee. After that, it should display the details of the employee with the highest salary.

#include <stdio.h>

struct Employee {
    char name[50];
    int age;
    float salary;
};

int main() {
    int numEmployees;

    printf("Enter the number of employees: ");
    scanf("%d", &numEmployees);

    struct Employee employees[numEmployees];

    for (int i = 0; i < numEmployees; i++) {
        printf("
Enter details of employee %d:
", i + 1);

        printf("Name: ");
        scanf("%s", employees[i].name);

        printf("Age: ");
        scanf("%d", &employees[i].age);

        printf("Salary: ");
        scanf("%f", &employees[i].salary);
    }

    int maxSalaryIndex = 0;
    for (int i = 1; i < numEmployees; i++) {
        if (employees[i].salary > employees[maxSalaryIndex].salary) {
            maxSalaryIndex = i;
        }
    }

    printf("
Employee with the highest salary:
");
    printf("Name: %s
", employees[maxSalaryIndex].name);
    printf("Age: %d
", employees[maxSalaryIndex].age);
    printf("Salary: %.2f
", employees[maxSalaryIndex].salary);

    return 0;
}

6. Write a program that defines a struct called Date with members day, month, and year. The program should prompt the user to enter two dates and calculate the number of days between them.

#include <stdio.h>

struct Date {
    int day;
    int month;
    int year;
};

int main() {
    struct Date date1, date2;

    printf("Enter the first date (day month year): ");
    scanf("%d %d %d", &date1.day, &date1.month, &date1.year);

    printf("Enter the second date (day month year): ");
    scanf("%d %d %d", &date2.day, &date2.month, &date2.year);

    // Assuming a non-leap year
    int daysInMonth[] = {31, 28, 31, 30, 31, 30, 31, 31, 30, 31, 30, 31};

    int totalDays1 = date1.day;
    for (int i = 0; i < date1.month - 1; i++) {
        totalDays1 += daysInMonth[i];
    }
    totalDays1 += (date1.year * 365);

    int totalDays2 = date2.day;
    for (int i = 0; i < date2.month - 1; i++) {
        totalDays2 += daysInMonth[i];
    }
    totalDays2 += (date2.year * 365);

    int diffDays = totalDays2 - totalDays1;

    printf("
Number of days between the two dates: %d
", diffDays);

    return 0;
}

7. Write a program that defines a struct called Student with members name, rollNumber, and marks. The program should create an array of Student objects and prompt the user to enter the details of each student. After that, it should display the names of students who scored more than 90 marks.

#include <stdio.h>

struct Student {
    char name[50];
    int rollNumber;
    int marks;
};

int main() {
    int numStudents;

    printf("Enter the number of students: ");
    scanf("%d", &numStudents);

    struct Student students[numStudents];

    for (int i = 0; i < numStudents; i++) {
        printf("
Enter details of student %d:
", i + 1);

        printf("Name: ");
        scanf("%s", students[i].name);

        printf("Roll Number: ");
        scanf("%d", &students[i].rollNumber);

        printf("Marks: ");
        scanf("%d", &students[i].marks);
    }

    printf("
Students who scored more than 90 marks:
");
    for (int i = 0; i < numStudents; i++) {
        if (students[i].marks > 90) {
            printf("%s
", students[i].name);
        }
    }

    return 0;
}

8. Write a program that defines a union named Number which can store either an integer or a float value. The program should prompt the user to enter a number and specify its type (1 for integer, 2 for float). Based on the user's choice, the program should store the number in the appropriate member of the union and display the stored value.

#include <stdio.h>

union Number {
    int intValue;
    float floatValue;
};

int main() {
    union Number num;
    int choice;

    printf("Enter a number: ");
    scanf("%d", &choice);

    if (choice == 1) {
        printf("Enter an integer value: ");
        scanf("%d", &num.intValue);
        printf("Stored integer value: %d
", num.intValue);
    } else if (choice == 2) {
        printf("Enter a float value: ");
        scanf("%f", &num.floatValue);
        printf("Stored float value: %.2f
", num.floatValue);
    } else {
        printf("Invalid choice
");
    }

    return 0;
}

9. Write a program that defines a union named Data with three members: an integer, a float, and a character array of size 20. Prompt the user to enter a choice (1 for integer, 2 for float, 3 for string), and based on the choice, store and display the corresponding data type.

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

union Data {
    int intValue;
    float floatValue;
    char stringValue[20];
};

int main() {
    union Data data;
    int choice;

    printf("Enter a choice (1 for integer, 2 for float, 3 for string): ");
    scanf("%d", &choice);

    if (choice == 1) {
        printf("Enter an integer value: ");
        scanf("%d", &data.intValue);
        printf("Stored integer value: %d
", data.intValue);
    } else if (choice == 2) {
        printf("Enter a float value: ");
        scanf("%f", &data.floatValue);
        printf("Stored float value: %.2f
", data.floatValue);
    } else if (choice == 3) {
        printf("Enter a string value: ");
        scanf("%s", data.stringValue);
        printf("Stored string value: %s
", data.stringValue);
    } else {
        printf("Invalid choice
");
    }

    return 0;
}

10. Write a program that defines a union named Point which can store either a 2D point (x and y coordinates) or a 3D point (x, y, and z coordinates). Prompt the user to enter the type of point (2 for 2D, 3 for 3D) and based on the choice, store and display the coordinates of the point.

#include <stdio.h>

union Point {
    struct {
        int x;
        int y;
    } twoD;
    struct {
        int x;
        int y;
        int z;
    } threeD;
};

int main() {
    union Point point;
    int choice;

    printf("Enter the type of point (2 for 2D, 3 for 3D): ");
    scanf("%d", &choice);

    if (choice == 2) {
        printf("Enter x coordinate: ");
        scanf("%d", &point.twoD.x);
        printf("Enter y coordinate: ");
        scanf("%d", &point.twoD.y);
        printf("Stored 2D point: (%d, %d)
", point.twoD.x, point.twoD.y);
    } else if (choice == 3) {
        printf("Enter x coordinate: ");
        scanf("%d", &point.threeD.x);
        printf("Enter y coordinate: ");
        scanf("%d", &point.threeD.y);
        printf("Enter z coordinate: ");
        scanf("%d", &point.threeD.z);
        printf("Stored 3D point: (%d, %d, %d)
", point.threeD.x, point.threeD.y, point.threeD.z);
    } else {
        printf("Invalid choice
");
    }

    return 0;
}

documents.title: CMPSC 311: Intro Sys Prog - SP25 Home Page
documents.content:
This course explores the art and methods of systems programming. Practically speaking, lectures and course assignments will provide students with experience programming in C within the UNIX environment. UNIX tools will be introduced, as will the general UNIX philosophy. Fluency in the use of the command line will be encouraged and expected, as will canonical compiler tools such as GCC. We will examine the use of shell programs, compilers, build sequences, memory management, filesystems, signal processing, parallel programming, and other topics essential to computer scientists. In addition, we will introduce students to the basics of systems administration on UNIX virtual machines.

See the syllabus for more information on the course. We are using Campuswire for class discussions. Please join Campuswire using the link and access code 2607. Students are advised to join via their .psu Email ID

We are using Gradescope to grade your exams. Please join the Gradescope using the entry code 7EWBKP and your .psu Email ID

Top Hat will facilitate participation in class activities. Please join Top Hat using the following code.

Section 001: 484069

We value your input! Please share your feedback anonymously to help improve the teaching and learning experience.

documents.title: Midterm Exam Structure and Guidelines
documents.content:
Dear Students,

I hope you are all doing well. As we approach the upcoming midterms, I wanted to provide you with an outline of the exam structure to help you prepare effectively.

1st Midterm:

  • Coverage: Topics 1-7
  • Questions:

    • 1 long answer question, worth 30 marks.

2nd Midterm:

  • Total Marks: 50
  • Coverage: Topics 8-14
  • Questions:
    • 10 multiple-choice questions (MCQs), each worth 2 marks.
    • 1 long answer question, worth 30 marks.

Make sure to review the material for each topic thoroughly, as the MCQs will test your understanding of key concepts, while the long answer questions will require deeper analysis and explanation.

Maksym Lupei

documents.title: Module 1 Lab 1 Submission (Graded)
documents.content: Remember that because the continents have moved and some PETM sites are in the current place of continents and don’t have temperatures under them when you turn the modern map on, you will need to interpolate the temperatures from equivalent latitudes. Note “polar” or “high latitudes” are north or south of 50 or 60 degrees N or S of the equator.

documents.title: Midterm study guide
documents.content:
Students:

Midterm 1 opens next week.  There are 70 questions in 90 minutes. There is a practice test that will open next week. The midterm is closed book.

Here is the study guide for it:

  1. Climate proxies, tree rings, stomatal density, leaves, ice cores and others (several questions)
  2. How oxygen isotopes work
  3. Instrumental records
  4. Lat glacial maximum and conditions
  5. Orbital cycles
  6. PETM causes and effects (several questions)
  7. Global mean temperature and trends
  8. Recent temperature history
  9. Changes in warming at different latitudes
  10. Impact of volcanism on climate
  11. ENSO (several questions)
  12. SSTs versus changes in air temperatures
  13. Future changes in precipitation
  14. Areas in US prone to drought
  15. Impact of glacial melting on global sea level (several questions)
  16. Recent changes in ice volume
  17. Areas in US prone to Hurricanes
  18. Future of hurricanes with global warming
  19. Polar vortex
  20. Definition of heat, temperature, black body, Stefan Boltzman, radiation, emissivity (several questions)
  21. Albedo (several questions)
  22. Solar constant
  23. Distribution of insolation
  24. Sunspots
  25. Heat capacity
  26. Greenhouse effect (several questions)
  27. Positive and negative feedback
  28. GCMs (several questions)
  29. Emission scenarios (several questions)
  30. Stream flow
  31. High latitude warming
  32. 2 degree threshold
  33. Paris climate agreement, clean power plan (several questions)
  34. Seawater pH, alkalinity and CO2
  35. Nutrients, upwelling, primary productivity, chlorophyll (several questions)
  36. Temperature range of seawater
  37. Deepwater sources
  38. Surface ocean circulation, thermocline, global conveyor belt
  39. ENSO and circulation
  40. Ocean futures, hypoxia, ENSO
  41. Current pCO2, its recent history and measurement (several questions)
  42. Deforestation
  43. Photosynthesis
  44. Permafrost
  45. Energy sources and CO2 emission (several questions)

Let me know if you have any questions.

Tim

Module 5 lab
documents.content:
Hi, Students:  In module 5 lab we return to STELLA to model what happens when we add CO2 added to the atmosphere and interpret what happens when we increase the rate of fossil fuel burning.  We will simulate the impact of the different emission scenarios on global temperature and evaluate how permafrost melting amplifies warming under the different emission scenarios.

There is no practice for the lab, instead most of the questions are given in the worksheet but we add a few in Canvas in addition to them.  So please make sure you are confident about the questions before you start and holler if you need any help.

Please use Chrome for the lab.

Best wishes,

Tim

Hi, Students:

Just a note on historical imagery.  If you can’t get it working the way you need to for the lab questions, it could be one of several things. 

  1. You could be zoomed too far out, so zoom in and try again
  2. You may need to close GE Pro, reopen it then reopen Historical Imagery.
  3. Sometimes doing 1 and 2 helps.

I also recommend you turn the hurricane tracks off when using historical imagery.

Hope this helps.

Tim

documents.title: Albedo
Module 3 lab
documents.content:
Hi, Students:

This week the lab closes on Wednesday night, Wednesday February 12 (the one lab that closes on Wednesday).

This week you will be learning about the climate system by using a climate model. This gives you the chance to make changes to the climate system, such as increasing the solar input, and see what the effect will be on the temperature of the earth.

Climate models are very powerful tools which we can use to understand the relationships between different forcings, however, they are also very complicated as they include a lot of physics. We don't expect you to memorize or understand all of the equations, they are there so that people who want to can dig deeper. We really just want you to get an idea of what goes into a climate model and how we can use it to better understand the climate system. 

The model you are using is called STELLA and it has a very intuitive web interface.  I highly recommend you use Chrome as your browser if at all possible.  There are detailed instructions and a practice so you get to answer the same type of questions you will see in the for credit lab.

As I said in my announcement, I recommend you get going on the lab early this week, that will help you understand material in the quiz.

This week the lab closes on Wednesday night, Wednesday February 12.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Tim

documents.title: Module 3 study guide
documents.content:
Hi, Students:

Welcome to Module 3 on Earth’s Climate System.  Just a word of warning, the presentation of materials in this module is the most detailed and scientific of any module.  The goal is not for you to learn all the equations or completely understand all the physics presented, but to demonstrate that climate is complex, controlled by physics and to allow you to probe deeper than the assessments require if you wish. 

Below are concepts you need to understand for the quiz.

The lab activity is designed to help your grasp so I also recommend doing the lab before the quiz if you have time.

So do not learn the equations and please holler if you need help.

Tim

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

  • Polar Vortex
  • Heat, Energy, Temperature definitions
  • Radiation-Blackbody definitions
  • Albedo
  • Solar constant
  • Distribution of insolation
  • Sunspots
  • Heat capacity of materials
  • Greenhouse effect
  • Heat transfer
  • Tipping Points

documents.title: Google Earth tips for Module 1 lab
Get going on Yellowdig for Module 1
documents.content:
Hi, Students:

You are off to a great start!  I've enjoyed reading the posts and thanks to all of those who have posted!

If you haven't posted, ts time to get going on Yellowdig.  Please make sure you have read the previous announcements as well as the instructions in Canvas.

Yellowdig is YOUR community.  It’s not a typical discussion board that you might have experienced in other classes.  It’s more of a gamified Facebook style learning community with emojis, accolades, search tools, and the ability to post videos and polls.  There’s also a leaderboard.  The goal is for you to learn a lot about current issues related to climate change, focused on Earth in 2100 and to build community with your fellow classmates.  There are weekly topics related to the weekly module.

This class is large and even though I will be reading every posted entry (sadly likely not every reply), it will not be possible for me to reply to posts. That is your job.  Find posts that interest you and comment on them. My main role is to make sure the forum is courteous and supportive.

The grading system in Yellowdig is built in.  You’ll get points for posting and replying once you pass the minimum length limits and you’ll get points when other students comment on your post.  So the best way to succeed is to post Early and comment Often!  The goal is NOT to leave working on your weekly entry till 11PM on Saturday night!  You won’t be able to get the maximum number of points for that week that way.  Post on Monday or Tuesday and you will.

One thing about Yellowdig.  I cannot get into the system to give extensions or change points awarded.  If you miss a deadline for any reason there is nothing I can do.  One thing that Yellowdig does have is a buffer of 35% meaning you can exceed the 1000 points required to get an A by 350 points, so you can make up credit lost in past weeks by excelling in the current week.  That is the only way to make up for absence or inactivity.

So I encourage you to build your community in this class.  You might make friends, you certainly will see the passion other students have for important and urgent issues facing our Earth.

Have fun with Yellowdig!

Tim

documents.title: Module 1 lab
documents.content:
Hi, Students:

Module 1 primarily concerns the ways we measure past climates. One such past climate was the Paleocene/Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM), a time about 56 million years ago when the climate warmed rapidly. Scientists believe that studying the PETM may give us insight into current warming trends. Therefore for Module 1 Lab this week you will compare estimated ocean temperature data from the PETM with modern sea surface temperatures. The lab relies on Google Earth; if you have not already, be sure to complete the Google Earth Tutorial.   

Please begin with the Practice lab (Module 1 lab 1 Submission (Practice)), it has the same type of questions you will get in the graded lab for credit.  You can get the instructions and the key Google Earth kmz files on the Instruction page.  Make sure you listen to my video on how to open files and do other important steps.   Once you have completed the practice, you may submit answers in Canvas. The practice lab has no time limit and unlimited attempts. It's an excellent way to verify whether or not you understand the concepts of the lab.

When you are ready, proceed to the Module 1 lab 1 Submission (Graded).  You will have one 90-minute attempt with no retakes so that’s why its good to do the practice as many times till you are ready. 

Let me know if you have any questions.

Best wishes,

Tim

documents.title: Yellowdig scoring
documents.content:
Hi, Students:

More on Yellowdig scoring.  You get points for your initial entry and for responses to other student’s entries. Your initial entry must be 75 words long to get credit. You earn more points for a great initial entry. Your peers are your judges and when they respond to your post because it interests or resonates with them, you get points. So you will be rewarded for doing great research and generating an excellent and thoughtful original post. Feel free to add images and videos to bring your post to life, but these are not essential. The main thing is that a quality post based on solid research will get you credit. Also, early entries will get more points because more students will get to respond to them before the deadline, so do not wait until the deadline to post your initial entry.

I will monitor the feed and award accolades and extra points for excellent entries. This will be another good way for you to see what a good entry looks like. I can also deduct points for entries that are off subject, have errors, or are impolite or offensive. Use of AI is easily detected and will result in severe penalties.

You get credit for replying to posts. Replies must be 25 words long to get credit. Please avoid single line entries like “I agree with you.” Make sure your entry has substance.

Here is a summary of the scoring:

  • Writing an Initial Post of at least 75 words (280 points) as early as possible.
  • Writing a Comment of at least 25 words (210 points) by Saturday midnight.
  • Receiving a Comment on your Post (70 points)
  • Receiving an Accolade on your Post or Comment (Points vary):
  • Receiving a Reaction on your Post or Comment (50 points

Bottom line, you need to get 1000 points a week to get full credit in Yellowdig.  You will learn how the scoring works as you post. Watch your score in Yellowdig and learn what you need to do to get 1000 points a week. Scores transfer to Canvas daily so you can watch there too but Yellowdig is more current.  The score in Canvas is an average for the number of weeks so do not worry when the score drops on Sunday morning, it will rise again when you start posting.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Tim

documents.title: Capstone discussion in Yellowdig
documents.content:
Hi, Students:

The goal of the Capstone Discussion is to develop engaging conversations on the theme Earth in the Year 2100.  Each week we will focus on different topics related to this theme and the current module. The goal is to take what you have learned in the module and synthesize it with your own research and analysis.  You will be required to submit an original entry every week and to reply to at least one other student's post by Saturday midnight.  Submit your entry early to get more responses and more points. Your grade will be based on how active you are in the conversation.  Yellowdig is used for the discussion as it offers a much better experience than traditional Canvas discussion boards.  

The first topics will open on Sunday related to Module 1.

The Capstone Discussion is a great way to gain credit lost in the quizzes and labs if you spend the time to be engaged. 

We also have an "I need help" option in Yellowdig for you to get help with labs or other matters. Include @ProfessorBralower for a faster response.

Please read he instructions in the Orientation and Module 1 carefully.  You will need to make an account with a one-time payment of $12.95 for the semester. You can purchase online or at the bookstore.  You will get the hang of the discussion in the first week and get an idea of how your activity is rewarded in points.  The main advice I have is to post your initial entry early.  That way it will gain more attention and possibly more points.

Please note that Use of AI of ChatGPT in generating entries is a breach of Academic integrity and is easily detected.  The penalties will be severe, so please make sure you always write everything in your own words. 

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Tim

We take plagiarism very seriously and this pertains especially to the Yellowdig Capstone. Use of AI of ChatGPT in generating entries is a breach of Academic integrity and is easily detected.  The penalties will be severe, so please make sure you always write everything in your own words. 

Second, the course materials including the tests belong to Penn State and me.  This is an issue of Copyright.  Any posting of materials (including questions) on Discord, Chegg, CourseHero, Quizlet or any other test bank site is absolutely prohibited and will receive a very severe penalty, at minimum a grade reduction.

You need to go through the material in the Academic Integrity section of the Orientation and upload a screenshot or a PDF of your Academic Integrity certificate. This is worth 2 points.

documents.title: Introduction---please read
documents.content:
Hi, Students:

I’m writing to welcome you to Earth 103, Earth in the Future. I’m Tim Bralower, Professor for the class and I look forward to a great semester.

The goal of the course is to understand how Earth’s climate works and how climate change will impact the planet and its inhabitants over the course of the next century. A key part of the class is the labs that are based on real data and designed to provide you with a hands-on understanding of the course material.

It’s very important that you read emails. I will be in touch a lot during the semester so please take the time to read emails as it will help your progress and often save you time.

I also make daily short announcements about cool topics in the climate arena. I often include tips about upcoming assignments so please listen to them!

As you will read in the syllabus and all-important Course Orientation, the class has weekly quizzes in addition to eight labs. All of these exercises are key to your understanding of the material. There is a Capstone discussion on Yellowdig which requires at least one entry and reply every week. Finally, there are two midterms for the course. More on the midterms and Yellowdig Capstone later on.

The lab for the course is worth 30% and it uses a combination of Google Earth and STELLA. The latter program will be introduced in Module 3, but the former will be used in Module 1. It will be very important for you to get comfortable with it so I recommend you do the Google Earth Tutorial in the Orientation and I will post a tour in a day or so.

My job is to help you learn about Earth and its future and I am truly passionate about making sure you get the most out of the course. At the same time, your experience in the class will be amplified if you keep up with the material. The class has 12 weekly modules and moves fast. Once you are done with one module, you move right on to the next one. If you fall a week behind, you will find it very hard to catch up. That is why quizzes and labs have firm deadlines and we will not bend the rules without a very legitimate excuse. We have to be very firm on this from the outset.

All of the course materials can be found on Canvas. This is a WEB ONLY class and there are no (repeat no!) Zoom lectures! There is also no textbook.

There is NO reading outside of the links on Canvas and the weekly Yellowdig Discussion.

I know many of you will actually want to work ahead and complete future weeks’ assignments. Feel free to read the materials and prepare, but I cannot answer questions about future modules or I will be all over the place and the assignments are open only for a week.

One final thing. We also use Yellowdig for informal questions. More on that in a few days.

That's it for now; please get working on the Course Orientation.

Again, welcome to Earth 103!

Best wishes,

Tim Bralower

documents.title: Introduction to Earth 103
Welcome to Earth 103N
documents.content: Module: Welcome to Earth 103N

documents.title: Syllabus
documents.content:
Earth 103N at Penn State: Earth in the Future (Spring 2025)

This syllabus is divided into several sections. It is essential that you read the entire document as well as the material covered in the Course Orientation. Together these serve as our course "contract."

Instructor | Overview | Prerequisites | Expectations | Materials | Assignments and Grading | Schedule | Getting Help | Policies | Disclaimer

Instructor Information

Tim Bralower, Professor of Geosciences, College of Earth and Mineral Sciences, Penn State University.
Email: tjb26@psu.edu. I read and respond to emails regularly during business hours.

Return to top

Course Overview

Description: Introduction to the science of Earth's climate system, the consequences of future climate on Earth, strategies for how to minimize the effects of and adapt to a changing climate.
Prerequisites: None

Earth has a complex, fascinating, interconnected system of processes that control the state of the climate. If we can understand how this system works, then we can make intelligent predictions about the climate in the future. The future of climate is of great importance to the quality of life in the future. In this class, we will explore the workings of the climate system — at the present, and in the past — through a series of modules with hands-on learning activities. We will learn how simple and sophisticated computer models can provide useful tools for making predictions about what our climate will be like in the next few hundred years, which will be a critical time for our species as we endeavor to find a more sustainable way of living. A changing climate means changes in, among other things, temperature and precipitation, which will affect our water supplies, our energy consumption, and our ability to grow enough food to feed the people of Earth. A changing climate also means a range of stresses on the global economy. We will examine these climate impacts, but we will not stop there — we will also focus our attention on what can be done to help us successfully meet these challenges.

Students who successfully complete EARTH 103N should be able to:

  • explain how the climate system works, including something about its natural variability and the factors that drive climate change on a range of different timescales;
  • understand how scientists approach the question of climate change through a combination of data, models, and hypotheses;
  • explain the basic principles of climate models including their limitations and their uses, and what they predict about our future climate;
  • explain the primary consequences of climate change for water and food supplies, coastal damages, relocation costs, energy consumption, and economic growth;
  • explain the options for minimizing the effects of climate change and for adapting to a changing climate.

Return to top

Prerequisites

None

Return to top

What We Expect of You

On average, most students spend eight to ten hours per week working on course assignments. Your workload may be more or less depending on your prior experience with the energy topics we're covering and your familiarity with web-based classes.

We have worked hard to make this an effective and engaging educational experience. You will succeed if you are diligent about keeping up with the class schedule and if you take advantage of opportunities to engage with both your classmates and your instructors throughout the course.

The key to success in this course is keeping up with the assignments. Students who complete the labs and quizzes on time have a good chance of success. If you fall behind, it is usually very difficult to catch up.

Specific learning objectives for each module and lab exercise are detailed within modules.

What You Can Expect From Me

I am excited about the topic of the class, and I love it when others get excited about this material too, so I will always be happy to answer your questions. I am using an online learning environment for this course, and as such, I will answer all questions via email. Please feel free to contact me with questions and I will respond to you within 24 hours in most cases (weekends and holidays being exceptions). If I am going to be out of touch for a while, I will let you know ahead of time.

Return to top

Required Course Materials

Software

Students should plan to use Google Earth Pro and Microsoft PowerPoint during the course. For this reason, you cannot take this class without access to a PC (Google Earth Pro will not run on phones and iPads). Many of the Labs will prompt you to download a Microsoft Word worksheet, but you may also use other note-taking software or applications such as Evernote or Microsoft OneNote to record notes and develop questions and ideas as you work through the course materials. 

Textbooks

There is no textbook for you to buy for this course. All materials are presented online through Canvas. In order to access all materials, you need to have an active Penn State Access Account user ID and password (used to access the online course resources). If you have any questions about obtaining or activating your Penn State Access Account, please contact the Penn State IT Service Desk. 

You will be required to purchase Yellowdig for weekly discussions. To get started with Yellowdig, click on the Yellowdig link in the left-hand navigation for this course section. You will need to create an account and pay the $12.95 fee for the semester.

Assistance with textbooks

Penn State honors and values the socioeconomic diversity of our students. If you require assistance with the costs of textbooks for this course, please contact your academic advisor. For additional needs, related to socioeconomic status, please visit Project Cahir or visit the Office of Student Care and Advocacy at 222 Boucke Building or call 814-863-2020.

Return to top

Assignments and Grading

Lab Exercises 30%

Eight of the modules include a lab exercise that will engage you in studying data, maps, and models. These exercises build on the topics covered in the module and they will deepen and enhance your understanding of the material in that module.

Please read the following two paragraphs very carefully to avoid confusion!

Collectively, these lab exercises will make up 30% of your grade. The lab for each module will be weighted equally; your score for each will be converted to a percentage, and then I will take the mean of those percentages (throwing out the lowest grade) to calculate your final lab score. This class is 100% online. You will be submitting your answers in Canvas and they will be graded by Canvas. The advantage of this is you will get immediate feedback. All labs will be due Tuesday midnight of the week after the lab was started (i.e., Module 1 lab is due the Tuesday of the week you are working on Module 2).

We will drop the lowest lab score.

Capstone Discussion 20%

The goal of the Discussion is to develop engaging conversations on the theme of the weekly module.  Each week we will focus on different topics related to this theme and the current module. The goal is to take what you have learned in the module and synthesize it with your own research and analysis.  You will be required to (1) submit an original entry every week and (2) to reply to other students’ posts.  Your grade will be based on how active you are. We use the Yellowdig platform for the discussion, as it offers a much better experience than traditional Canvas discussion boards.  

Yellowdig provides a gamified approach to engaging with your peers. There is a one-time fee of $12.95 to use the platform for the course.  You'll be awarded points for your initial entry (provided it meets the required word count), then each time someone responds to your post, you also receive points. So, it's in your best interest to create thoughtful posts which will engage your peers in a meaningful discussion.  You will also receive points for replying to other students’ posts.  There is a leaderboard so you can see who is generating the highest quality posts and receiving the most responses.  

Each week I will give you a topic for the Discussion and you will be required to do some research beyond the course website.  I recommend you write your entry in MS Word and proof it before cutting and pasting it into Yellowdig.  Your original entry must include citations (any format is fine) but your replies to other students don’t need to unless you use information from other original sources.

 More information will be provided during Module 1.

Two Midterm Exams @ 15% each

These exams will cover material related to the module content and the lab exercises. The "Learning Outcomes" at the beginning of each module provide a list of topics you should know about. The first exam will cover Modules 1-6 and the second exam covers Modules 7-12.

Weekly Quizzes (total of 20%)

Students’ understanding of the module content and lab exercises will be assessed through electronically administered and graded quizzes (in Canvas). The quizzes will be designed to assess the extent to which students have mastered the science presented in the modules. There are Practice Quizzes available for each module to help your study before taking the Graded Quiz. The lowest quiz score will be dropped. Most questions will be chosen from among the questions listed under "Learning Outcomes" at the beginning of each module. The quizzes must be taken by Sunday midnight of the week in question.

Grades will be posted in Canvas with each assignment so that you can track your progress. The Capstone grade will be posted at the end of the semester.

Final overall grades will be determined based on the sums of these elements. Your grade will be expressed as a percentage, with 100% being the unattainable perfect grade. We convert these scores to a letter grade as follows:

Course Grading Schedule

Late Policy

All course-related assignments must be completed and successfully submitted by the assigned date — this is your responsibility. If an emergency arises, get in touch immediately to work out a solution.

Tips for Success in EARTH 103N

Do the work on time

We set deadlines to keep everyone on track to reach our ultimate goal of understanding what the future of climate means for our future. We will reach this goal in small steps, and we need to pace ourselves so that we can really learn this material. If you do your best to follow this pace and meet the deadlines, you will succeed. If an emergency arises, let us know as soon as possible and we can work something out if there is a good excuse — we are not merciless, but at the same time, we have to be fair to others by not giving in to less serious requests for extensions.

Be professional

We will assume that everyone in the class is an adult and will behave with integrity. We expect that you will not lie or cheat and that you will adhere to all of Penn State's policies on academic integrity. Penn State defines academic integrity as "the pursuit of scholarly projects in an open, honest and responsible manner." Academic integrity includes "a commitment not to engage in or tolerate acts of falsification, misrepresentation, or deception." In particular, the University defines plagiarism as "the fabrication of information and citations; submitting others' work from professional journals, books, articles, and papers; submission of other students' papers, lab results or project reports and representing the work as one's own." Penalties for violations of academic integrity may include course failure. If you are unclear about these policies, please review the material at the Policies and Rules for Undergraduate Students site. We also expect that you will treat your classmates and your instructor with respect. Climate change is an important topic with wide-reaching implications so that it has spilled out of the halls of science and into the more clamorous realm of politics, which is often ruled by opinions and beliefs rather than data. Politics is not science and it can often become personal; let us remember that this is a science class where we focus on the data rather than beliefs.

Getting Help

Class Support Services

Technical Help

  • Online Course Content: If you experience technology problems in the external, online course content, please contact your Instructor.  
  • Canvas: If you experience technology problems in Canvas, please contact Penn State's IT Help Portal.

It is in your own best interest to be as specific as you possibly can. Vague descriptions of a problem only delay assistance; try to include information such as:

  • the specific course page, quiz question, etc., you were on, what you attempted to do when that failed, and the exact language of any error message displayed on your screen;
  • the date and time when your problem occurred;
  • any other pertinent information (does the problem happen consistently and always in the same way, etc.).

A member of the Help Desk will be in contact with you to offer assistance.

documents.title: Meet the Instructor
documents.content:
Tim Bralower, Professor of Geosciences, College of Earth and Mineral Sciences, Penn State University.

Tim Bralower was born in Armonk, NY but moved to London at the age of four. London in the 1960s often had thick smog due to the use of coal for heating, and Tim remembers his father walking along the side of the car on a foggy night to help his mother steer it through the streets. Tim attended Oxford University and received a BA in Earth Science. Weather was a big factor in his choice of graduate school, so Tim followed his undergraduate degree with a PhD in Earth Science at Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California San Diego. Although a classically trained marine geologist, Tim’s specialty is calcareous nannoplankton, a group of marine plankton that leave an exquisite fossil record. The nannoplankton allows us to tell time or date ancient sediments back to 225 million years ago, and, in addition, inform us about environments in the past. Recently, Tim has focused his research on ancient time periods when the climate warmed rapidly. In particular, he is interested in what happens to life during these episodes. The motivation for this research is to predict what will happen in the future as the ocean continues to heat up. He is also interested in mass extinction, in particular, the same event 65 million years ago that led to the demise of the dinosaurs, which almost eradicated the nannoplankton. The extinction and subsequent recovery of life in the ocean give us a worst-case scenario for how modern plankton may respond to drastic environmental change.

Tim started his academic career as an Assistant Professor at Florida International University in Miami before moving to the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill where he rose through the academic ranks to become Chair of the Department of Geological Sciences. Tim moved to Penn State in 2003 and was Head of the Department of Geosciences for a total of 9.5 years. Tim’s research has taken him for fieldwork in Italy, much of the Western US, the Andes, and five ocean drilling expeditions. He recently served as a micropaleontologist on a rig that was set up to drill the Chicxulub crater off the coast of Mexico.
