documents.title: Course Structure
documents.content:
Canvas

Canvas is the learning management system currently being used by Penn State University. In Canvas, registered students may consult course calendars; communicate with instructors, teaching assistants, and fellow students; submit assignments; receive feedback from the instructor and teaching assistant; take online quizzes and surveys, and check assignment scores and course grades.

The instructional materials for Earth 103N are also located here in Canvas. The course consists of 12 lessons (modules). Each lesson contains an introduction, lengthy presentation of the topic and a laboratory exercise. The lab exercises are a key part of the class, designed to provide you with a stronger grasp of the concepts in each module. Many of the lab exercises involve the use of Google Earth; you must have Google Earth Pro on your computer, and you must be familiar with how to use it to complete the labs. We will help you if it does not work on your computer. Note that you cannot use a phone or a tablet to use Google Earth for this class. There are no readings for the Modules outside of the extensive material on the website. However, the Capstone involves a lot of reading (see below). The Earth is very visual and we have incorporated a lot of images in the text, more than a typical online course. Some of the images are in boxes. Make sure that you take in these images as you read the text. The final element of the course are videos, both clips recorded by the instructor to explain tricky concepts and longer documentaries mostly on YouTube. Make sure you watch these videos.

Yellowdig

 Yellowdig is the Discussion forum we use for this course. It also allows students to get help from the instructor and other classmates. Threaded discussions allow multiple posts and replies. More information on setting Yellowdig up is given below.

  • In general, questions and comments about project assignments, and course content should be shared with the entire class via Yellowdig. That way, everyone can benefit from the discussion.

Course and Structure

Topics of study

The content of this course is divided into 12 lessons (modules). Each module will be completed in approximately 1 week. The first six modules discuss the physical basis for climate change and the last six discuss the impact of change on natural systems as well as people.

  • Module 1: Past Episodes of Climate Change
  • Module 2: Recent Climate Change
  • Module 3: Earth's Climate System
  • Module 4: Introduction to General Circulation Models
  • Module 5: Global Carbon Cycle
  • Module 6: Ocean Circulation and its Impact on Climate
  • Module 7: Ocean Acidification, Red Tides and Monster Jellyfish
  • Module 8: Water Resources and Climate Change
  • Module 9: Climate Change and Food Supply
  • Module 10: Rising Seas
  • Module 11: Terrestrial Ecosystems in Peril
  • Module 12: Adaptation and Mitigation

Course assignments

Evaluation of student performance will be based on the following assignments:

Lab Exercises 30%

Eight modules include lab exercises that will engage you in studying data, maps, and models. These exercises build on the topics covered in the module and they will deepen and enhance your understanding of the material in that module.

Please read the following two paragraphs very carefully to avoid confusion!

The course is 100% online. You will be submitting your answers in Canvas and they will be graded by Canvas. The advantage of this is you will get immediate feedback. All labs will be due Tuesday midnight of the week after the lab was started (i.e. Module 1 lab is due the Tuesday of the week you are working on Module 2).

Collectively, these lab exercises will make up 30% of your grade. The lab for each module will be weighted equally; your score for each will be converted to a percentage and then I will take the mean of those percentages (throwing out the lowest grade) to calculate your final lab score. If you miss a lab with no documented excuse, you will not get a score for that lab.

Capstone Discussion: Earth in 2100 (20%)

The goal of the Discussion is to develop engaging conversations on the theme Earth in the Year 2100.  Each week we will focus on a different topic related to this theme and the current module. The goal is to take what you have learned in the module and synthesize it with your own research and analysis.  You will be required to (1) submit an original entry every week and (2) to reply to other students’ posts.  Your grade will be based on how active you are. We use the Yellowdig platform for the discussion as it offers a much better experience than traditional Canvas discussion boards.  

Yellowdig provides a gamified approach to engaging with your peers. There is a one-time fee of $12.95 to use the platform but you can then use it in this and other courses where it is required.  You'll be awarded points for your initial entry (provided it meets the required word count), then each time someone responds to your post, you also receive points. So, it's in your best interest to create thoughtful posts which will engage your peers in a meaningful discussion.  You will also receive points for replying to other students’ posts.  There is a leaderboard so you can see who is generating the highest quality posts and receiving the most responses.  

Each week I will give you a topic for the Discussion and you will be required to do some research beyond the course website.  I recommend you write your entry in MS Word and proof it before cutting and pasting it into Yellowdig.  Your original entry must include citations (any format is fine) but your replies to other students don’t need to unless you use information from other original sources.

More information will be provided during the first week of class.

Two Midterm Exams (15% each)

These exams will cover material related to the module content, the readings, and the lab exercises. Discussion questions posted at the end of many of the lab exercises represent possible exam questions, so you should study these carefully. The "Learning Outcomes" in the blue boxes at the beginning of each module provide a list of topics you should know about. The first exam will be multiple choice and the second will be short answer. Each exam is weighted equally; the first exam will cover Modules 1-6 and the second exam covers Modules 7-12.

Weekly Quizzes (total of 20%)

Students’ understanding of the module content and lab exercises will be assessed through electronically administered and graded quizzes (in Canvas). The quizzes will be designed to assess the extent to which students have mastered the science presented in the modules. The lowest grade will be dropped. Questions will be chosen from among the questions listed under "Learning Outcomes" in the blue boxes at the beginning of each module. The quizzes must be taken by Sunday midnight of the week in question.

Grades will be posted in Canvas with each assignment so that you can track your progress. The Capstone grade will be posted at the end of the semester.

Final overall grades will be determined based on the sums of these elements. Your grade will be expressed as a percentage, with 100% being the unattainable perfect grade.

documents.title: Using Yellowdig for this course
documents.content:
Sign up for Yellowdig 

Yellowdig is the Discussion Platform we'll be using for this semester. It offers a much better experience for you the learner than traditional Canvas discussion boards.  

How it works... 

The platform offers a gamified approach to engaging with your peers. You'll be awarded points for your initial entry (provided it meets the required word count), then each time someone responds to your post, you also received points. So it's in your best interest to create thoughtful posts which will engage your peers in a meaningful discussion.  

There is also a leaderboard so you can see who is generating the highest quality posts and receiving the most responses.  

Weekly Post and Response 

You will be required to post once a week and to reply to at least one classmate's post. The system will monitor your posts and the number of responses you receive. 

Grading 

The grading of these posts and responses is based on how much you engage. The more you interact, the higher your grade will be.  More information is provided in Module 1.

How to get started 

To get started with Yellowdig, click on the Yellowdig link in the left hand navigation for this course section. You will need to create an account and pay the $12.95 fee for the semester.  

Once you receive access to the system, you can review the getting started messages and the tutorials.

documents.title: Course Communication
documents.content:
Meaningful interactions among students and instructors are the hallmark of a successful online class. Canvas supports several types of communication, as described below. 

In addition, registered students have Penn State e-mail accounts (<Access Account ID>@psu.edu) that they need to monitor for any official communications that come from the University or from the Penn State World Campus.

Please note that this is a comprehensive list of communication tools available in Canvas. This course may or may not utilize all of the options below.

Announcements

Announcements are messages from your instructor that contain important information. Current announcements can be accessed through the Announcements link in Canvas. Announcements may highlight assignment due dates (also published in the Course Calendar), lesson recaps, a preview of an upcoming lesson, and other essential course information.  There will be daily announcements for most of the semester.

Conversations

Inbox/Conversations: The Canvas "conversations" tool (called "Inbox" in your global navigation menu) allows you to communicate with your classmates, group members, and course instructor from within Canvas. It's great to use for a quick email to another student, instructor, or a whole team. Keep in mind that the text editor is very minimal, and does not have much formatting capability. Please use Canvas email only for private messages to instructors or fellow students. If you need rapid assistance, email me at bralower@psu.edu or tjb26@psu.edu.

Yellowdig

Yellowdig allows students to interact with the instructor and other classmates. Threaded discussions allow multiple posts and replies.

  • In general, questions and comments about project assignments, and course content should be shared with the entire class via Yellowdig. That way, everyone can benefit from the discussion.

Note

Whenever you post a message in Yellowdig or send course mail, please title every message with a descriptive subject line. Subject lines that include the gist of a question or comment increase the chances that students and instructors can retrieve the messages we're looking for. Poor subject lines, such as "Question" or "Lesson 1," are not very useful as search keywords. When replying to a prior message, consider whether or not the subject line should be altered to indicate the content of your reply!

documents.title: How to Succeed in Earth 103N
documents.content:
The Recipe for Success

In real estate, you hear the phrase, "Location, Location, Location!"

In music, as in sports, the phrase goes something like "Practice, Practice, Practice!".

And in the world of cooking, everyone knows that "the better the batter, the better the cake!".

In other words, what you put in greatly influences what you get out. And that is what this page is all about:  Quality in - quality out.

How To Succeed in an Online Course

For online courses, the advice most likely to lead you to success is "Engage, Engage, Engage!"

What does this mean? Quite simply, it means being active in the course on a regular basis. It means keeping in sync with what's going on in the course, staying on top of deadlines and assignments, asking for help when necessary, and taking every opportunity to interact with the content and the instructors. It means making EARTH 103 a regular part of your routine. Do this, and frankly, it will be difficult for you NOT to succeed in this course.

In online courses, the role of both the instructors AND the students tends to shift from the traditional classroom roles. The instructors' role is similar to that of good supervisors, and the students' role is closer to that of a good employee. The instructors define and set overall goals, outcomes, and timelines; make the information, resources, and experiences available to you to meet those goals; and, provide the support, guidance, communication channels, and feedback to help you succeed. The students' primary responsibilities are to stay on task; to manage their time and energy in order to get everything done on a weekly basis; to ask for guidance when in need of clarification, and to take every opportunity available to improve their chances of success.

So, the very best advice we can offer you is to be engaged in this course at least nine hours each week, and log on 5-6 days of the week to spread out your study and thinking time. In the final analysis, completing multiple online sessions of quality study time is a tried-and-true recipe for success in EARTH 103.

Six specific steps to help you succeed in this course

  1. Intentionally schedule your time! Treat this course like a traditional face-to-face course and you should be fine.
    • Schedule a time to read the instructional materials and take notes on what you read.
    • Schedule a time to review your notes.
    • Schedule a time to do your assignments.
    • Do not procrastinate.
    • Use a calendar program and set regular reminders for yourself.
  2. Read, Read, Read
    • Read the Lesson overview and objectives.
    • Read and take notes on all lesson materials including external readings, videos, etc.
    • Read all email, discussion forum posts, and class announcements.
    • Read all the instructions that accompany all assignments—they are there to help you succeed!
  3. Take Notes!  Again, treat this course just like a traditional face-to-face course.
    • Take notes when you read!
    • Write down what you don't understand and ask about it in the discussion boards.
  4. Communicate with the Instructors.
    • Use the Discussion Forums to ask general questions about the course set-up or content.
    • Email "ALL COURSE FACULTY" for private questions.
  5. Be Familiar with all of the Technical Requirements.
    • Just like other courses that have prerequisites, this course requires you to have certain technical specifications and knowledge.  Do NOT bypass the tests on the Technical Requirements page.   Failure to do so may result in poor learning outcomes.  Pay specific attention to the browser you are using—this is critical to your success in EARTH 103!
  6. Understand and know how to use Canvas. 
    • Review the PSU Canvas Student Orientation. 
    • Become familiar with where things are located and when things are due.
    • Use the Canvas help if you have questions (question mark icon on the lower left-hand side of the Canvas page).

documents.title: Google Earth Tutorial
documents.content:
Google Earth

Google Earth is an incredible geospatial tool that can be used for a wide variety of educational and research purposes. This digital globe software is very easy to use. Individuals can download the software for free and can easily browse, carry out inquiry, create new knowledge and data, and can save and share information using KMZ data files, or you can easily output the content as image files for incorporation into presentations or reports. Google Earth is a great research tool and with it anyone can collect information. A wide-range of Imagery including historical imagery contains a great deal of information about both natural and human landscapes around the Earth's surface. Street View functionality is also expanding in major cities and some rural areas and this adds an incredible array of 360° panoramic views as though the user were actually in place on the street. Built in features also provide terrain views to add to 3-D visualization. A whole range of additional tools (measuring tools, image overlay tools, video touring tools, and others) allow for both qualitative and quantitative analysis of landscapes through time. Google Earth layers offer additional geographic information sorted by thematic area, provide labels, political boundaries, and more. Google Earth is also searchable and allows you to fly to most any location by name or coordinates.

For all of these reasons, this software will be the principal tool that will be used in this course to help you develop critical geospatial skills.

Download the Software

Go to the Google Earth website and download the Google Earth Pro version for your computer. 

Install the Software

  1. Find and double-click the GoogleEarthComputerTypePro.dmg file. The file name will change a little depending what type of computer you have. 
  2. Next use the Google Earth Installer that will be displayed to install the software. Start by clicking the icon that is displayed.
  3. Follow the instructions to complete the process. 

Tutorials and Resources from Google Earth

Note: There are a number of instructional elements on the Google Earth Help Center, so make sure you refer to the Help Center when necessary.

  • Getting started resources from the Google Earth Help Center website
  • The Science Education Resource Center (SERC) has an extensive tutorial document that is extremely useful.

Google Earth Video Tutorial (20:27)

Video transcript.
In this tutorial we're going to spend a little bit of time focusing on the tools within Google Earth. When you open Google Earth you'll see this screen. A couple of the things that I want to point out to you are the header bars and tools that are available here. The first one you'll notice is the search bar at the top left-hand corner of the screen. Anytime you can type in a location that you're interested to find. For instance, if you're interested in Adelaide, South Australia, you click on that and hit Search. Google Earth will zoom in to the location that you typed in. In this case you can see we've zoomed in on Adelaide, South Australia. And you can continue to zoom in to see other features; and you can even type in street addresses and other locations. You can also use latitude and longitude here, as well, to find a location. What are some of the other tools? First off you'll notice that down in the lower right-hand side of the screen you’ll notice latitude and longitude and elevation of wherever your cursor is. So as you zoom in to this coastline, and of course you can see in this particular view, as you zoom, an ocean-going vessel underway, going up this particular river. But you can see that the latitude and longitude is shown, as well as the imagery day of the image. So this image was from January 30th 2010. Okay. So it's a lot of information that's available. In terms of navigating, up in the upper right hand corner, you can use the compass tool, or the GOI tool, and you can spin the view at any point, and you can choose the perspective. And you just have to play around with those tools to become comfortable with them. You can use your mouse, if you have a roller ball, and you can zoom in and zoom out fairly simply. Or you can double click on features and you can zoom in and out of those features. So that's an interesting tool. So here you can see a beautiful mangrove system on these tidal creeks leading into this river system here going out into the ocean. Other tools. Okay, so up here at the top you'll see the placemark tool. So if you're interested in labeling a feature and you want to make sure that you are able to find that feature in the future, you can just identify that. You click on the placemark tool and while the dialog box is open, you can click on the placemark and you can move it to wherever you would like to on the screen and you can name it. And you can also change the color. There's a number of different versions, so if you wanted the color code features you certainly could do that. You can change the color of your pin. We'll change it to blue. And again, you can do any number of different things that are here. Okay, so that makes that pretty easy. So notice now when I change, it's in the green situation. You can change the labeling. So the Adelaide, Australia, if you want to change that to a different color, you can do that. Notice now I just changed it to yellow. And the icon itself you can change as well. You can change different colors that way. So it's pretty simple. And notice now that I close that, the pin location is here. In this case it's in the temporary places folder. And this is really important, so what I would like you to do is add a folder here. Anytime you're working in Google Earth and you want to retain information, add a folder and you should name that according to your projects. A good way to do that is project module 1, for instance if you were working on an assignment for module 1. And you can you can click OK and then easily once you have made your folder you can move your placemarks into that folder. Now the big thing, before you exit out of Google Earth, make sure you move that into your “my places” folder. That way you will be able to save it by right clicking “Save place as” and you can save it to any location that you would like save it to. You can navigate to your documents and you can in a place it there, so that's pretty simple. I'm not going to save mine at the moment but we'll leave it there. So that's the placemark tool. What are some of the other tools that you can find? Well we have a “add a polygon” tool. So for instance if we wanted you to, or if you wanted to measure the area of a particular coastal feature or of a town. So if we are here for instance, you have a number of impoundments that have been clearly developed here as flood control structures. If we wanted to measure the area of those or we wanted to highlight those features, again you click on the button and you can simply click and drag around the area. And you can be very precise with this, I'm just doing it very sort of cursory. And you can use your arrow keys to move if you have to. Now notice I didn't like the way those buttons, so I can hit the delete button rather than the return. Just hit the delete and I can undo whatever it was that I had just pinned and so there I have completed my polygon and I can you know name it whatever I would like to, Area One. And I could even add a description, so if I wanted to say this was an impoundment, you know we could do that. You could also add a link to a website if you found information out about it. Or you can add information, an image to your content description. Whatever you put in this description box, it will be there for you when you click on that feature. So you see area one impoundment, everything is there. Now if you close out of a feature that you've already identified and you would like to go back in and modify it, it's really simple. You come over to your places box on the left hand side. You right click on there with your mouse and you come down to properties. So at any time you can come back in here and you can add or edit any information. So I want to change my line color, maybe I want to change my fill color. Now what if I wanted to actually see this in a little bit of a transparency. So what you can do is here in the opacity, we can take that down to say 20 percent or we can take it down to 30 percent, whatever you would like to do. The same goes with the opacity of the line color that you run around the outside perimeter. Whichever you do, you're just going to need to hit okay and it's easy for you to go back to those points. Now notice I'm now navigated away from the very first point that I had done. And if I want to go back to that at any point, I can just click on that location on that point and it will zoom me back to the location I was at when I placed that pin. Let's just try for another. Let’s go for Beijing China. We'll see what we can find out about Beijing and then we'll use another tool there. So notice I'm flying or navigating to Beijing. And you can see that Beijing is located sort of to the west of the ocean, but it's a fairly large city. So let’s sort of zoom in on some of the coastal features here just a little and you'll notice that we have a very large port area. So for instance, if we wanted to measure the distance between Beijing, and we’ll go ahead and we’ll do a ruler tool here. The first thing I want to do is I'm going to put a placemark, and we'll put it down here, just so that it’s a reference. And we’ll just say “nearest port to Beijing”, and we hit okay. And now if I wanted to measure the distance how am I going to measure that distance? Now I can click up here on the ruler tool and I have a couple of different options that I can follow here. First of all, I can use the line tool and I can just simply click. And now this is in meters or I can switch it to kilometers or I can switch it to miles, whatever units you would like. When you're doing long distances it is wise for you to use, obviously a larger scale, for instance kilometers. So in this particular case you'll notice that the distance from my Beijing City Center to the nearest port, as the crow would fly, is 157 kilometers. And that's also at a heading of a hundred and thirty degrees. So in other words, this is north, as we all know is a zero degree reading on a compass. So if I were to go from Beijing China to the port, I would be going to South East at a bearing of a hundred and thirty degrees, to get from Beijing to that port. Okay now another thing that you can do, instead of just doing a simple straight line as the crow would fly, you might want to know the path. So for instance, if you wanted to follow a road or a river. So here you can see one of the rivers. It's very simple for you. You can click on the image and again here I'm going to use my arrow keys to trace out the river system. So I'm going to continue to do that. As I follow this river I’m going to arrow over. For a boat to make it to Beijing from the port city, rather than going by airplane or as a crow would fly. Notice here that that path that I chose, it is a very rough path, it's not precise. You can be certainly much more careful with your clicking. It's roughly 200 kilometers to travel that distance. At any time, you can always hit clear and you can go back. Now if you want to upgrade to Google Earth Pro you can also do lots of areas and perimeters and other kinds of things, which are very interesting, as you develop your abilities. Pretty neat tool to do here. So when you're ready to close that go ahead. So we've covered the “add a placemark” tool and the “polygon tool” and let's talk a little bit about a line or a path. So just as I did before, this is a way for us to actually label a path that’s on this stream, so I'm just going to go ahead and I'm gonna click a path that I might want to follow, not necessarily you know okay perfect one. But so there's a path and if I wanted to say this was a transportation route for instance, I could do that. And add any kind of a description in here. So there it is and notice it's still in the projects bar, module one at any time that I'm interested to go back to a site. So what if I wanted to go back to Adelaide? Again I could just click on Adelaide and I can fly all the way back down there. Okay so that's pretty simple. And as I zoom in again you can see the polygons, that was my impoundment, and here's of course Adelaide itself. All right so the only other tool that I was going to point out at this point, well there are two more tools that I want to point out. One of them is what's called the “add an image overlay” tool. If there was a map or other image that you would like to add, you would click on that new image overlay and you would browse for that map and you could insert it. And once it's inserted you can rotate the map to align it with your geology or you can drag the corners and make it smaller or larger. Ok, again you can shift the center of it around. So there's a lot of neat things that you can do with this tool and this is really, in a GIS environment, what is called georeferencing. So you can take any map, any image that you would have as a JPEG or a PNG file and insert it in here, and you can align it to the map. And if you want to be able to see through your map, to be able to register it, sometimes it's really useful to use the opacity or transparency function to be able to see it as well. So I'm never going to have finished this one because obviously I haven't selected a map but that's something that you could do easily enough. The last tool what I want to point out to you in terms of you know workable tools that are useful for you, one of them is right here. It's called the record a tool and this will allow you to make interesting video captures of features that you want to see. And so a little dialog box that opens on the screen, you can notice that there's a microphone and that there is a record button. So anything that you do from the point that you click on that button you will be able to record. So at this point I'm going to zoom into area one and you'll notice that down here it's clicking off so it's recording everything that I'm doing. And if I wanted to zoom in on another area, okay I could click on that area on that feature and as you zoom in, it’s recording your activity. So as we zoom in here you can see that this is probably a river channel, that's obviously covered in a lot of trees and it's probably a freshwater system or at least mostly freshwater, that it clearly must have some saltwater influence on it, so it may even have some tidal component to it. But that's beside the point of this at this point in time. So I will go ahead and hit stop and immediately my video will start playing and I have the option of watching that video to see if it's if it's exactly what I want. And if it's what I like, and I'm happy with the video, I can hit the save the video and save it to your places and it will always be a video that you can share with anybody easily enough. So I can hit share and I can call that one a quick tour of Adelaide. So I’ll hit save and notice it also comes into my and to my folder for my project. As long as that's where I've been working that's where it will be. And when I'm ready to finish this project, it's very easy for me to go here and hit save place as and I can save it to any folder I want to save it to. Okay so there I have my tool I have the tools, and that would be the important part one. Oh one more item that I meant to mention here. The historical imagery tool. So we will zoom back out for a minute and if I'm interested to see how this landscape might be changing, I can certainly turn on a historical imagery tool. You'll notice that up pops this little box, and if you look closely here there are several images that are posted here. I can go back in time to, in this case this is March 17, 2005 January 15, 2004, April 25th 2003. Now not all images are very perfect for all areas, because of course depends on the quality of the imagery that was taken at that time, but if we wanted to zoom in and see some of the changes that do take place. Okay you can see there are some referencing images issues here, so sometimes it may not be the best. For some regions you'll get very excellent data. So again that historical imagery tool and you can turn it back off if you don't want to see it. Alright so there's a very quick set of instructions showing you what's going on in Google Earth and how to use some of the tools. And there are certainly a number of other ones that are available to you online via the Google Earth website itself. So that will help you hopefully, this will help you. If you have any questions on Google Earth feel free to ask your instructors.

documents.title: Academic Integrity Assignment Overview
documents.content:
Academic Integrity is one of the six Penn State Values that all students are expected to uphold. As stated in University Faculty Senate Policy 49-20:

“Academic integrity is the pursuit of scholarly activity in an open, honest and responsible manner. Academic integrity is a basic guiding principle for all academic activity at The Pennsylvania State University, and all members of the University community are expected to act in accordance with this principle."

Additionally, academic integrity includes "a commitment not to engage in or tolerate acts of falsification, misrepresentation, or deception." In particular, the University defines plagiarism as "the fabrication of information and citations; submitting other's work from professional journals, books, articles, and papers; submission of other students’ papers, lab results or project reports and representing the work as one's own." Penalties for violations of academic integrity policy may include forfeited assignments, course failure, or disqualification from a degree or certificate program.

We don't expect that any of our students would willfully violate the University's Academic Integrity policy, but it is important that you are fully aware of it so that you don't inadvertently violate the policy. The majority of students who have taken this class in the past have not cheated on purpose. There have been, however, more than a few students have submitted assignments that violate academic integrity standards of the University. In most cases this is due to inadequate awareness of our expectations, poor paraphrasing, and citation errors. Your good faith participation in this assignment should minimize that risk for you.

Expectations

We expect our students to be able to:
  1. Paraphrase an original source properly. Recognize an inadequate paraphrase and explain why it's inadequate,
  2. Quote original material properly, including different typographical formats for short quotes and extended quotes. Recognize over-reliance on quotations vis a vis original text. For EARTH 103, use quotations sparingly. Only use quotations when someone says something.
  3. Cite paraphrases, quotations and graphics adequately and consistently. An adequate citation includes enough information to find the associated reference in a footnote or at the end of the work.
  4. Reference cited works adequately and consistently. An adequate reference includes enough information to find the original version of the cited work in a library or online - even after the URL expires. In EARTH 103, we use APA style guide. (Published reference styles like APA are recommended, but not required unless a work is to be published formally. For this course, however, citations are required.)
  5. Explain why it's wrong to produce a report that does not fulfill the first four objectives.
  6. Recognize the penalties that the University authorizes for violations of academic integrity.
  7. Understand that the copyright of the materials in this class, including the course website, the quizzes and labs belong to Penn State and the professor. Distribution of these materials (for example on CourseHero, Chegg, Discord, Quizlet or elsewhere) is strictly illegal, is a serious academic integrity violation and will result in academic integrity sanctions.
  8. Use of ChatGPT or any AI writing generator is strictly prohibited.
  9. Understand that all Quizzes and Midterms are Closed Book.

Instructions

Note: This assignment should take no more than 45 minutes of your time to complete.

  1. Carefully read the University Faculty Senate Policy 49-20 Academic Integrity.

  2. Watch the 14-minute video called Summarizing, Paraphrasing, and Quoting: A Guide to Doing it Right!

  3. Review the Citation and Reference Style Guide, which focuses on correct APA citation and reference style.

  4. Read and familiarize yourself with the Dos and Don't of using ChatGPT.

  5. Complete Penn State's Academic Integrity training and score an at least an 80 on the training's Final Assessment.

  6. Upload a screenshot or a PDF of your certificate. If you have taking the training before, you may upload that certificate and forgo retaking the training. If you are unsure of how to take a screenshot, refer to the following resource: https://www.take-a-screenshot.org/ (Links to an external site.)

To begin, either click the links above or use the Next button to work through each step. If a page does not load into your browser window, click the link at the top of the page to force it to open a new window.

documents.title: Dos and Don'ts of ChatGPT and other AI Tools
documents.content:
ChatGPT and other Generative AI tools including Microsoft CoPilot, Gemini, Claude, etc. are very powerful tools that can help you research a lot of topics. At the same time these tools can be used in ways that are not legitimate.  For example, you cannot use ChatGPT to write any part of your assessments or to answer quiz questions for you.  Both of these uses are considered violations of academic integrity and will incur serious penalties. 

Below are legitimate ways you can use artificial intelligence as well as examples that are not considered legitimate in this course. 

Legitimate uses of Generative AI Tools

  • Using for research before writing a post for Yellowdig. If you do this make sure you cite AI assistance in your reference list.
  • Using it to proofread your Yellowdig entries
  • Asking questions about study material you don’t understand

Illegitimate uses of Generative AI Tools

  • Don’t ask AI software to write Yellowdig entries for you. This is a form of plagiarism and as such is a breach of academic integrity.

You might not realize but professors are pretty good at detecting language that is AI generated.  It is robotic and often uses words that are not natural choices in topics like the ones you will be writing about in this class. We can use ChatGPT checkers to determine the probability that text is AI generated.  So, the bottom line is you will likely not get away with using ChatGPT to write for you, so please don’t use it

  • Don’t blindly trust AI-generated information. Especially with very technical information we present in this course, AI will often give you the wrong answers. Specifically for quizzes, we have intentionally modified questions to make them more complex so that AI will either fail to give you an answer or give you the wrong answer.

documents.content:
Welcome to Module 1 of Earth 103! To begin this module, click Next to work through the Module 1 materials. Don't forget to review the Assignments Roadmap and complete all of the assignments by the due dates located on the syllabus.

Objectives:

On completing this module, students are expected to be able to:

  • Explain how sediments, ice cores, and tree rings record geological time
  • Explain how proxy information on past climates is extracted from geological materials
  • Infer the nature of climate change from proxy records
  • Consider how ancient events can inform us of changes to come in the future

After you have read and understood everything in the course content for this module, complete the Lab 1 Practice Submission and the Lab 1 Graded Submission. Before moving onto the next Module, make sure that you take the Module 1 Quiz. To get started, click Next below to begin reading the content.

documents.title: Capstone Assignment Description
documents.content:
Discussion Themes: Any topic related to weekly module

The goal of the Capstone is to develop engaging conversations on the theme of the weekly module. The goal is to take what you have learned in the module and synthesize it with your own research and analysis. You should attempt to (1) submit an original entry every week as early in the week as possible and (2) to reply to other students’ posts by Saturday midnight. Your grade will be based on how active you are in the conversation. Yellowdig is used for for the discussion as it offers a much better experience than traditional Canvas discussion boards.

Yellowdig is the online conversation platform that we will be using for Earth in the Future. You receive points for participating in Yellowdig conversations, and the points you receive in Yellowdig factor into your final grade. Each week, you can earn up to 1000 points. To get an "A" on the Yellowdig assignment, you must have at least 12,000 points by the end of the course. If you reach the weekly max by the end of each week, you are guaranteed to get an "A" on the Yellowdig assignment which is worth 20% of your final grade.

Yellowdig provides a gamified approach to engaging with your peers. There is a one-time fee of $12.95 to use the platform for the course. You'll be awarded points for your initial entry (provided it meets the required word count), then each time someone responds to your post, you also receive points. So, it's in your best interest to create thoughtful posts which will engage your peers in a meaningful discussion. It will also benefit you to post early in the week, Thursday by the latest, as more students will have the opportunity to respond to you. You will also receive points for replying to other students’ posts. There is a leader board so you can see who is generating the highest quality posts and receiving the most responses.

Each week you should focus on topics related to the weekly module. For the discussion you will need to do some research beyond the course website. I recommend you write your entry using Google Voice and MS Word and proof it before cutting and pasting it into Yellowdig. Your original entry must include citations (any format is fine) but your replies to other students don’t need to unless you use information from other original sources.

Here is a summary of the rules:

The Goal

The goal of the discussion is for you to integrate what you have learned in the module with independent research and analysis on topics related to it. You should be synthesizing information in that module with your own research. Personal opinions on topics that will foster positive discussion are encouraged.

Weekly Post and Response

You will be required to post once a week and to reply to a classmate's post. The system will monitor your posts and the number of responses you receive. You will get the hang of it over the course of the first few weeks. The more peers you post comments on, the more point you will accrue.

Research

I suggest that you use sources like the New York Times, Washington Post, Scientific American, or Google Scholar to do your research. Wikipedia is also a possibility but it is less likely to be original than other sources, so I recommend you search more broadly. You can use the course website but you must use additional sources. Remember the more original your post is the more likely you will get responses to it.

Initial Entry

Your initial or primary post must be more than 75 words. We advise you to submit it early in the week, the earlier you post this entry the more responses you are likely to get, and these responses will improve your score. Please make sure that you write in your own words and paraphrase all quotes. This means absolutely no direct copying from your sources will be tolerated including copying with quotation marks. We can also identify text written by AI or ChatGPT. Make sure you write clearly and stay on topic. I highly recommend you write your initial post as well as your replies in Word so you can proof them before submitting. Word will also check for spelling and grammatical mistakes.

You earn more points for a great initial entry. Your peers are your judges and when they respond to your post because it interests or resonates with them, you get points. So you will be rewarded for doing great research and generating an excellent and thoughtful original post. Feel free to add images and videos to bring your post to life, but these are not essential or required. The main thing is that a quality post based on solid research will get you credit. Also, early entries will get more points because more students will get to respond to them before the deadline. To earn as many points as possible, you are strongly encouraged to contribute to our Yellowdig Community early and often.

Responses to other students’ posts

You must reply to at least one other student’s post each week by Saturday midnight, however, to accrue 1000 points, you will need to reply to more than one of your peers if others are not replying to your post. The idea is to reward your peers for producing excellent content by commenting on and reacting to their posts. Responses must be at least 25 words long long. Please try and make this reply thoughtful with substance, comments as well as disagreements. It is not enough to say things like “I agree with you.”

Grading

The grading of these posts and responses is based on how much you engage. The more you interact both replying to other students’ posts and having them reply to yours, the higher your grade will be. I will moderate the discussion and points will be deducted for factually erroneous posts, those that are not on topic and those that copy directly from the source (including in parentheses). Points will also be deducted for posts of comments that are rude or lack respect for other students’ points of view as well as for plagiarism.

The grading period for each Yellowdig module/week will begin on Sunday morning and end on the following Saturday at midnight. Your Yellowdig grade is worth 20% of your final grade.

You receive points for interacting and engaging with your peers in the following ways:

  • Writing an Initial Post of at least 75 words (280 points) as early as possible.
  • Writing a Comment of at least 25 words (210 points) by Saturday midnight.
  • Receiving a Comment on your Post (70 points)
  • Receiving an Accolade on your Post or Comment (Points vary):
  • Receiving a Reaction on your Post or Comment (50 points

The goal is to reach the weekly target of 1000 points to get you an A in the Capstone, but we have an additional great feature which is a buffer of 35% or 350 points, this allows you to make up for weeks that you have scored lower or missed posting. There is no way for me to adjust points in Yellowdig if you miss posting for any reason. You will have to use this buffer. Once you cannot earn 1350 points there is no way to earn any more until the weekly reset deadline on Sunday morning.

Yellowdig passes back your Yellowdig grade to Canvasas a proportion (a percentage) that represents your current pace toward getting an "A" in Yellowdig. Therefore, the points you see in Yellowdig might not match the points you see in Canvas. I will hide the Yellowdig score in Canvas to avoid confusion. To see how you are doing, look in Yellowdig. If any of this confuses you, just remember: if you end every week with a Yellowdig grade of 100%, you are guaranteed to get an "A" in Yellowdig.

You will learn how your activity impacts your score over the first week or two and then you can modify your subsequent entries based on that knowledge. Your lowest week’s score is dropped, so you can use the first week as a learning experience.

Our Community will thrive when we treat each other with respect and sensitivity. We will be adopting Yellowdig's code of conduct for this course. [I also remind you of our institution's policies around student conduct: Link to or list additional ground rules]

Timing

For each module the Discussion will open on Monday and stay open till Sunday midnight. You must complete your initial entry and your responses to other students’ posts by Sunday midnight. Absolutely no extensions will be given under any circumstance.

How to get started

To get started with Yellowdig, click on the Yellowdig link in the left hand navigation for this course section. You will need to create an account and pay the $12.95 fee for the semester.

Once you receive access to the system, you can review the getting started messages and tutorials. A few additional recommendations:

  • Watch Yellowdig's student orientation videos.
  • Peruse the Features and Functionality section of Yellowdig's Knowledge Base.
  • If you have any technical questions or are having trouble, send Yellowdig a support ticket here.
  • Take advantage of features like #hashtags and @mentions to bring your conversations to life!

documents.title: Capstone: Yellowdig Assignment  1
documents.content:
Topics: Any topic related to Module 1

Instructions

  1. Research a topic related to Module 1 using sources like the New York Times, Washington Post, Scientific American, or Google Scholar. Wikipedia is also a possibility but it is less likely to be original than other sources, so we recommend you search more broadly.
  2. Your initial or primary post must be over 75 words.  Post this early to get more feedback and more points. Make sure you choose the right topic flag. Please make sure that you write in your own words and paraphrase all quotes. This means absolutely no direct copying from your sources will be tolerated including copying with quotation marks. Make sure you write clearly and stay on topic. I highly recommend you write your initial post as well as your replies in MS Word so you can print them out and proof them before submitting.  Word will also check for spelling and grammatical mistakes.
  3. You must reply to at least one other student’s post during the course of the week. Please try and make this reply thoughtful and substantiative with comments as well as polite disagreements.  Your post must be at least 25 words long.  It is not enough to say things like “I agree with you.”  Remember the grading is based on how much you engage, so the more replies you post and the more that others reply to your post the higher your grade.  I will moderate the discussion and deduct points for factual errors, posts that are off the topic and plagiarism.  I will also deduct for posts that show a lack of respect for the opinions of others.
  4. You must post your primary entry and response(s) by Saturday midnight to get credit. Absolutely no extensions will be given.
  5. Also as soon as Module 2 opens on Sunday, your Yellowdig score in Canvas will halve!  So if you had 100% on Saturday night, you will have 50% on Sunday morning.  Do not panic, your entries during the week will raise it back up again!

documents.title: Module 2: Recent Climate Change (Week 2)
documents.content: Module: Module 2: Recent Climate Change (Week 2)

documents.title: Module 2: Welcome and Instructions
documents.content:
Welcome to Module 2 of Earth 103! To begin this module, click Next to work through the Module 2 materials. Don't forget to review the Assignments Roadmap and complete all of the assignments by the due dates located on the syllabus.

Objectives:

On completing this module, students are expected to be able to:

  • Describe climate trends from recent changes in temperature, atmospheric water content and glacier length and mass
  • Explain the difference between weather, climate and the importance of time scales when looking at climate data   
  • Infer temperature trends from instrumental and borehole data

After you have read and understood everything in the course content for this module, complete the Lab 2 Practice Submission and the Lab 2 Graded Submission. Before moving onto the next Module, make sure that you take the Module 2 Quiz. To get started, click the link below to begin reading the content on the course website.

documents.title: Module 3: Earth's Climate System (Week 3)
documents.content: Module: Module 3: Earth's Climate System (Week 3)

documents.title: Module 3: Welcome and Instructions
documents.content:
Welcome to Module 3 of Earth 103! To begin this module, click Next to work through the Module 3 materials. Don't forget to review the Assignments Roadmap and complete all of the assignments by the due dates located on the syllabus.

Objectives:

On completing this module, students are expected to be able to:

  • Describe how energy is absorbed, stored, and moved around in Earth's climate system
  • Distinguish how the amount of energy stored determines the temperature
  • Interpret the importance of feedback mechanisms that make our climate system sensitive to forcings, but also provide a stabilizing influence
  • Infer how temperature responds to changes in solar input, albedo, and greenhouse gas concentrations
  • Evaluate how simple (i.e. STELLA) models can be used to make projections of climate variables

After you have read and understood everything in the course content for this module, complete the Lab 3 Practice Submission and the Lab 3 Graded Submission. Before moving onto the next Module, make sure that you take the Module 3 Quiz. To get started, click the link below to begin reading the content on the course website.

documents.title: Module 4: Welcome and Instructions
documents.content:
Welcome to Module 4 of Earth 103! To begin this module, click Next to work through the Module 4 materials. Don't forget to review the Assignments Roadmap and complete all of the assignments by the due dates located on the syllabus.

Objectives:

On completing this module, students are expected to be able to:

  • Explain how general circulation climate models work
  • Describe the different emission scenarios that are used for future model predictions and distinguish their relative impact
  • Evaluate regional climate model predictions for the worst-case emissions scenario
  • Assess how scientists communicate model predictions to policymakers

documents.title: Module 5: Global Carbon Cycle (Week 5)
documents.content: Module: Module 5: Global Carbon Cycle (Week 5)

documents.title: Module 5: Welcome and Instructions
documents.content:
Welcome to Module 5 of Earth 103! To begin this module, click Next to work through the Module 5 materials. Don't forget to review the Assignments Roadmap and complete all of the assignments by the due dates located on the syllabus.

Objectives:

On completing this module, students are expected to be able to:

  • Explain the different components of the marine and terrestrial carbon cycle
  • Recognize that atmospheric CO2 has changed through time and how that variation has impacted climate
  • Interpret how the carbon cycle impacts Earth's climate
  • Project through modeling how the amount and rate of future carbon emission impact climate and the chemistry of the oceans

After you have read and understood everything in the course content for this module, complete the Lab 5 Graded Submission. Before moving onto the next Module, make sure that you take the Module 5 Quiz. To get started, click the link below to begin reading the content on the course website.

documents.title: Lesson 1 HW (Graded)
documents.content:
Homework (20% of grade)

Graded homework (HW) is assigned for each of the 12 Lessons of the course through McGraw-Hill Connect. There will be 12 homework opportunities. You will have unlimited attempts at each homework (i.e. you can do the HW as many times as you wish before the deadline), and your highest homework score will be used in determining your final grade.

A "Check Answer" button is available. Clicking this button will reveal if you have successfully completed the assignment question. You will have five attempts to check your answer when navigating each graded assignment question. After five attempts, if you want to earn a higher grade on that assignment you will have to restart the assignment.

Each homework must be completed by the due date/time established in the Course Calendar. Once a graded homework closes, it cannot be re-opened for any reason. However, students can continue to review their submitted homework as part of their continued practice of the course material.

If you want to keep practicing the homework assignment after the due date, please refer to the respective "Study Attempts" assignment. You do not earn points via the "Study Attempts" assignment, but it allows you to continue to practice the problems after the homework due date.

To assist students with any technical issues, personal extenuating circumstances, or illness during a Lesson, we will drop the two lowest Homework scores earned. Therefore, the 10 highest Homework scores will be used toward your final grade, and each assignment is worth 2%.

documents.title: Lesson 1 EP (Extra Credit)
documents.content:
Extra Credit (up to 4%)

Students may earn extra credit by completing the Lesson Extra Practice (EP) via McGraw-Hill Connect for each Lesson. There are 12 EP (Extra Credit) opportunities, one for each of the 12 Lessons of the course. Each EP (Extra Credit) allows you to earn up to 0.33% extra credit toward your final course grade. You may take each EP (Extra Credit) an unlimited number of times, and the highest score will be used toward the Extra Credit (for example: if your highest score on an EP assignment for the Lesson is 90%, you would earn 90% of .33, or .297, in Extra Credit toward your final grade).

All of the EP (Extra Credit) for a Module will stay open until 11:59 p.m. on the night before the scheduled exam (see the Course Calendar for specific dates/times). The EP (Extra Credit) is designed to be attempted/taken at the completion of each Lesson. You may also take them again in the days before an Exam for study purposes; however, please do not wait until the last days before an exam to attempt all of the EP (Extra Credit) for the first time for the entire Module. If you do, you may find there is not enough time to complete them and/or fully understand the Lesson material.

Once the EP (Extra Credit) close, it cannot be re-opened for any reason, and there will be no further Extra Credit opportunities for that Module. Likewise, extensions will not be granted for EP (Extra Credit) for any reason, including technical issues, personal extenuating circumstances, or illness. Plan ahead and complete at least one attempt at each EP (Extra Credit) at the end of each Lesson throughout your study of the material, so you do not lose your Extra Credit opportunity due to an emergency at the end of the Module.

documents.title: Lesson 2 EP (Extra Credit)
documents.content:
Extra Credit (up to 4%)

Students may earn extra credit by completing the Lesson Extra Practice (EP) via McGraw-Hill Connect for each Lesson. There are 12 EP (Extra Credit) opportunities, one for each of the 12 Lessons of the course. Each EP (Extra Credit) allows you to earn up to 0.33% extra credit toward your final course grade. You may take each EP (Extra Credit) an unlimited number of times, and the highest score will be used toward the Extra Credit (for example: if your highest score on an EP assignment for the Lesson is 90%, you would earn 90% of .33, or .297, in Extra Credit toward your final grade).

All of the EP (Extra Credit) for a Module will stay open until 11:59 p.m. on the night before the scheduled exam (see the Course Calendar for specific dates/times). The EP (Extra Credit) is designed to be attempted/taken at the completion of each Lesson. You may also take them again in the days before an Exam for study purposes; however, please do not wait until the last days before an exam to attempt all of the EP (Extra Credit) for the first time for the entire Module. If you do, you may find there is not enough time to complete them and/or fully understand the Lesson material.

Once the EP (Extra Credit) close, it cannot be re-opened for any reason, and there will be no further Extra Credit opportunities for that Module. Likewise, extensions will not be granted for EP (Extra Credit) for any reason, including technical issues, personal extenuating circumstances, or illness. documents.title: Exam_1_ACCTG211_SP25 - Requires Respondus LockDown Browser
documents.content:
Following is the Smeal College of Business Honor Code:

We, the Smeal College of Business community, aspire to the highest ethical standards and will hold each other accountable to them. We will not engage in any action that is improper or that creates the appearance of impropriety in our academic lives, and we intend to hold this standard in our future careers.

 

According to the Penn State Principles and University Code of Conduct:

Academic integrity is a basic guiding principle for all academic activity at Penn State University, allowing the pursuit of scholarly activity in an open, honest, and responsible manner. According to the University’s Code of Conduct, you must neither engage in nor tolerate academic dishonesty. This includes, but is not limited to cheating, plagiarism, fabrication of information or citations, facilitating acts of academic dishonesty by others, unauthorized possession of examinations, submitting work of another person, or work previously used in another course without informing the instructor, or tampering with the academic work of other students.

The disciplinary process and your rights regarding academic integrity are outlined in Penn State’s University Faculty Senate Policy 49-20 and are supplemented by Penn State’s Office of Undergraduate Education Procedure G-9.

While this is not an exhaustive list, following are a few examples of actions during the examination process that could result in an Honor Code violation: 1) accessing items that you have been asked to place in the Testing Center’s approved green-colored drawstring bags; 2) accessing an unapproved examination aid; 3) using a calculator other than the calculator provided to you during the exam check-in process; 4) reproducing exam questions for other parties or transmitting exam questions to other parties; 5) entering the testing center restroom facility with your cell phone, scratch paper, exam ticket, or any unapproved examination aid; and 6) leaving the Testing Center with your scratch paper or exam ticket.

By clicking on the "Take the Quiz" button below, you implicitly certify that you have not engaged in any action that conflicts with the Smeal College of Business Honor Code or the Penn State Principles and University Code of Conduct prior to the start of the exam, and you further implicitly certify that you will abide by the Smeal College of Business Honor Code and the Penn State Principles and University Code of Conduct during the exam.

Copyright 2022 Schalyn Sohn and Kristy Schenck.  No portion of this exam may be used for commercial purposes, reproduced, published, broadcast, rewritten for broadcast or publication, or redistributed directly or indirectly in any medium without the express written permission of the authors.

File any conflicts with the Registrar.  All conflict requests must be filed with the registrar office.  The deadline for filing a final exam conflict with the registrar is Sunday, March 9th.

documents.content:
**Both Exam 2 and the Final are open for scheduling at the testing center.  Please make note of your reservations so that you have the correct time for the correct exam!!!

 

Final Exam Scheduled

The Final Exam for ACCTG 211 for Spring 2025 Semester is scheduled for Tuesday May 6th at the Pollock Testing Center. Similar to our other exams, students will be able to register for their exam time based on the time slots provided by the testing center. Please review your final exam schedule. File any conflicts with the Registrar.  All conflict requests must be filed with the registrar office.  The deadline for filing a final exam conflict with the registrar is Sunday, March 9th.

Exam 2 Registration

Registration for ACCTG 211 exams begins at 8:00 AM, two weeks prior to the exam.  

The ACCTG 211 Module 2 Exam is scheduled for Monday, March 3rd and Tuesday, March 4th.  Be on the lookout for an email from eTesting today Monday, February 17th. You should receive an email from the Testing Center at eTesting Support (etest@psu.edu) with directions on how to schedule your exam. Registration begins at 8:00 AM, and you do not need to wait for the email in order to register for a time. To register for your exam, go to the following link at the dates/times below: Exam 2 signup  and select the link at the top of the page, "Students: Choose Exam Time." 

  • Register for your exam time as soon as possible when the registration begins to get the best choices of available times. Popular times fill quickly.
  • Remember that the Pollock Testing Center closes promptly at 11:00 PM, regardless of what time you start your exam. We do not recommend students to schedule with a 9:30 PM exam start time as the Testing Center closes promptly at 11:00 PM.

documents.title: Exam 1 Grades Posted
documents.content:
Confirming the posting of the Module 1 Exam scores on Canvas and providing some follow-up information.  The median score for all students who took the Module 1 Exam was 76, and this is consistent with past median scores during the Spring semester when exams were given in the Pollock Testing Center.

Great job with attending class (in-person or via WEB videos) and following the Read, Watch, Do, Review Process!! 

We conduct various checks after the conclusion of each exam in an effort to validate the exam scores prior to posting them to our Canvas grade book. As a result of this validation process, and combined with observations that we made during the administration of the exam, we have decided to provide the equivalent points associated with one exam question as credit back to all students. Please note that we included the effect of this credit in your Module 1 Exam score when we uploaded the results to Canvas…so your Canvas score for the Module 1 Exam already includes the effect of these additional points. Some of you may notice that your exam score exceeds 100% as a result of these additional points. Canvas treats any amount in excess of 100% as extra credit in the course. If you are interested to review your exam, please sign-up via this link: Exam Review

We would like to remind you to make use of the "Grade Calculator" excel file found on the canvas page Course Grades and Grade Calculator to determine your current overall grade in the course. A reminder that Extra Credit assignments ONLY help your grade. Let's say you earn 50% on all extra credit assignments then at the end of the semester you would increase your grade by 2% i.e. possibly going from 88% to 90%. You have unlimited attempts on the Extra Credit assignments and we post the highest grade on Extra Credit assignments.  

The highest assignment grade for HW for Lesson 1 - Lesson 3 and for EC for Lesson 1 - Lesson 3 have been posted to Canvas. Please confirm you see your highest assignment grade for each of these assignments.  

Great job overall on the Module 1 Exam! 

~ Your ACCTG 211 Instructional Team.
