documents.title: EXAM INFO-IMPORTANT
documents.content:
Since the Pollock Testing Center has made some changes to their process this academic year, we wanted to reach out with some reminders. See this PPT for specific information.

    1.  Plan to arrive 30 minutes before your scheduled time. Early is better than late! 
    2. Do not be late. We have heard from other courses that students that have arrived 1-2 minutes late are told they cannot take their exam. Since the center is full on our exam days, you probably will not find a time to reschedule. Failure to take the exam on Monday or Tuesday, will result in a 0.
    3. Please be respectful to the Testing Center staff. If you are rude or disruptive, you may be asked to move to the end of the line, reported to your instructor and/or asked to leave.
      1. If you are asked to leave, you will not have an opportunity to start or finish your exam.
      2. If the instructional team is made aware that a student is rude or disruptive, the instructional team has the discretion to penalize as they see fit which could include a zero for missing the exam.
    4. IF YOU MISS YOUR EXAM TIME-YOU WILL GET A 0 ON THE EXAM

 

Since the exam will not launch automatically, you will need to click on the exam for it to launch. Please do this as soon as you are logged into Canvas. If you take too much time to launch the exam, you may not have the full time. The testing center is full on our exam days and the staff may ask you to leave if you go past your appointment time, even if you are not done with the exam.

  1. The exam is titled: Exam_1_ACCTG211_SP25 – Requires Respondus LockDown Browser  
  2. Please see the screenshot below for the location of the exam.
    1. It can also be found on the right side of your Canvas page under “To Do.” Please note that the Exam Module is locked until the exam morning so you may not see the module and/or exam until after 7:30AM on exam day.

documents.title: Reminders: Exam 1
documents.content:
ACCTG 211 Exam 1 on Lessons 1, 2, and 3, is scheduled for Monday, February 10th and Tuesday, February 11th , to be taken in Pollock Testing Center. 

  • Make sure you have received a confirmation email from eTesting confirming the time you selected for the exam. 
    • Arrive 30 minutes prior to your exam time. 
    • Do not be late. We have heard from other courses that students arriving 1-2 minutes late are told they cannot take their exam. Since the center is full on our exam days, you probably will NOT find a time to reschedule. Failure to take the exam by end of day on Tuesday, will result in a 0.
    • Please check the weather and factor in any weather delays to your travel time to the exam.  The testing center CANNOT admit you to the location after your time slot has begun.
  • IF YOU MISS YOUR EXAM TIME-YOU WILL GET A 0 ON THE EXAM
  • Exams are closed book/ closed notes.
  • Please bring your student ID and a pencil or pen to the testing center.
  • The testing center will provide you with a basic calculator and a blank sheet of paper for you to use when taking your exam.
    • Please make sure you take a calculator when you check in to the exam.  You will turn in the sheet of paper when you exit the Pollock Testing Center.
    • The lockdown browser should also provide a basic calculator on the computer - you are free to use that as well.
  • You are not allowed to use your own calculator, only the basic calculator provided to you by the Pollock Testing Center.

Some important notes for the Module 1 Exam (65-minute exam):

           1) you will be given 25 questions (questions are selection based so you will be required to select the correct answer from a list of options)

  • this means that you will have just under 2.5 minutes per question (on average) to complete the exam...some questions will take longer while other questions will take less time

           2) pace yourself properly, as the 65-minute time frame will move very quickly;

           3) we will provide a basic 4-function calculator when you check into the exam...you will not be allowed to use any other calculator during the exam (you may use the basic calculator that is provided on your screen with the lockdown browser)

           4) blank scratch paper will be provided to you.

Good luck!

Also…repeating previous reminders that the Testing Center will close at 11:00 pm EST, regardless of when you start your exam.  

Please note the following Pollock Testing Center Protocols:

Module 2 will unlock for students at 12AM Wednesday morning.  If you are working ahead you may begin the textbook readings for Lesson 4 (Purchase and Sale of Inventory) as noted below: 

  • Textbook: Chapter 4 - Accounting for Merchandising Operations
  • Textbook: Chapter 5 - Inventories and Cost of Sales and Appendix 5A Inventory Costing under Periodic System and 5B Inventory Estimation Methods

Finally...repeating a previous reminder that we will not be able to answer any questions related to the content of the Module 1 Exam while the exam window is open. We trust that you have been doing a great job in your exam preparations and we wish you well on the exam! No classes are held on exam day. You can do this!

documents.title: Lesson 3 Videos and Exam 1 Review
documents.content:
Exam 1 Prep

As you continue to prepare for the exam, please continue to refer to:

  • Module 1 Exam Preparation page located at the end of Module 1.  The Exam Prep includes the Review Topics, Review Videos, Sample Exam and Answer Keys. Feel free to review and practice any of the material already posted in Module 1.
  • Another resource are the Study Attempts (non-graded) and Extra Credit assignments in Connect.

 

Office Hours

Please note that there are no office hours once the exam window opens - so our instructional team (instructors AND TAs) are not able to answer content related questions once the exam window begins on Monday 2/10 through the close of the exam window on Tuesday 2/11.

There will also be extra TA office hours on Sunday, February 9th for anyone needing additional help. In-person help is available in 102 Business on Sunday from 11am to 6 pm and via zoom from 11am- 3 pm, 4pm-5pm and 6-8 pm.

Beta Alpha Psi will be available to help with any questions you have on the sample exam from 3-4 pm EST in 102 Business Building.

  • In person in 102 Business Building
  • Beta Alpha Psi, a national honor society with a stated purpose of recognizing outstanding academic achievements in the fields of accounting, finance, and information systems, will host a special evening session to help answer questions you might have on the sample exam. 

McGraw-Hill Connect

  • Our Module 1 Extra Credit assignments will be due Sunday 2/9/25 at 11:59 pm EST. We hope that you have already started working on these extra credit assignments.  (Unlimited attempts; the highest score will be posted to Canvas. The Extra Credit assignment can only HELP your grade-do not miss the extra credit opportunity in the course!)

You can also practice the non-graded assignments in Connect as well.

Happy studying!

documents.title: In Person Class Update Please Read: In Person Classes Cancelled 2/6 until Noon
documents.content:
Many of you have likely seen the UP Weather Alert for cancelled classes and activities until 12PM tomorrow (Thursday 2/6).

Please note that this means that Section 001 and Section 003 (Curling) WILL NOT meet (Thursday 2/6).  Students enrolled in Section 001 and 003 are still responsible for finishing Lesson 3 content today by watching the Lesson 3 videos found under the "Watch" section of the Lesson 3 canvas page (the content should be the Error Analysis videos).  Please reach out to Professor Curling or Karen Trust (course coordinator) if you have any questions on the lesson videos.

Just a reminder that all students are expected to finish lesson 3 content by end of day Thursday to stay on track.  There will be Friday labs on 2/7 and the Module 1 extra credit is still due on Sunday 2/9. 

Stay safe!

ACCTG 211 Instructional Team

documents.title: Module 1 Wrap-Up
documents.content:
As we wrap up Module 1 of our course, we would like to remind you of several items that will help keep you on track with our expectations for you at this point in the course:

  • Exam 1 is scheduled for Monday, February 10th and Tuesday, February 11th.  You should have registered for your exam by now.  Please refer to the announcement "Important Module 1 Exam Registration Reminder" for details on registration. 
  • https://lat-apps.tlt.psu.edu/eTesting/Students 
  • Make sure you have received a confirmation email from eTesting confirming the time you selected for the exam. Mark your personal calendar correctly with the time you selected. If you miss your exam, you will receive a zero.

Thursday Class

  • Attend class as we wrap-up Module 1 and review "Error Analysis." The PPT files for the live lecture on Lesson 3 can be found in "Lesson 3 Files." It is recommended you download / review the PPT slides prior to coming to class.
  • Or if you are attending via WEB option, download the “Error Analysis PPT” before you watch the "Error Analysis" videos. 

TA Friday Lab & Instructor Review Video 

  • The topic for each of Friday TA lab sessions this week will be a review for the upcoming Module 1 Exam. Please refer to "Module 1 Friday TA Lab files" to obtain the PPT files and watch past and future zoom lab recordings. Anyone is invited to attend one of the labs via Zoom. Follow this link to download the Weekly Class Schedule.

Exam Prep Information

  • A “Module 1 Exam Preparation” page is available at the bottom of Module 1 in our Canvas course.  There, you will find a list of review topics, exam review videos, and a sample exam. 
 

Other Opportunities for Help 

  • Please visit our excellent TAs office hours for additional help in preparing for the exam.  They are an excellent resource for helping you prepare. The TA Office Hour schedule can be found in Module 0 "Meet Your Instructional Team". 
  • REMINDER: There are no office hours on exam days. The last opportunity for help will be on Sunday. We will not be answering content questions on Monday and Tuesday.

McGraw-Hill Connect 

  • Lesson 3 HW is due Wednesday, February 5th, at 11:59pm.  
  • Your Lesson 1 and 2 Homework grades have been posted. We will post Lesson 3 Homework grades by this Friday.  
  • Our Module 1 Extra Credit assignments will be due on Sunday, February 9th at 11:59 pm. We hope that you have already started working on these extra credit assignments.  Remember: these are the ONLY extra credit opportunities in the course.  Don’t miss them! 

You can do this!  Lean on your instructional team…including our excellent TAs…and know that we are all here to assist you in your final preparations for our Module 1 Exam. 

Happy Studying! 

~Your ACCTG 211 Instructional Team.

documents.title: Continuing Lesson 3, Important Exam 1 Reminders
documents.content:
Exam 1 Date & Registration Reminder 

  • The ACCTG 211 Module 1 Exam is scheduled for Monday, February 10th and Tuesday, February 11th.  
  • To register for your exam, go to the following link: https://lat-apps.tlt.psu.edu/eTesting/Students  and select the link at the top of the page, "Students: Choose Exam Time." 

Exam information and Tips

  • All students (Sections 001, 002, 003, 004, 005) will be taking exams at University Park Pollock Testing Center via eTesting. Registration for ACCTG 211 exams begins at 8:00 AM two weeks prior to the first day of an exam. 

 Registration tips:

  • Register for your exam time as soon as possible when the registration begins to get the best choices of available times. Popular times fill quickly.
  • Remember that the Pollock Testing Center closes promptly at 11:00 PM, regardless of what time you start your exam. Please be sure to schedule enough time to complete the exam.  
  • Make sure you receive a confirmation email from eTesting confirming the time you selected for the exam. If you do not receive this confirmation email, then your registration was not completed correctly, and you should try again. There is no guarantee that you will be able to take the exam if you failed to schedule an exam time.  Failure to take the exam on the exam date will result in a zero on that exam.
  • When you receive the confirmation email, be sure you mark your personal calendar correctly with the time you selected.
  • If you miss your exam, you will receive a zero.
  • Students can show up 30 minutes prior to the exam time - students will NOT be admitted to the testing center after their scheduled exam time - so please plan to show up early

Lesson 3: Instructor Lecture or Lesson 3 Videos 

  • Please refer to the "Lesson 3 -- The Basics of Accrual Accounting" page for Learning Objectives, and what to do as you go through the Read, Watch, Do, Review process. 
  • Attend class as your schedule indicates as we continue with Lesson 3. The PPT files for the live lecture on Lesson 3 can be found in "Lesson 3 Files". It is recommended you download / review the PPT slides prior to coming to class. 
  • Or if you are attending via WEB option, continue watching the Lesson 3 Videos (pre-recorded videos) in Canvas. We recommend that you download the PPT files for the Lesson 3 Videos before watching the videos. Reminder: There are many videos found in Lesson 3 since the videos are broken down into mini-lectures.  Please note that the lesson 3 videos span 3 class periods - the Error Analysis videos are not needed to complete the Lesson 3 homework but all other videos should be watched prior to Wednesday in order to finish the homework

TA Labs 

  • There are Tuesday labs scheduled at 4:35pm and 6pm. Follow this link to download the  Weekly Class Schedule.

Homework 

  • Lesson 3 HW is due Wednesday, February 5th at 11:59pm. 
  • Reminder: You have 5 “check your work” in each attempt; unlimited attempts; and we post your highest grade earned. 
  • If you have questions related to completing homework, you may visit our helpful and qualified ACCTG211 TAs during office hours, offered Monday through Wednesday. Please refer to the "TA Office Hours" schedule.

Remember to begin working on the Lesson 3 EP (Extra Credit) in Connect as we wrap up Lesson 3.  Although the assignment is not due until Sunday, February 9th, we expect students to be working on the EP assignments as we conclude each lesson.  Reminder these are the only extra credit opportunities in the course.

documents.content:
Lesson 3: Instructor Lecture or Lesson 3 Pre-Recorded Videos

  • Please refer to the "Lesson 3 -- The Basics of Accrual Accounting" page for Learning Objectives, and what to do as you go through the Read, Watch, Do, Review process.
  • Attend class as we begin Lesson 3. The PPT files for the live lecture on Lesson 3 can be found in “Lesson 3”. It is recommended you download / review the PPT slides prior to coming to class.
  • Or if you are attending via WEB option, begin watching the Lesson 3 Videos (pre-recorded videos) in Canvas. The PPT filesfor the Videos are located in the link above the videos

TA Labs

Please attend a Friday TA lab as part of your "Read-Watch-Do-Review" process for Lesson 3. Follow this link to download the Weekly Class Schedule

Homework / Extra Credit

  • Lesson 3 HW is due Wednesday, February 5th, at 11:59pm. 
  • Reminder: You have check your work 5 times in each attempt; unlimited attempts; and we post your highest grade earned. 
  • If you have questions related to completing homework, you may visit our helpful and qualified ACCTG 211 TA's during office hours, offered Monday through Wednesday. Please refer to the "TA Office Hours" schedule
  • Remember to continue working on the EP assignments (Extra Credit) in Connect .Although the assignments are not due until February 9th, we expect students to be working on the EP assignments as we conclude each lesson.  Just a reminder that these assignments are the only extra credit opportunity provided in the course.
  • Please continue to check Canvas to confirm your highest homework grade is posted to Canvas.

Exam 1 Registration and Information

All students (Sections 001, 002, 003, 004, 005) will be taking exams at University Park Pollock Testing Center via eTesting. Registration for ACCTG 211 exams begins at 8:00AM two weeks prior to the first day of an exam. 

The ACCTG 211 Module 1 Exam is scheduled for Monday, February 10th and Tuesday, February 11th.  You should have received an email on Monday from the Testing Center at eTesting Support (etest@psu.edu) with directions on how to schedule your exam. Registration begins at 8:00 AM, and you do not need to wait for the email in order to register for a time.

 To register for your exam, go to the following link at the dates/times below: https://testingapps.it.psu.edu/etesting/students

                     -select the link at the top of the page, "Students: Choose Exam Time."

Registration tips:

  • Register for your exam time as soon as possible when the registration begins to get the best choices of available times. Popular times fill quickly.
  • Remember that the Pollock Testing Center closes promptly at 11:00PM, regardless of what time you start your exam. Please be sure to schedule enough time to complete the exam.  A special alert to anyone who schedules a 10:00PM exam start time: arriving after 10:00PM to start your exam will mean that you will NOT be given the full 60 minutes to take your exam, as the Testing Center closes promptly at 11:00PM.
  • Last semester the Pollock Testing Center started turning students away if they were late for their scheduled time. Schedule a time that you KNOW you will not be late or you will risk not being able to take the exam! Failure to take the exam on the exam date will result in a zero on that exam.
  • Make sure you receive a confirmation email from eTesting confirming the time you selected for the exam. If you do not receive this confirmation email, then your registration was not completed correctly, and you should try again. There is no guarantee that you will be able to take the exam if you failed to schedule an exam time.  Failure to take the exam on the exam date will result in a zero on that exam.
  • When you receive the confirmation email, be sure you mark your personal calendar correctly with the time you selected.

If you miss your exam, you will receive a zero

documents.title: Exam 1 Registration Reminders
documents.content:
Exam 1 Registration Reminders

We want to send an important reminder about exam registration. 

All students (Sections 001, 002, 003, 004,005) will be taking exams at University Park Pollock Testing Center via eTesting. Registration for ACCTG 211 exams begins at 8:00AM two weeks prior to the first day of an exam. 

The ACCTG 211 Module 1 Exam is scheduled for Monday, February 10th and Tuesday, February 11th.  Be on the lookout for an email from eTesting on Monday. You should receive an email from the Testing Center at eTesting Support (etest@psu.edu) with directions on how to schedule your exam. Registration begins at 8:00 AM, and you do not need to wait for the email in order to register for a time.

To register for your exam, go to the following link at the dates/times below: https://testingapps.it.psu.edu/etesting/students

                     -select the link at the top of the page, "Students: Choose Exam Time."

Registration tips:

  • Register for your exam time as soon as possible when the registration begins to get the best choices of available times. Popular times fill quickly.  You are permitted to check in to the exam up to 30 minutes early - NO LATE CHECK INS ARE ALLOWED!  When selecting your exam time make sure you choose a time where you can be early!
  • Remember that the Pollock Testing Center closes promptly at 11:00PM, regardless of what time you start your exam. Please be sure to schedule enough time to complete the exam.  A special alert to anyone who schedules a 10:00PM exam start time: arriving after 10:00PM to start your exam will mean that you will NOT be given the full 60 minutes to take your exam, as the Testing Center closes promptly at 11:00PM.
  • Last semester the Pollock Testing Center started turning students away if they were late for their scheduled time. Schedule a time that you KNOW you will not be late or you will risk not being able to take the exam! Failure to take the exam on the exam date will result in a zero on that exam.
  • Make sure you receive a confirmation email from eTesting confirming the time you selected for the exam. If you do not receive this confirmation email, then your registration was not completed correctly, and you should try again. There is no guarantee that you will be able to take the exam if you failed to schedule an exam time.  Failure to take the exam on the exam date will result in a zero on that exam.
  • When you receive the confirmation email, be sure you mark your personal calendar correctly with the time you selected.
  • If you miss your exam, you will receive a zero.

~On behalf of your ACCTG 211 Instructional Team

documents.title: Getting started in ACCTG 211
documents.content:
Course Orientation

Thank you for attending our Course Orientation yesterday! If you missed the live Orientation session or were unable to attend the zoom orientation session, please review the orientation video posted in "Course Orientation Live Session Recording and Slides" in Module 0 as soon as possible.  Watching the orientation session will provide you with tips on navigating the course that will be very helpful going forward - so please make every effort to watch the recording!

If you have not already, please review ALL the material in "Course Syllabus, Grades, and Exam Instructions" and "Module 0: Course Orientation" to be able to open Module 1 of the course. You will not be able to see Module 1 until all the steps have been completed in those modules.

Lesson 1

Tomorrow (Thursday) we will present Lesson 1 in-class. Please refer to "Module 1: Lesson 1 -- Introduction to Accounting" to start the "Read Watch Do Review" for the lesson. It is recommended you download / review the PPT slides prior to coming to class or watching the videos. Please refer to "Lesson 1: Introduction to Accounting" to download the PPT slides.  If you are a WEB student, please download the PPT slides and begin watching the videos on Canvas. The videos are posted below the link for the PPT slides in Canvas. As a general rule, if you are watching the videos, you should expect to get half way through the video content before lab on Friday.  Remember there are multiple short videos that should equate roughly to two 75 minute classes.

documents.title: Welcome to ACCTG 211!
documents.content:
Please note for the Spring 2025 semester, similar to past semesters, whether you are enrolled in the “Live” class section(s) or “WEB” section(s) we plan to administer exams IN-PERSON to ALL students at University Park at the Pollock Testing Center.

ACCTG211 Orientation Information

Please use the Course Calendar file when planning your schedule for completing Lesson tasks/assignments; it provides additional information for each week of the semester.

documents.title: Course Grades and Grade Calculator
documents.content:
ACCTG 211 Grades, Grade Calculator, and FAQ’s

To help you determine where you currently stand in the course, please download this ACCTG 211 Grade Calculator (see directions and instructional video below).

Grades are based on the following criteria:

12 Homework Assignments
  • Lowest 2 assignments are dropped
  • Unlimited attempts until the due date
  • Highest score is used in Canvas
 20%
Module 1 Exam (65-minute exam) 16%
Module 2 Exam (65-minute exam) 16%
Module 3 Exam (65-minute exam) 16%
Module 4 Exam (65-minute exam) 16%
Module 5 Exam (60-minute exam) 16%
TOTAL 100%
12 Extra Credit Assignments (EP Problems)
  • Unlimited attempts until the due date
  • Highest score is used in Canvas
  • Possible 0.33% for each extra credit assignment completed
 4%

Grading Scale

Standard rounding will be used (ex: 89.5% will be rounded to an A-)

A

94% - 100%

A-

90% - 93%

B+

87% - 89%

B

83% - 86%

B-

80% - 82%

C+

75% - 79%

C

70% - 74%

D

60% - 69%

F

0% - 59%

Grade Calculator - Estimating your Grade

Canvas does not always accurately calculate your grade until the end of the semester when all grades are entered. Therefore, we do not show course totals in the Canvas gradebook.

To help you determine where you currently stand in the course, please download this ACCTG 211 Grade Calculator.

The Grade Calculator will give you the best representation of where you stand at each point in the semester.

  • Download the file. (Do not use the online version.)
  • Open using Excel.
  • Enter your assignment grades from Canvas into the "blue" cells
  • To get an idea of where you might finish in the course put in some "sample" figures for any remaining Homework, Extra Credit, and Exams.
  • Select your evaluation point using the drop-down menu in the blue box under the Exam Scores section.

Use the grade calculator to see what scores you would need to receive on the remaining graded items to earn the course grade you desire.

To follow an example of how to use the ACCTG 211 Grade Calculator, please view the following video:

Remember

  • The grading scale you see on the Grade Calculator will not be changed at the end of the semester - so this is an accurate representation of the scores you need to earn your desired grade.
  • Only YOU can determine if you are willing and able to adjust your study habits and/or the time you spend on ACCTG 211 in the remainder of the semester to maintain your performance in the course, or improve your performance, to earn the grade you desire.
  • Like the syllabus says: EXPECT TO RECEIVE THE GRADE THAT YOU EARN. Work all semester toward the grade you "need" or desire by seeing our TAs regularly and getting help often. At the end of the semester, it is too late to ask for "extra work," something you can do to improve your grade, or for your grade to be "bumped up" because you are "close" to a desired grade.

Frequently Asked Questions

Click each of the banners below to see answers to FAQs

Final Grade Questions

Can my final grade be bumped up/changed?
  • The short answer is no. We do our best to ensure the grade cut-offs are clearly stated in the syllabus and throughout the semester. We do this to ensure that our students understand exactly what they need to do in order to be successful in the course.
  • If you are concerned about the entrance to major requirements for the Smeal College or fulfilling requirements for your major or minor, please contact your academic advisor to discuss your academic progress and they can provide guidance to achieve your goals.

Homework/Extra Credit Grade Questions

The grade I see in Connect is wrong.
  • Your best attempt grade is synced to the Canvas gradebook. Please look at your grades in Canvas for the most accurate information. Grades are synced within 1 business day of the due date. If you still believe your grade is not reflected correctly, send screenshots to the course coordinator or your instructor of record.
Can I receive an extension to complete the homework/extra credit? Can you re-open the assignment?
  • We do not extend the due dates for assignments since they are open for an extended amount of time. The expectation is that you are working on assignments as they are assigned.
Can I re-take an exam?
  • No. Once exams are opened, even if you have not answered a question, it is considered taken and no make-ups or re-takes will be given.
HELP! I missed my exam time at the Pollock Testing Center.
  • Try to reschedule by checking the e-testing registration site.
  • Go to the testing center as soon as possible and ask if they can assist you.
  • Keep checking the e-testing registration site.
  • If you cannot reschedule the exam, you will receive a “0”.

Performance Improvement Questions

HELP! I am not doing well in the course. How can I do better?
The following are ways you can perform better in ACCTG211:
  1. Follow the Read, Watch, Do, Review process.
  2. All students have access to the videos in Canvas. If you are not attending class in person, you should be watching the videos. The videos provide the same amount/level of coverage of the content as the in-person sections (so roughly 2.5 hours of lecture videos per week).
  3. Attend Friday labs. During Lab, the TAs go over course concepts and problems associated with the homework.
    • We also have Tuesday lab where the TAs cover different problems than the Friday labs.
  4. Attend TA or Instructor office hours.
    • The Office Hours are listed on the “Meet Your Instructors” Canvas page. We have several qualified and experienced TAs who have over 25 hours of open office hours in person and via Zoom every week. These TAs were all vetted by our team and are your first source of help.
    • We also have 3 amazing professors for our course. These professors have office hours at various times during the week. You may speak to any of the professors.
  5. Complete all homework and extra credit assignments without looking at the solution first. Once the assignment has closed, you can complete the non-graded assignments for extra practice.
  6. Do the sample exams to prepare.
  7. Watch the Exam Reviews that are created by the instructors.

documents.title: Exam Directions and Instructions
documents.content:
ACCTG211 Exam Information

All Accounting 211 exams are:

  • • In-person in the Pollock Testing Center
  • • Closed book
  • • Closed note

At Pollock Testing Center:

  • • Calculator and blank paper will be provided upon arrival and returned when you are finished
  • • Bring only your PSU ID and a pencil.
  • • No office hours on the day of exams

Exam Dates

Exam Exam Date Exam Registration Date
Exam 1 Tuesday, February 10th and Wednesday, February 11th Tuesday, January 27th
Exam 2 Tuesday, March 3rd and Wednesday, March 4th Tuesday, February 24th
Exam 3 Wednesday, March 26th and Thursday, March 27th Wednesday, March 12th (during Spring Break)
Exam 4 Tuesday, April 15th and Wednesday, April 16th Tuesday, April 1st
Exam 5 Scheduled by Registrar TBD

Do NOT be late-you will be need to reschedule if there are any openings.  Due to the large enrollment of our course do not count on openings available for rescheduling.  If a student arrives late and is unable to take the exam, a score of 0 will result.

Scheduling Instructions for ACCTG 211 Exams through Pollock Testing Center

Scheduling your Exam

  • Exams 1-4
    • Schedule 2 weeks prior beginning at 8 am
    • etest@psu.edu will email you with directions (you do not need to wait for the email)
    • https://testingapps.it.psu.edu/etesting/students and select the link at the top of the page, "Students: Choose Exam Time."
  • Exam 5 (Final Exam)
    • Determined by the Registrar’s Office
    • https://testingapps.it.psu.edu/etesting/students and select the link at the top of the page, "Students: Choose Exam Time."

Pollock Testing Center Information

  • Students will no longer be allowed to check-in late; they can only check-in early. Students who arrive late will not be able to take their exam and if they are unable to reschedule a score of 0 will result.
  • Students will now tap their ID or their smartphone to check-in/out after passing through the turnstiles.
  • Once students have signed into their assigned computer, they must launch the Respondus LockDown browser. This will log them into Canvas.
  • Students will have to find and open their scheduled exam in Canvas.
  • Until a student starts the exam, the lockdown function is not activated; this might tempt some students to delay starting the exam.
    • Please let students know that if they delay starting the exam, they might be asked to leave at the end of their scheduled exam time, even if they are not finished.

Registration Tips

  • Register for your exam time as soon as possible when the registration window opens to get the best choices of available times. Popular times fill quickly.
  • Schedule enough time to complete the exam.
  • Pollock Testing Center closes promptly at 11:00 pm, regardless of what time you start your exam.
    • We encourage students to schedule an exam earlier than 10 pm if possible.
    • If you do schedule a 10 pm exam, plan to arrive no later than 9:45 pm as arriving late to start your exam means you will NOT be receiving the full 65 minutes to take your exam. Also, a reminder if you show up late you need to reschedule - so keep this in mind if you schedule the last time slot - there is NOT the opportunity to reschedule your exam!
  • Make sure you receive a confirmation email from eTesting (etest@psu.edu). If you do not receive this confirmation email, then your registration was not completed correctly, and you should try again.
  • Be sure you mark your personal calendar correctly with the time you selected.
  • If you miss your exam:
    • Continue to monitor the eTesting registration site to see if a space opens up.
    • Immediately go to the Pollock Testing Center Scheduling and try to change your exam to any available space remaining.
    • Go to the Pollock Testing Center-inquire if there is anything the staff can do to assist you.
    • Due to high enrollment in the course, there may not be any available spots if you miss your time.
    • If you are unable to reschedule, you will receive a 0%
    • Best advice: Do not miss your exam time!
    • The ACCTG 211 instructional team cannot override you into a full-time slot - so don’t ask.

Exam Preparation and Review

  • Attend the Exam Review at any of the Friday TA lab sessions
  • Watch the pre-recorded exam review videos

documents.title: Module 0: Course Orientation

documents.title: Getting Started in ACCTG 211
documents.content:
Orientation To-Do List

Confirm that you've reviewed and completed the following orientation items to access Module 1:

  • ✓ Course Syllabus (in the Syllabus Tab)
  • ✓ Course Calendar (in the Syllabus Tab)
  • ✓ Announcements
  • ✓ Meet Your Instructional Team
  • ✓ Attend and/or View Course Orientation Live Session
  • ✓ Sign the Smeal Honor Code
  • ✓ Access Your McGraw Hill Connect Account
  • ✓ Exam Information
  • ✓ Diversity and Inclusion Lesson
  • ✓ Wellness Resources
  • ✓ Forward Your Canvas Email
  • ✓ ACCTG 211 Contact Info

Course Structure

Modules

The course is divided into five “Modules” of material:

Module Lessons
Module 1 Lessons 1 – 3
Module 2 Lessons 4 – 6
Module 3 Lessons 7 – 8
Module 4 Lessons 9 – 10
Module 5 Lesson 11 - 12

Exams

We will present you with one exam at the end of each module of material.

Lessons

We will follow a "Read-Watch-Do-Review" approach for each Lesson in our course:

  • Read. Read the textbook chapter(s) associated with the Lesson material.  Read any canvas course announcements.
  • Watch. Attend the live lectures, watch the live or virtual lab sessions, watch the online lecture videos, and watch the online lab videos. Mix and match to fit your preferred learning style.
  • Do. Complete online assignments in McGraw-Hill Connect (graded, non-graded, and extra credit). Review and rework practice problems as demonstrated in live lectures, live or virtual lab sessions, online lecture videos, and online lab videos.
  • Review. Attend the lab review sessions. Watch the pre-recorded exam review videos when they become available. Re-watch the online lecture videos, re-watch the online lab videos, and re-work the online McGraw-Hill Connect assignments.
  • Repeat this process for EACH lesson in the course !!!

Help

If you have any questions about the course in general or how to be successful in the course, then please reach out to the Instructional team.

Canvas Browser

Which browser is best for working with Canvas?

For best performance, Instructure products should be used on the current or previous major releases of Chrome, Firefox, Edge, or Safari. Please refer to the following Canvas Browser Recommendations. If you find that you are having trouble accessing Canvas features, then we recommend that you try a different browser before investigating other potential causes.

documents.title: Academic Integrity
Generative Artificial Intelligence Course Policy
documents.content:
Defining Generative Artificial Intelligence

Let's start with the basics. Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a field of computer science focused on creating systems capable of performing tasks that typically require human intelligence. These tasks may include problem-solving, language understanding, and interaction.

GenAI refers to a category of artificial intelligence technologies designed to generate new content, such as text, images, video, audio, or code, that is similar to what a human might produce. This is achieved through algorithms, often based on neural networks, which learn patterns and structures from large datasets (OpenAI, 2024).

There are a variety of ethical considerations surrounding AI, including bias, privacy, transparency, and copyright concerns. We encourage you to consider these as you create your AI policy.

If you would like to learn more, please visit the Penn State Library Guide on Generative AI: ChatGPT and Beyond or refer to the additional resources listed on our website.

Generative Artificial Intelligence Overview

Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) has created a new landscape for students and instructors. It's essential that members of this course understand how GenAI can impact their learning journey and the importance of approaching GenAI use responsibly. The following guidelines are designed to help you and ensure a successful semester.

Guidelines for Using GenAI in this Course

  • Course Policy: In this course, the use of GenAI is prohibited.
  • Responsibility: You are responsible for the work you submit for grading to ensure Academic Integrity compliance. Unless your instructor specifically tells you otherwise, you may not use any GenAI tool for any course assignments.

Course GenAI Policy

The use of GenAI is prohibited in this course for all assignments. This policy applies to the use of all GenAI tools, including but not limited to ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude, Perplexity, Quillbot, Penn State's freely available version of Copilot, etc., and is reflective of the notion that your personal mastery of the course material is front and center. There will be courses in your educational career where GenAI is allowed or even encouraged--it can be an important collaborative tool that graduates will need for their careers. This is not one of those courses, and if the instructor finds evidence of plagiarism of any kind, the appropriate punitive actions will be taken.

According to Faculty-Senate Policy G-9, "Academic Integrity, misrepresenting another's words, results, processes, or ideas in whole or in part without giving appropriate attribution, citation, or credit is an academic integrity violation." This includes submitting GenAI output as one's own (e.g., plagiarism).

Please refer to the university policies regarding academic integrity in part 2 of the syllabus. This provides more in-depth details about university and college processes involving plagiarism and the Academic Integrity Violation Process, as well as the values outlined in the Smeal Honor Code.

documents.title: McGraw-Hill Textbook & Connect Instructions
documents.content:
Textbook Info

The textbook for this course is based on selected chapters from Financial and Managerial Accounting 9/e by Wild with Connect software. Connect is an online Assignment and assessment software you’ll use to complete homework, extra credit, and other optional assignments. Connect will include a media rich eBook and an adaptive eBook: Smart Book 2.0. Once registered you’ll have electronic access for 18 months.

How to Register for McGraw-Hill Connect

  • Step 1: Go to any assignment.
  • Step 2: Click "Go to Connect."
  • Step 3: Enter your PSU e-mail in the box area. If you’ve used Connect previously or concurrently in another course, use that same e-mail. Otherwise, you’ll be asked to create a McGraw-Hill Education Account. If you purchased a new book from either PSU Bookstore, enter the 20-digit registration code in the Connect code area, image below. OR, if you’re comfortable with the All-digital option, select Purchase or you may click Temporary Access (free for 14 days).

Where to Get It

The accounting department has arranged for two deeply discounted purchase options listed below.

Print option (If purchase NEW printed book INCLUDES McGraw-Hill Connect) - Both PSU bookstores are offering a discounted package of the customized printed book, ISBN # 9781307711547.

OR

Online - All DIGITAL ($83): You can purchase Connect (no print book but includes the complete eBook and access to all course content) directly from within your Canvas account. Note: If you purchase the ALL DIGITAL and then later want to have a printed book, you’ll see that option in your Connect account and it costs an additional $44, anytime during your 18-month access period for the printed book, directly from McGraw-Hill. (If you think you want a printed book, purchase the "Print option" above.)

IMPORTANT NOTE: If you purchase a USED book, you will not receive the Connect access and therefore will still need to purchase Connect access.

Temporary Access is available. If you would like to test drive the All-Digital option, you may select Temporary Access. This provides 14 days of complimentary access to Connect and the eBooks, at the end of which you will need to purchase either the bookstore package or select Purchase. You must purchase full Connect access to maintain access to your course assignments and materials. Any work you complete during the 14-day free access period will be saved.

Which browser is best for working with McGraw-Hill Connect?

  • McGraw-Hill recommends using browsers (listed in order of best to worst) in reference to the use of Connect:
    • Chrome
    • Safari
    • Edger
    • Internet Explorer

McGraw-Hill Connect Technical Support

  • If you need Technical Support (forgotten password, wrong code, etc.) please contact the McGraw-Hill Education Customer Experience Group (CXG) at 800-331-5094 or mhhe.com/support) (be sure to get your case number for future reference if you call the CXG line.)
  • If the issue pertains to the homework or extra credit itself (i.e., material, grades, etc.), then the TAs can view your homework or extra assignment with you to help you understand your errors and the material.

McGraw-Hill homework and extra credit assignment grades are reflected as zero in Canvas. What do I do?

We have to manually sync the grades from McGraw-Hill Connect to and load them to Canvas. We plan to sync the homework grades by Friday each week (for lessons submitted that week) and we plan to sync the extra credit grades after the exam for those lessons has been completed.

Connect typically presents an average of all homework attempts but the highest attempt is uploaded to the Canvas gradebook. Please note, the Canvas gradebook is used to maintain student scores. It is a student's responsibility to check this frequently for accuracy and report any concerns to the Course Coordinator.

My McGraw-Hill homework and extra credit assignment grades are reflected as zero in Canvas. What do I do?

Officially, the Canvas gradebook is used to maintain student scores. It is a student's responsibility to check this frequently for accuracy and report any concerns to the Course Coordinator.

Please follow up if you do not see your grades posted by the Friday after the due date of the homework assignment. Extra credit grades will be posted after the exam date.

documents.title: Helpful Tips Using McGraw-Hill Connect
documents.content:
First, it is important for us to repeat that the subject of Accounting is best learned through practice. So we will provide a variety of McGraw-Hill assignments during the semester to help you "practice, practice, practice" the course material. The McGraw-Hill assignments provided to you throughout this semester will include:

  1. SB - SMARTBOOK (Non-Graded) - these flashcard type assignments encourages you to read the book PRIOR to attending class or watching online videos. Being prepared for class will help you better understand the lessons.
  2. LP - LECTURE & LAB PROBLEMS (Non-Graded) - not found in Connect but please practice problems presented in class or in online videos.
  3. HW - HOMEWORK (Graded) - these graded assignments are intended to provide intermediate-to-advanced-level practice questions which you should be able to solve in the middle of each Lesson (after starting the "Read" and "Watch" portions of the "Read-Watch-Do-Review" process). Make sure you complete each of these assignments by the due date listed in Connect (each due date is also listed in the "Course Calendar" on Canvas).
  4. EP - EXTRA PRACTICE (Extra Credit) - these optional extra credit assignments are intended to provide a set of advanced-level practice questions which you should be able to solve at the end of each Lesson (after completing the "Read," "Watch," and "Do" portions of the "Read-Watch-Do-Review" process). These optional extra credit assignments can also be used to help prepare you for each of the exams in the course. IMPORTANT NOTE: THESE OPTIONAL EXTRA CREDIT ASSIGNMENTS ARE THE ONLY EXTRA CREDIT ASSIGNMENTS IN THE COURSE. If you wish to complete these optional extra credit assignments, then please make sure that you complete the assignments by the due date listed in Connect (each due date is also listed in the "Course Calendar" on Canvas).

Specific Tips for Navigating the HW - HOMEWORK (Graded) and the EP - EXTRA PRACTICE (Extra Credit) Assignments:

HW and EC assignments may be completed an unlimited number of times prior to the assignment due date and your highest score will be used in determining your final grade.

A "Check Answer" button is available. Clicking this button will reveal if you have successfully completed the assignment question. You will have five attempts to check your answer when navigating each graded assignment question. After the five attempts if you want to earn a higher grade on that assignment you will have to restart the assignment. As mentioned you have unlimited attempts on the HW and EC assignments.

Graded homework (HW) is assigned for each of the 12 Lessons of the course through McGraw-Hill Connect. The McGraw-Hill Connect content will be organized by Lesson. There will be 12 homework opportunities. You will have unlimited attempts at each homework (i.e. you can do the HW as many times as you wish before the deadline), and your highest homework score will be used in determining your final grade.

Each homework must be completed by the due date/time established in the Course Calendar. Once a graded homework closes, it cannot be re-opened for any reason. However, students can continue to review their submitted homework as part of their continued practice of the course material. We will enable "study attempts" after the due date for the assignment closes.

To assist students with any technical issues, personal extenuating circumstances, or illness during a Lesson, we will drop the two lowest Homework scores earned. Therefore, the 10 highest Homework scores will be used toward your final grade, and each assignment is worth 2%

Students may earn extra credit by completing the Lesson Extra Practice (EP) via McGraw-Hill Connect for each Lesson. There are 12 EP (Extra Credit) opportunities, one for each of the 12 Lessons of the course. Each EP (Extra Credit) allows you to earn up to 0.33% extra credit toward your final course grade. You may take each EP (Extra Credit) an unlimited number of times, and the highest score will be used toward the Extra Credit (for example: if your highest score on an EP assignment for the Lesson is 90%, you would earn 90% of .33, or .297, in Extra Credit toward your final grade).

All of the EP (Extra Credit) for a Module will stay open until 11:59 p.m. on the night of the scheduled exam (see the Course Calendar for specific dates/times). The EP (Extra Credit) is designed to be attempted/taken at the completion of each Lesson. You may also take them again in the days before an Exam for study purposes; however, please do not wait until the last days before an exam to attempt all of the EP (Extra Credit) for the first time for the entire Module. If you do, you may find there is not enough time to complete them and/or fully understand the Lesson material.

Once the EP (Extra Credit) closes, it cannot be re-opened for any reason, and there will be no further Extra Credit opportunities for that Module. Likewise, extensions will not be granted for EP (Extra Credit) for any reason, including technical issues, personal extenuating circumstances, or illness. Plan ahead and complete at least one attempt at each EP (Extra Credit) at the end of each Lesson throughout your study of the material, so you do not lose your Extra Credit opportunity due to an emergency at the end of the Module.

Responsibility for Ensuring Grades are recorded on CANVAS correctly

Connect typically presents an average of all homework attempts but the highest attempt is uploaded to the canvas gradebook. Please note, the Canvas gradebook is used to maintain student scores. It is a student's responsibility to check this frequently for accuracy and report any concerns to the Course Coordinator.

documents.content:
Student Care & Advocacy

College life can be confusing and overwhelming, and sometimes you just need someone to help you sort things out. Student Care and Advocacy is committed to helping students facing unforeseen challenges navigate Penn State’s structure in close and careful collaboration with campus and community partners. Their case managers welcome any opportunity to provide consultation and direct you to the resource best equipped to meet your needs. Please call 814-863-2020 or e-mail Studentcare@psu.edu to make an appointment.

Counseling & Psychological Services

Counseling and Psychological Services (CAPS) is open and available to help you. For your health and safety during the pandemic, our services are virtual.

CAPS offers a wide range of services for undergraduate and graduate students including wellness and self-help options; group, individual, and couples counseling; crisis intervention; psychiatric services; and community education and outreach services for the University community.

https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling

documents.title: What is Academic Integrity (AI)?
documents.content:
NOTE: It is a bit confusing that the abbreviation AI is used for both "Academic Integrity" and "Artificial Intelligence", especially since the improper use of Artificial Intelligence tools is a common way to commit an Academic Integrity violation. In this module, the term AI always refers to Academic Integrity.

Message from the Director of the School of EECS

Academic Integrity is the pursuit of scholarly activity in an open, honest and responsible manner (University Faculty Senate Policy 49-20). Falsifying any aspect of your academic work jeopardizes the entire education process.

In this module, we will discuss:

  • Why academic integrity is important​
  • Types of academic integrity violations​
  • Consequences of academic integrity violations​
  • Academic integrity violation process

What is Academic Integrity?

Why is AI Important?

Types of AI Violations

Consequences of AI Violations

AI Violation Process

Take the Quiz

documents.title: Why is Academic Integrity Important?
documents.content:
Practice Makes Perfect

Engineering is an ethical profession, and unethical practices in the workplace can have dire consequences. Just like you learn and practice other tools that you’ll use in the real world (programming languages, test equipment, simulation software, etc.), practicing integrity in an academic setting will help you make ethical decisions once you’re in the workforce. Practice makes perfect!

All engineers and scientists need to follow codes of ethics. Here are a few examples of professional codes of ethics in related fields:

  • IEEE Code of Ethics
  • ACM Code of Ethics
  • NSPE Code of Ethics

While the consequences of violating academic integrity standards can be steep, the consequences of ethics violations in the workplace can be even more detrimental, including:

  • being terminated from a job
  • fines being levied onto individuals and/or companies
  • legal action
  • injury/death to users of products that were jeopardized by unethical practices

There are many examples of lapses in ethical judgment in industry that led to lawsuits, injuries, or even death. Here are some high-profile cases:

Connection Between Academic Integrity & Professional Ethics

In the real world, it is generally acceptable to look up existing resources/code, and sometimes even directly utilize existing libraries in one's project, granted that while doing so you are giving trust to the resource(s) you are using. However, if one does not have a thorough understanding of the code/library they use, this could pose security problems. The code may contain errors or even intentional malicious backdoor traps. For example, here are five common accidental sources of data leaks. You must be able to properly scrutinize, vet, or modify the code you find through other resources. If you haven't properly learned the material, you could be opening yourself, and others, to harm.

In an academic setting, the goal of projects/assessments is to learn. Looking up answers, or even submitting modified code/work from others after understanding what it does is not a good way to learn or a sustainable practice. Instructors may utilize existing resources as good, or bad, examples to help you learn, but you must develop a strong foundation to build on, so you are able to be competitive and innovative once you enter the workforce.

What is Academic Integrity?

Why is AI Important?

Types of AI Violations

Consequences of AI Violations

AI Violation Process

Take the Quiz

documents.title: Types of AI Violations
documents.content:
Below are some types of violations typically seen in EECS courses. This is not necessarily a complete list of types of AI violations, because what is considered to be an AI violation can vary from course to course, or even from assignment to assignment. You should always consult your course syllabus for details about the Academic Integrity policy and expectations for that particular course. If you're unsure whether something is ethical, consult your instructor.

AI Violations in the Lab

Examples of academic integrity violations in the lab include things like:

  • Falsifying data
    • Making up data if you don't finish an experiment
    • Changing data to make it closer to what you expect
    • Copying data from other students or lab groups
  • Using circuits designed by other students or lab groups
  • Using Artificial Intelligence tools to complete any part of the assignment unless explicitly permitted by the instructor
  • Copying answers to lab questions from other students
  • Sharing any data, circuit designs, or answers with other students
  • Posting any of your lab results on any internet website or message forum, even after the lab is over

Key Points

  • What is considered to be an AI violation can vary from course to course, or even from assignment to assignment.
  • Always check with your course instructor to determine the AI rules for that course.
  • Read the course syllabus for details on Academic Integrity.
  • The use of Artificial Intelligence tools (e.g., ChatGPT) to complete any part of an assignment is considered an AI violation, unless explicitly permitted by the instructor.
  • Sharing answers, code, or specific details about assignments or exams with others that would offer an unfair advantage is always considered an AI violation, even after the assessment is over.
  • In the case of AI, it is NOT easier to ask for forgiveness than for permission! When in doubt, ask for clarification.

AI Violations in Programming Courses

Examples of academic integrity violations in programming courses include things like:

  • Submitting code that is not your original work as your own work, such as:
    • Submitting code (partially or fully) copied from other people except course staff
    • Submitting code (partially or fully) copied from any external sources (public forums, group messages, public GitHub repositories, etc.)
    • Using Artificial Intelligence tools to complete any part of the assignment unless explicitly permitted by the instructor
    • Looking up code anywhere and then making changes to copied code. This does not make the code your own. Your submitted code must be your original work.
    • Failure to clearly identify code from an external source and/or collaboration and to properly credit the source even when it is explicitly allowed by the course
  • Not securing your own code and intentionally or unintentionally facilitating others to violate academic integrity.
    • Posting your code online that is visible by other people, such as:
      • Posting to public GitHub repositories
      • Posting to online forums and/or group messages
    • Providing any part of your code to another student
    • Leaving your code unattended in public locations (i.e., on an unlocked machine in a public space)
    • Sharing any part of your code with another student or posting any part of your code on any internet website or message forum, even after the assignment is over.

There is no fixed percentage threshold of similarities for code to be considered an academic integrity violation. We rely on the expertise of the instructors to determine whether similarities rise above what a reasonable person could expect two students working independently to construct.

AI Violations When Taking Exams

Examples of academic integrity violations with exams include things like:

  • Using unauthorized resources
    • Calculator, if not permitted
    • Notes or formula sheets, if not permitted
    • Books, if not permitted
    • Communication devices of any kind
  • Obtaining (or attempting to obtain) answers from or discussing exam content with others

For take-home or online exams:

  • Using unauthorized internet resources (including Artificial Intelligence tools such as ChatGPT)
  • Seeking assistance from or providing assistance to others (either in-person or online)
  • Posting any take-home or online exam on an internet website or message forum, even after the exam is over

AI Violations in Completing Homework

Examples of academic integrity violations in homework include:

  • Using unauthorized solution manuals
  • Using Chegg or other online "tutoring" resources
  • Using Artificial Intelligence tools to complete any part of the assignment unless explicitly permitted by the instructor
  • Copying other students' homework
  • Sharing your work with others

Other Types of AI Violations

Some other examples of AI violations include:

  • Plagiarism
  • Improper citation of materials used
  • Falsifying attendance record
  • Falsifying assignment submission record
  • Misrepresenting absences (e.g. feigning illness)

For more details, visit University Policy G-9: Academic Integrity.

What is Academic Integrity?

Why is AI Important?

Types of AI Violations

Consequences of AI Violations

AI Violation Process

Take the Quiz

documents.title: Consequences of an AI Violation
documents.content:
AI Violation Sanctions

If you are found responsible for an AI violation in a course, the sanction (punishment) may be academic and/or administrative, and may consist of one or more of the following, depending on the nature of the violation:

Academic Sanctions

  • Having to redo the assignment
  • Grade penalty on the assignment
  • Grade of zero (0) on the assignment
  • Lowering of a course grade by one (or more) letter grade(s)
  • F in the course
  • Having to participate in ethics/integrity workshops
  • XF (F for the course with a transcript notation)
  • Removal from your degree program

Administrative Sanctions

Note: The faculty member and the College of Engineering Academic Integrity Committee can recommend disciplinary sanctions, but they can be imposed only by the Penn State Office of Student Accountability and Conflict Response.

  • Formal warning
  • Conduct probation
  • Suspension from the University
  • Permanent expulsion from the University

Other Automatic Consequences of AI Violations

If you are found responsible of an AI violation in a course, the following restrictions will be automatically imposed, in addition to any academic/administrative sanctions above.

  • You are not permitted to drop the course
  • You are not permitted to use alternate grading for that course (if alternate grading is in place that semester)
  • You are not permitted to use grade forgiveness for that course
  • You are not eligible for Dean’s List that semester
  • Possible removal from the Schreyer’s Honors College
  • Possible removal from ROTC

What is Academic Integrity?

Why is AI Important?

Types of AI Violations

Consequences of AI Violations

AI Violation Process

Take the Quiz

documents.title: Academic Integrity Violation Process
documents.content:
If a student is suspected of committing an AI violation in a course, the following steps are taken:

  • The instructor speaks to the student regarding their concerns and completes the AI violation form.
    • Description of suspected violation
    • Proposed sanction
  • The student has five (5) business days to respond to the accusation.
    • The student can accept both the violation accusation and sanction.
    • The student can contest (challenge) either the violation itself, the sanction, or both.
    • If the student does not respond within 5 business days, the case proceeds as if the student accepted the accusation and sanction.
  • If the student accepts both the accusation and sanction, the sanction is imposed (see note below about previous confirmed violations).
  • If you contest either the sanction or the accusation itself, the College of Engineering will conduct a hearing with a panel of faculty members and students. The panel will decide one of the following:
    • You are not responsible for the violation.
    • You are held responsible, but with reduced sanctions.
    • You are held responsible, and the proposed sanctions are imposed.
    • You are held responsible, and additional sanctions are imposed (see note below about previous confirmed violations).

Once an academic integrity case is resolved, and sanctions are imposed, the results of the violation are filed with the Penn State Office of Student Accountability and Conflict Response and basic information is shared with Schreyer Honors College (when applicable), but are not shared with others, except in cases of some administrative sanctions or when the student has a future academic integrity violation, in accordance with FERPA rules.

Note: If a student with a current confirmed violation has any prior violation(s) of academic integrity at Penn State, the current case and the academic integrity history is reviewed, likely with additional sanctions imposed. This review and addition of sanctions happens whether or not the student contests the current violation, even if the prior violation was in a different course. Augmented sanctions are typically only imposed for students who have confirmed past AI violations (either accepted or contested and upheld). For first violations, the Committee typically defers to the instructor's judgment regarding academic sanctions if the instructor's proposed academic sanctions are reasonable under the circumstances and fall within Penn State's Sanctioning Guidelines for Violations of Academic Integrity. The Committee, however, retains the discretion to increase sanctions if the details and circumstances of the violation indicate the action to be a major or egregious violation.

For more details, visit AAPPM: G-9 Academic Integrity.

Dr. Almekkawy
